149607918.review:
I had never played an action game like that before Darksiders, so I started without knowing what to expect at all.

Well, I expected it to be difficult, but even a novice gamer like I was at the time was able to finish it without help. So that is a first good point. The controls are fairly easy to understand and complexity is added gradually enough that you never feel overwhelmed.

What I liked the most about this game is how satisfying combat is. The combos look cool, finishers are brutal, and you do feel powerful even when enemies are challenging.

The level design also blew my mind. Learning a mechanic to solve puzzles to advance through a level feels organic and natural, it does not feel like a tutorial. And when you get to each boss, you have to use all the mechanics you have learned to beat them, meaning the boss fights are also a bit of a puzzle. So every advance you make, every win, feels extra good because you also have to think, not just be good at combat.

Story-wise, I did not expect much, but I was wrong. What starts as a simple redemption quest leads you to uncover a much more intricate plot, that I did not see coming. A very good surprise.

Characters have a lot of personality and I love them all. (Or love to hate, depending.) They have their own motivations and stick to them, and interactions always elicit a reaction from the player, from laughter to tears. (I'm not fond of the lack of female characters, but I unfortunately expect it.)

All in all I really recommend it, Darksiders is a great game.

Great game with a great take on the characters of the End Times.

Highly recommend!

142912247.review:
Darksiders, developed by Vigil Games in 2010, presents an immersive journey through a post-apocalyptic realm as War, one of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse. This action-adventure masterpiece skillfully blends captivating gameplay, an engrossing storyline, and impressive visuals, ensuring an enthralling experience for players.

Gameplay:  Darksiders offers an exhilarating gameplay mix that effortlessly melds intense combat, intricate puzzles, and satisfying exploration. As players control War, they unleash a flurry of powerful attacks, crafting devastating combos and supernatural abilities to conquer an array of adversaries. The game's meticulously designed dungeons and puzzles maintain engagement and entertainment, forming a balanced and rewarding experience throughout the campaign.

Storyline and Narrative: The narrative within Darksiders is a shining jewel, enveloping players in a dark and captivating saga. By assuming the role of War, accused of hastening the Apocalypse, players embark on a journey fraught with enigma, betrayal, and redemption. The narrative's complexity is magnified by well-rounded characters and thought-provoking dialogues, bestowing a layer of depth and emotional resonance. Darksiders' storytelling prowess makes it a memorable highlight.

Graphics and Visuals: Darksiders impresses visually with its striking and atmospheric world design. The post-apocalyptic landscapes, spanning from desolate Earth to infernal abysses, are meticulously detailed and immersive. Character designs, particularly those of War and his adversaries, are remarkable, breathing life and individuality into the game's vibrant world. Despite its age, Darksiders' graphics remain visually compelling.

Sound and Music: Darksiders' sound design and music significantly enhance its immersive nature. The clash of combat, voice acting, and ambient effects seamlessly blend with gameplay, intensifying its impact. The music complements the mood of each moment, infusing layers of emotion and excitement. The auditory elements elevate the overall experience, solidifying their role as an integral component of the game's appeal.

Performance and Optimization: Darksiders performs seamlessly across various platforms, reflecting meticulous performance and optimization efforts. Players can seamlessly traverse the game with minimal loading times and a steady frame rate, guaranteeing a polished and enjoyable gaming experience. Developers' dedication to optimization ensures players can fully engage with the game's world without encountering technical hindrances.

Replayability: Though Darksiders may lack the replayability of expansive open-world titles, it provides ample reasons to revisit its world. Concealed secrets, collectibles, and optional challenges encourage players to explore every nook and cranny. Additionally, the joy of mastering combat mechanics and reliving epic moments contributes to the game's replay value.

Innovation and Originality: Darksiders stands out by amalgamating diverse gameplay elements. The seamless fusion of action, puzzle-solving, and exploration within a post-apocalyptic framework sets it apart from conventional titles. While drawing inspiration from various sources, Darksiders manages to carve its own path, providing a distinct and captivating experience.

Difficulty and Learning Curve: Darksiders offers a well-balanced difficulty and learning curve, catering to newcomers and veterans alike. Variable difficulty settings accommodate different skill levels, ensuring both a fair challenge and engaging experience. The learning curve allows players to grasp mechanics fluidly while also offering depth for those seeking a more formidable test.

Value for Money: Darksiders offers excellent value for its cost, providing a content-rich adventure that justifies its price tag. With its high-quality gameplay, captivating narrative, and impressive presentation, the game serves as a substantial investment for fans of action-adventure genres.

Comparison to Previous Titles (if applicable): N/A - Darksiders stands as the inaugural entry in its series, showcasing originality and distinctiveness.

Developer Support and Updates: Vigil Games' dedicated support for Darksiders is evident through the addressing of reported issues and the provision of post-launch patches to enrich the gameplay experience. The developers' commitment to maintaining game quality underscores their devotion to the player community.

Community Reception: Darksiders garnered widespread acclaim, resonating with both critics and players, leading to the formation of an enthusiastic and committed community. The game's positive reception highlights its lasting impact on gamers, and their admiration for its captivating gameplay and compelling narrative.

Personal Enjoyment and Recommendation: As an enthusiast of action-adventure titles, Darksiders captivated me from start to finish. Its immersive gameplay, intricate narrative, and evocative world made for an unforgettable experience. I wholeheartedly recommend Darksiders to those in search of an epic journey filled with dynamic combat and an enthralling story set against a beautifully realized post-apocalyptic backdrop.

Overall Impression: Darksiders shines as a remarkable action-adventure title that etches a lasting memory for players. Its captivating gameplay, expert storytelling, and impressive aesthetics coalesce to create an outstanding achievement within the genre. With minor areas for potential growth, Darksiders undoubtedly deserves a positive overall rating.

140270707.review:
Darksiders (2010) is an action-adventure game developed by Vigil Games and set in a post-apocalyptic world inspired by various mythologies and biblical references.

In Darksiders we assume the role of War, one of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse. The story begins when a premature and destructive apocalypse occurs on Earth, triggering a battle between Heaven and Hell. War is blamed for prematurely initiating the end of the world and is stripped of his powers.

The gameplay of Darksiders combines elements of hack and slash combat, puzzle-solving, and exploration. War possesses a wide array of weapons, including a giant sword called Chaoseater, which can be upgraded and enhanced as players progress. He also gains access to various supernatural abilities and forms that grant him additional combat options and traversal abilities, just like in the God of War and Devil May Cry series.

As players progress through the game, they acquire new weapons, abilities, and equipment, which allow for more varied combat strategies and exploration. Even though the world is nonlinear, featuring interconnected areas that can be revisited as new abilities are unlocked, enabling access to previously inaccessible locations.

Darksiders is quite an average project combining a lot of mechanics from the genre; yet for those who like hack and slash combat with exploration elements, the game might be worth your while.

reVote 7/10

132511994.review:
Darksiders is an action-adventure game developed by Vigil Games and published by THQ, first released in 2010. The game is set in a post-apocalyptic world where players take on the role of War, one of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

Graphics:
Darksiders features high-quality graphics with detailed environments, character designs, and special effects. The art style is unique and creates a dark and atmospheric world for players to explore. The game's graphics hold up well even years after its release.

Sound:
The sound design in Darksiders is excellent, with a powerful soundtrack that sets the mood and accentuates the action. The sound effects are also well-done and add to the overall immersion of the game.

Story:
The story of Darksiders is well-written and engaging, following War as he sets out to clear his name after being accused of starting the Apocalypse. The game's narrative is well-paced and has plenty of twists and turns that keep players interested.

Gameplay:
The gameplay in Darksiders is a mix of combat, puzzle-solving, and exploration. The game features fast-paced and fluid combat, as well as challenging puzzles that require players to use War's abilities to progress. The game also allows players to upgrade their abilities and weapons, adding a level of depth to the gameplay.

Good Points:

High-quality graphics with a unique art style
Excellent sound design with a powerful soundtrack
Well-written and engaging story
Fast-paced and fluid combat
Challenging puzzles and upgradeable abilities

Bad Points:

Repetitive and sometimes dull combat
Linear level design
Lack of enemy variety

Conclusion:
Overall, Darksiders is a solid action-adventure game with high-quality graphics and sound design, as well as a well-written and engaging story. The gameplay is fast-paced and fluid, with challenging puzzles and upgradeable abilities. However, the repetitive and sometimes dull combat, linear level design, and lack of enemy variety can make the game feel a bit stale after a while.

Final Score: 8/10

132351915.review:
Gameplay is as follows:
1) Go where the game says
2) Mash X to fight arena of enemies
3) Get blocked from progressing without an as-yet-unheard-of ability/key/item
4) Backtrack through most of what you just did, still mashing X sometimes
5) Get to the area you were [i]actually[/i] supposed to find first
6) Mash X more to kill more enemies
7) Do a QTE and watch your enemy defeated via a cutscene that may as well just say "Hey, wow, you pushed the B button when we told you to!!"
8) Find missing ability/key/item, discover its usage is deeply specific for 1, [i]maybe[/i] 2 things
9) Backtrack [i]once again[/i] through Dracula's Castle--sorry, [i]the Black Tower[/i]--and get through the original progress block from Step 3.
10) Repeat this dreadful loop.

Summing up: It's about as fun as that one 3D Castlevania with the hack-and-slash action-adventure mechanics. No, not [i]that[/i] 3D Castlevania, the [i]other[/i] one. You know, the bad one that sucks to play and isn't any fun. The combat mechanics here boil down to "mash X and watch for QTE buttons," and it's honestly just the worst part of a whole [i]slew[/i] of '00's-era action games. In fact, the whole game feels like it's meant to be played exclusively on a PS2 covered in [i]Korn[/i] and [i]Slipknot[/i] stickers. Halcyon days, yes, but as far as its popular game mechanics go, I look back at the '00's with little fondness in my heart.

So, if you're into generic "epic" music and the [i]World of Warcraft[/i] vibe where everyone wears colossal shoulders and boots while swinging weapons the size of their own body, you might like the way [i]Darksiders[/i] looks. You might even be able to get over how it plays because of that aesthetic, but for me, [i]Darksiders[/i] has so much tedious backtracking and "mash X to fight" combat that I just couldn't enjoy it.

Soy un padre de 50 años, probablemente una de las personas más viejas que juegan este juego. Soy padre soltero de mi hijo, que ahora tiene 14 años. Mi hijo recientemente descargó Darksiders
y en menos de una semana, ya había jugado durante más de 20 horas. Esto fue terrible para mí, ya que ya era bastante difícil para mí pasar tiempo con mi hijo, ya que él siempre sale con sus amigos o simplemente mira videos en Tiktok. Así que decidí crear una cuenta de Steam y comprar este juego para ver si podía jugar junto a él. Cargué el juego, hice el tutorial pero estaba atascado en lo que se suponía que debías hacer. Le pedí ayuda a mi hijo y organizó un juego para que yo me uniera. Me encantó porque era el mejor momento que había pasado con mi hijo desde que mi esposa había muerto. Desde entonces, este juego ha acercado a mi hijo y a mí nuevamente y ahora también pasamos tiempo juntos fuera de la casa. Este juego me recordó que hay diversión en todo, y nos ha traído tanto a mí como a mi hijo muchos recuerdos felices.

123035646.review:
El Pacto entre Los Hijos de los Hombres, los Señores del Cielo y la Escoria del Infierno se ha quebrado por la ruptura del mítico Séptimo Sello.

Hace tiempo quería revivir este juego nuevamente, y he de decir que sigue siendo un excelente hack and slach para pasar el tiempo, muy disfrutable.

Si bien se nota el paso del tiempo, en algunos aspectos como por ej toma de desiciones, gráficos, jugabilidad... lo gana en muchos otros aspectos.

Es un hack slach de la vieja escuela, al mas estilo GOW, con una historia muy buena (Al menos a mi así me lo pareció).

Pros:
- Diseño: La faceta artística del videojuego, la ambientación y el diseño tanto de esbirros, monstruos, ángeles, boss y a destacar los escenarios.
- Cantidad de combos y armas
- El prota "WAR" es un badass
- Combate fluido, lo cuál lo hace bastante adictivo, y antiestress.
- Sin bugs de cierres inesperados o perder los savegames, más allá,  de ser un juego "antiguo"
- Historia
- Buenos Puzzles, me he trabado en alguno.
- Soundtrack

Contras:
- Combos fluidos vistosos pero muy o quizás demasiado automatizados
- Mapas confusos: El mapa en el videojuego es bastante confuso en general, es dificil ubicarte tanto en el mapa general como en el minimapa.
- Pocos slots para objetos y armas rápidas (Se entiende por ser un port de play, se me hizo medio tedioso acostumbrarme al teclado).
- Mala optimización gráfica (Por ser un juego antigüo, no se le saca el máximo rendimiento, independientemente de la pc que tengas). A destacar la falta de opciones para subir y/o bajar gráficos.
- El sistema de dasheo es pésimo, el personaje se siente lento, como cargando una mochila, no hay un "fast run". Personalmente, iba dasheando todo el tiempo, lo cual es tedioso.
- El uso de la montura "Ruina" no esta bien pulido, tiene muchos bugs, se baja solo del caballo, e incluso hace sonidos de aparecer y no aparece.
- No hay un boton para save game, extraño un f5 como en los juegos de rol, pero creo que esta bien por ser un Hack n slash.

Prefieres hacer la guerra solo? No, sólo no.
*Caen 3 meteoritos del cielo*

It has fun graphics and uncomplicated. 

However, the linear nature of the game means that you can't progress if you get stuck at a particular point. I often had to consult the walkthrough to figure out the puzzle maze. There is no alternative solution to killing a particular boss other than the one recommended, which means madness (doing the same thing over, and over, again and expecting a different result).

121872882.review:
I think someone once called it a Zelda-killer. The only thing it killed with any proficiency was braincells.

Coming from the same crop of ideals that spawned hypermasc power fantasies that would later become sad thirty year old boomer dad memes, Darksiders' comic book roots don't save it from becoming a muddled hodge-podge of everything cool and good in gaming that ends up falling short of cool and good. It's like store-bought chocolate cake from the local supermarket chain. Sure, it's got all the ingredients, and it looks and tastes like it's supposed to, but are you really going to remember and cherish its memory?

The first comparison most people will make is the WoW-inspired art style. And while that might be true, they overlook how American comic books have largely informed WoW and everything that came after. There are hints of Frank Miller, Todd McFarlane, and Chris Liefeld in there. And while you'd hope this would result in a hard, pounding opera of gore and emotion, what came out the other end was a rote and dreary beat-em-up starring roided-out kewpie dolls bouncing around contract concept art. To be fair, this first foray into the world of Darksiders was likely an exploratory step, but first impressions count, and aspirations at weaving a grander cosmology without directly stepping on Christian toes is merely that - aspirations.

Meanwhile, the puzzles, combat, and exploration make you experience a hellish grind for no real reason, just because it's what a video game like this is supposed to do. You'd think exploring a ruined Earth would be more compelling, but little more than palette swaps and a new mechanic do anything to make you care about the world and how it works - if it works. It's all so much barely functional window dressing for the next fight sequence.

121181254.review:
Darksiders is one of those well-functioning games where there is nothing wrong in particular but it just leaves me with an empty feeling.
Despite playing as war one of the four horsemen of the apocalypse in an epic battle that makes you fight both the forces of God and the Devil. I found myself completely lost in the story despite not skipping cutscenes.

Does this sound familiar to you.
You run around in a doomed world collecting souls as a form of currency and fight the undead, monsters, devils, angels and bosses of all kinds using mostly melee weapons.

The game is in the easy section but when you die in-game it is almost too abrupt.

The game feels like it wants to be too many things that aren't necessarily related. An RPG, a hack and slash game, superficially dark souls, a puzzle platformer, and all coated in the palette which I could best describe as World of Warcraft.

The combat works but I really miss the enemy health bars, it just feels weird not having them.
Credit where credit is due if you buy the original or vice versa you will get both the original and the remastered version.
Overall a very mediocre game that just feels bland more than anything 5/10.

[h1] NO SOY "GOD OF WAR" [/h1]

Puede llegar a ser una comparacion por ser el pilar del genero de accion/aventura, pero combina mas mecanicas como si fuera una fusion del ya mencionado GoW y otros como Devil May Cry, The Legends of Zelda y Prince of Persia, con todo esto,  todo funciona genial, creando asi su propia imagen

+ Su historia puede no ser la mas original entre angeles y demonios, pero te logra atrapar la necesidad de saber sobre los jinetes y su deber. Esto te lleva a explorar una variedad de paisajes y escensarios muy diversos y bien armados, los cuales podras volver a visitar cuando quieras ya que el juego no es tan "lineal" como otros y permite la exploracion
+ El combate es genial, si bien los combos no son tan numerosos, mientras mas avanzas desbloqueas nuevo equipo que puede cambiar tu forma de combatir y asi combinarlo con los combos para complementarlos
+ El mismo equipamiento son siempre nuevas mecanicas que se explotan a lo largo de todo el juego, cada vez que consigas algo nuevo quiere decir que tendras que volver a explorar por donde ya pasaste para descubrir otros caminos, ni en el final del juego dejas de aprender cosas nuevas o combinaciones entre estos mismos y eso se agradece
+ Los diseños son hermosos, tanto de los personajes principales y bosses, hasta el esbirro mas inutil, todo tiene un cariño en su diseño y se los puede diferenciar facilmente a la hora de combatir con cada uno

- Quiza lo unico que note algo flojo son las habilidades o "poderes" lo veo como un extra ya que no las utilize mas de 3 o 4 veces a lo largo de TODO el juego, por lo que podes pasar de ellas tranquilamente si te acostumbras al combate por combos
- No tiene opciones graficas, supongo que un detalle para aquellos que les cueste correrlo
- La pistola solo sirve una vez y luego solo es fachera

Overall a quality, fun game! Combat is simple but very satisfying. Puzzles are not frustratingly difficult and, again, are satisfying to solve. The theme and design are fun and cool, but the story itself isn't anything groundbreaking - it's pretty simple and not all that prevalent in the gameplay. None of the characters are very fleshed out, but the voice acting is excellent and includes talent like Mark Hamill, Troy Baker, and Phil LaMarr. Soundtrack and sound design are also very good. The graphics are dated obviously, but the game doesn't really suffer for it as the style and atmosphere are still very much engaging and nice to look at. As others have said, the gameplay is quite similar in a lot of ways to the Legend of Zelda games, with the art style of Warcraft and a (secular) theological, apocalyptic flavor. 

My biggest complaint is what feels like a big imbalance in difficulty in a few places. There are a couple of enemies that are WAY harder (and take longer) to beat than any of the game's bosses, including the final one! It took me 10+ tries to beat a team of two Iron Giants, but only 2-3 to beat the final boss of the game... Even once you figure out how to beat those enemies, they have so much health that it just takes forever to kill them and it gets a bit tedious. Controls can also be a bit frustrating at times, but I think that's mostly a result of this being a port to PC, and you do get used to it for the most part.

All in all, a fun classic-style game that has a good rhythm to it and fun, good-looking environments and enemies. Highly recommend.

96047267.review: I begrudgingly have to admit that it’s an overall alright game. I feel like it comes up a bit short in places, combat feels particularly shallow, and the world feels a bit too big in comparison to how much there is to do/find/collect, but as far as Zelda-likes are concerned, it’s ok. I felt personally disappointed by it’s failing to ‘go above and beyond’ in any aspect. Despite it having enough of an aesthetical identity, it still has this distinct sense of ‘generic late 2000’s game’ in that it throws random ‘side segments’ that differ from regular gameplay in for seemingly no reason than to stretch the game out. They’re never particularly engaging and generally feel like the game would’ve been better if they’d been excluded. There’s also the matter of how needlessly edgy it feels that gives it a sense of being aged. If you are going to play it, I recommend the Warmastered edition rather than the original I played, simply a better version of the same game. Though if you are planning on playing the whole series, or are just out of better Zelda-likes to play, my main complaint would be the previously mentioned shallow combat. The most baffling aspect of Darksiders to me is how they clearly took some inspiration from God of War’s bloody fast paced combo driven hack and slash gameplay… and yet weapons don’t really combo into each other well at all in my experience, leaving you with 2-4 hit chains of attacks with a single weapon being the only reliable way to attack. It seems like some of the groundwork is there, it seems like it’s what they wanted, but just couldn’t deliver on, so you’ll pretty much just end up doing the same small string of attacks over and over throughout the whole game. Still though my personal experience with it was a bit disappointing, it’s an enjoyable enough experience to recommend.

95231233.review:
[h1]"In times of war, the law falls silent."
[i]~Marcus Tullius Cicero[/i][/h1]

The seventh generation of video game consoles. In my humble opinion, it was the last generation, in which console war was still a thing. I mean, seriously. Look at the world we live in now. We have [b]Kingdom Hearts[/b] and [b]Final Fantasy[/b] on [b]Xbox[/b], [b]Crash Bandicoot[/b] and [b]Forza[/b] on [b]PC[/b] and so on. Sure, technically, the console war is still on and some titles are still available only on certain platforms, but all in all, seventh generation was the last one when it was still interesting. The last one when it was actually worth having more than one system on you. And this game? It's taking advantage of that.

See, even up to this day we never had [b]The Legend of Zelda[/b] game outside [b]Nintendo[/b]'s system. We also never had [b]God of War[/b] game outside [b]PlayStation[/b] family. [b]Vigil Games[/b] decided to change that. Not by porting those games, of course (we all know what [b]Nintendo[/b] does with those who mess with their property, the guys are worse than any inquisition), but by making their own high quality alternative. That's pretty much all you need to know about the [b]Darksiders[/b]. It's stylish and charming mix between [b]The Legend of Zelda[/b] and [b]God of War[/b].

[b]Vigil Games[/b] didn't stop there, though. They literally took everything that was cool about popular titles like [b]Devil May Cry[/b], [b]Gungrave[/b], [b]Ubisoft[/b]'s [b]Prince of Persia[/b], [b]Legacy of Kain[/b], [b]Portal[/b] and even [b]WarCraft[/b] (design in this game was copied from what we had in [b]WarCraft III[/b] / [b]World of WarCraft[/b] almost as is), mixed all that together and called it a day. Sure, it doesn't sound that good. I mean... we all hate plagiarism, right? But you know what? It actually [i]is[/i] a good thing. Thanks to [b]Darksiders[/b], a lot of people who never played such games before finally got a chance to do so, while the others? The others just got even more of a good thing.

Like I said, [b]Darksiders[/b] is a high quality product. It looks good and it feels good. Almost as good as the original titles. And all of those different elements from different games? They work surprisingly well together. While playing as a brutal guy who looks almost exactly like [b]Arthas Menethil[/b], we'll explore a [b]Zelda[/b]-like world with dungeons, use a gun like [b]Dante[/b] and [b]Beyond the Grave[/b], do some basic tricks like in those early [b]Prince of Persia[/b] titles from [b]Ubisoft[/b], we'll fight some huge enemies and do [b]QTE[/b] like in [b]God of War[/b], solve the puzzles similar to what we had in [b]Zelda[/b], [b]Legacy of Kain[/b] and [b]Portal[/b], and so on. It really does work perfectly well. The addiction, the satisfaction... it's all here.

Add the fact that this game also comes with surprisingly great cast (not only we've got [b]Troy Baker[/b], we've also got [b]Mark Hamill[/b] himself, so, it's, like, one heck of a [b]Joker[/b] paradise here) and you'll see that... well... this game is good. Simple like that. You want a good game? Here it is. It's really hard to find something really bad to say about the [b]Darksiders[/b]. No matter how you look at it, it's a good game and that's it. Even the fact that [b]Vigil Games[/b] kind of overdid it with puzzles at one point can't change that (even though they sure did and this game comes with even more annoying dungeon than that [b]Water Temple[/b] thingy from [b]Ocarina of Time[/b], keep that in mind if you don't have enough patience).

There's one thing, though, that gives [b]Darksiders[/b] a certain... unpleasant aftertaste. I'm talking, of course, about the fact that this game doesn't have a face. Like [b]John Travolta[/b] in that certain [b]John Woo[/b] movie. Sure, it looks very impressive and stylish, but at the same time, when you look at this game? You don't see [b]Darksiders[/b]. You see the original games. When you watch cutscenes? It's a bloody [b]WarCraft[/b]. When you shoot? You see [b]Dante[/b]. When you pick up bombs from the ground? You see [b]Link[/b] who's getting ready to face [b]King Dodongo[/b]. And so on. The biggest problem with this game is that it can't really offer you anything unique, while everything that [b]Vigil Games[/b] borrowed from the other titles is so obvious that it's literally impossible not to think about that. It's just a bunch of some really cool stuff from the other, more famous titles and that's it. Does it ruin the game? Of course, not. And yet, like I said, it adds a certain unpleasant aftertaste. Like... you know. When you're playing one of those so-called “clones”, no matter how good it is, it's still just a clone, right?

There was a good chance to fix all that through story, bu-u-ut... let's just say that story is not the strongest point here. All in all, it's fine, but it relies too much on setting. You know, angels, demons, post-apocalyptic future... In other words, it's [b]Requiem: Avenging Angel[/b]. Which is pretty cool and stylish, but... let's just say that the actual storytelling is not really that good. [b]Vigil Games[/b] tried to follow the [b]God of War[/b] formula, in which our character just keeps beating the heck out of one character after another, but... let's just say that without [b]Kratos[/b] and his charisma you can't help but want more twists. I'm not trying to say that [b]War[/b] (yes, we're playing as one of the Horsemen of the Apocalypse here, because... you know... [b]War[/b]... [b]God of War[/b]... good grief...) isn't a charming character. It's just... it doesn't make as much impact as [b]Kratos[/b]. At least, not enough to cover for the lack of plot twists. In other words, the story just can't cover the fact that this game is just a clone. Unfortunately.

Then again, for those of us who don't have any consoles on them, this game is a great choice. And even for those who already played all of the games I've mentioned above, I can still recommend this one. Because, let's just admit it, having a good clone from time to time? It's a good thing. Like, OK, [b]Age of Empires[/b] is a good game. But it doesn't mean that we can't enjoy clones like [b]Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds[/b], [b]War Diary II[/b] and even [b]BC Kings[/b] because why the heck not? And [b]Darksiders[/b]? It's sure a good clone. Seriously, guys, you haven't played it yet? Go buy it.

[b]P.S.[/b] Nowadays, though, it may actually be a good idea to go for so-called [b]Warmastered Edition[/b] instead. The new version comes with the [b]4K[/b] resolution support (in the original version you can't go higher than [b]2K[/b]), high resolution textures, improved shadows and post-processing effects, re-rendered cutscenes and, the best of all, the pre-order weapon (the [b]Harvester[/b] scythe) as a free bonus. Well, it won't be [i]free[/i], since you'll need to buy it with the in-game currency, but you know what I mean. In [b]Warmastered Edition[/b] you won't need any pre-order codes to get [b]Harvester[/b]. In other words, it's, like, the same exact thing, only better and with pre-order bonus as a gift. Which makes purchasing the original version kinda useless. As long as you're not a die-hard geek who wants to have every single version of this game. Dixi.

94819367.review:
Darksiders is a hack-n-slash game, whose completion relies on platforming, the completion of puzzles and combat. You play as War, the first of the horsemen of the apocalypse, who comes after the legions of hell have been unleashed upon Earth and the forces of heaven have gone to intercept them, starting the biblical apocalypse. However - unlike what has been foretold, you are the only Horseman to answer the call and thus strive to find out what is going on.
Combat will be an integral part of your gameplay and the combat here is a generally fluid, relying on timely dodging, parrying and counter-attacks. When I say "generally fluid" I mean, that the game sometimes fails to register your input or registers it wrongly (I played with a controller on PC, using the Steam controller emulation). You will have three main weapons to choose from - the Chaoseater sword (with a wide variety of potential attacks and a higher rate of generating wrath/chaos, more on those later), a Scythe (which generates more souls per kill) or the Tremor Gauntlet (which knocks down enemies with every completed attack sequence and is used in puzzles to break walls of ice). Along with these weapons there will be six items, which are mainly used to solve puzzles, but some of which can also enhance your combat. Ill let you find those yourself. I also feel that the opponents are more poorly balanced here than in the Warmastered edition, meaning you will have a worse time of it than in that game.
War has all of his powers stripped at the end of the Prologue, which means you will have to power him back up. Despite of this - there are no levels to speak of. You gain souls from killing enemies and use these to buy upgrades from a merchant. These are mostly skill upgrades (you buy new moves for each weapon and upgrade them), but there are also the classical health restoration items, upgrades, a few weapons (the Scythe for example) and skills. The skills are launched when War has enough Wrath, which is kind of a mana/stamina reservoir. The devs have kept the Wrath pool relatively low, meaning that while you can have powerful spells, you shouldn't reach a point where you can just comfortably walk through areas and steamroll everything with spells alone. Lastly there is Chaos, which is an attribute that launches War's Chaos form - this looks pretty much exactly as a Balrog from The Lord of the Rings and is invulnerable, but only lasts a limited amount of time.
The setting means, that you shouldn't expect much cheer here - Humanity has been annihilated and its cities lie in ruin. Despite this the graphics and color schemes are a lot more bright than in Soulsborne products - despite the setting I found there to be very little actual gloom and/or negativity. You basically have little to no time to build any sort of a relationship to anything you meet and thus won't much care what lives or dies. So if you're looking for something straight-forward and simple to turn your mind off to - Darksiders is a very good choice.
Despite how straight-forward the story is however, it doesn't mean its shallow or that it has no surprises along the way - the villain of this installment is not obvious [spoiler] (they also officially die very early on) [/spoiler] and ..... getting more into this would be a major spoiler, so lets just leave it at that everyone you meet has their agenda and very few things are as simple as they first seem.
However it must be said, that the Warmastered Edition is VASTLY superior to this game and to be perfectly honest with you - this review is positive only because this version comes with that version by default. Thus my advice to you - only ever play this game after you have played the remaster and want to compare what they have done better there or want to go achievement hunting in a game you "already know" (from the remaster). And speaking of achievements - those are bugged, so if you have to restart the game at any point, anything that should count towards your achievements will not. The solution is to restart steam and then launch the game again. 
If you find this game stand-alone, do not waste your money on it and go for the remaster instead.

88105898.review:
Darksiders looks great on PC, thanks to the greater resolution and the lack of tearing. The game itself comes with excellent graphics and nice artistic direction, but its strength lies in its gameplay: War faces hundreds of different enemies, using many different weapons, and there are plenty of puzzles to be solved in each level. 86871193.review:
I had high expectations for this game, unfortunately it ended up feeling like one of the worst games I ever bought.
I finished this game for about 65% as of writing this, and I'm thinking of just dropping it considering I don't have any fun playing it. 

Things I disliked the most about this game:
- The controls:
Playing this game with a keyboard and mouse is a pain in the ass. I'm sure that playing this game on console would be 10x more enjoyable solely for this reason. Movements feel very 'static' and linear, something you see often in 2010 games. A game having lackluster controls doesn't instantly make it a bad game, however the issue here is that the game is heavily revolved around solving terrain puzzles where you often find yourself needing to go through small holes or having to time your jumps perfectly to reach a certain part of the map. Hence you'll find yourself wanting to ragequit because of this matter quite alot.

- Map design:
The developers tried to stick with the 'dark theme' by using similar gloomy color palettes throughout the game which gives the maps a dull and somewhat repetitive vibe.
Furthermore, I found alot of the terrain puzzles being unclear and I caught myself watching walkthroughs on youtube more than once on parts where I was stuck.

- Killing enemies
Killing enemies in this game gets very repetitive; there's no actual fun in killing them, you just do it for the sake of getting them out of your way so you can continue trying to solve your dumb stage puzzles for the 100th time.

To anyone looking to pick this game up (even if its on sale); I suggest watching a couple of gameplay videos first to see if it would be worth your money. I personally think there are better games out there to buy, even for this price.

86647457.review: Darksiders is one of the first games, which combines two different types of games. That types are slasher and RPG, in some moments this combination is made well, but also there are some things that I find irritating. But about the story now, in this game we play as one of the horsemen of the apocalypse, he is called War. At the start of the game, we are killed by the demon, but after that, we come back to life after the year out of knowing what was happened in the world. We have been returned to life by Council, they said us what was happened, with that knowledge to get our honor back, we have to restore the balance of the world. To be sure that we will do it, Council gives the power above us to observe. In the whole of the game, developers give us some perfect plot twists, the last of them made truly smile on my face, it's because we get cut scene that shows what will happen at the end, after that, I felt so disappointed, but that plot twist made it the best end of the game, which could ever imagine. Also in-game was the moment that made me laugh, it's the moment in dialogue after we killed the second boss. Now some words about type game combination, that developers use to make Darksiders. About the good sides of that type of game combination, in the whole of the game we're able to fight with one main weapon, two secondary weapons, and six additional gear and equipment. The more we use a main or secondary weapon to fight, the much they are getting more powerful, every they can have a maximum fourth level of power. Even, if we upgrade all weapons to level four, we can make them stronger, to do it we're using special runes, all of them gives different passive, or active bonuses to fight. About the bad aspects of that idea, things we get from chests. In-game we have three types of souls, these are: blue, it's our currency, we can buy everything with using it, all additional moves upgrades, special attacks, and many types of crystals (remember that last thing), green gives us health, and orange gives us fury. So why things in chests are bad in my opinion? The answer is: In the game are many of chest, at some moments are four chests next to each other, and all of them almost always have only souls and that's why many times we take only two of them, rest of them most will not be open forever. In-game as I said before we have many types of crystals in it are health crystals, but we're able to find only about four of them in chests, okay but we can buy them, yes, but there is the main problem they are expensive. First, you can end the game with all achievement after one passing the game, to do it you have to choose the apocalyptic difficulty of the game, it will give you some problems at the beginning, but while you're further, the game start being easier (calmly you can die as much as you need to pass the game). Second, to get an achievement called Aerial Predator, to get it you have to kill one hundred and sixty, while you fly on the flying beast. It's not hard, but there is some problem with it. 86171588.review:
Back on its release, Darksiders 1 was described by many as “Legend of Zelda meets God of War.” They weren’t wrong, and the Darksiders series continues to be a blend of other genres with metroidvanias. 

The Darksiders games follow the story of the four horsemen of the apocalypse: War, Death, Fury, and Strife. The artistic design is the brainchild of Joe Madureira, comic book artist of Uncanny X-men and Battlechasers. This distinct art-style is the icing on the cake for the hack-and-slash gameplay. 

Darksiders 1 is the most Zelda-like of all four titles. There are classic dungeons, classic unlockable items that allow for additional exploration, and tons of areas you can backtrack to in order to unlock health and mana upgrades. Customization is minimal. You always use War’s sword Chaoseater, but have the option of using a Scythe or Gauntlets as your secondary weapon. You also have a few activated abilities you can take advantage of. You do have the ability to change what “enhancement” is attached to each weapon, but the impact they have is pretty minimal. Combat gets repetitive, but it’s balanced nicely with exploration, puzzles, and scripted action sequences.

Some elements of progression are annoying, like leveling-up your weapons. As you kill enemies, your weapons gain miniscule amounts of experience and become more powerful. The main issue is that only the weapon that deals the killing blow gets any experience. 

In the remaster, the controls have been mostly untouched. This is simultaneously a good thing (the combat controls in the original were tight) and a bad thing (the aiming in the original was way way too sensitive). Fortunately, it hooks right into Steam’s controller API that allows you complete control over inputs and layouts. I had a few crashes while playing the remaster, but mostly my experiences were positive. Graphics look great.

83458032.review:
Darksiders Review

Strap in, you are in for the ride of your life as War sets out…

Some key points that this game offers:

1.	Brilliant Story Line
2.	Impressive Visuals and lighting effects
3.	Character Progression
4.	Epic Boss Fights

Gameplay & Controls:

The game handles like a dream Whether you are playing on console or PC. I have played Darskiders on both Xbox 360 and PC and I can truly say that the experience on both were absolutely amazing. Controller configuration is superb and the game handles and plays like a dream. Your trusty keyboard and mouse will not fail you either. The game plays just as smooth and fluid on the PC. You can customize and rebind your keys if you need to. The game also offers some controller support, it depends on the controller type you use.

Answering the call, you fulfil your duty, and ride brining about the apocalypse… 
You are War, one of the Horsemen of the Apocalypse, who has set out on a journey to clear his name and find the ones responsible for brining doom to the third kingdom.

The game is a Semi-Open world experience. To unlock new areas, you will have to progress the main story line to unlock newer areas. You can revisit previously cleared areas as well. This is mainly to find items or secrets you missed the first time around, or were unable to obtain or open before.

As War progresses through the game you will increase in power by increasing your life and wrath bars. Your weapons also gain experience as you defeat enemies with them unlocking new abilities and moves. The combat for the game is pretty decent and fun. It is pretty much your average Hack and Slash with some Epic combos and finishers. Plus, you are literally one of the Horseman of the Apocalypse, making it ten times more fun and awesome. 

War has a pretty deadly arsenal at his disposal once he starts collecting them. With each new area you unlock you are also met with new mechanics and requirements and you make use of your newly acquired weapons and abilities to beat or meet these requirements. There are some fun puzzle mechanics and platforming to do, but nothing that is overly difficult or complicated. It is one fun filled experience to seek out and explore every nook and cranny of this apocalyptic world.

Graphics:

More than just impressive! The colours and themes were brilliantly designed to offer us a visual marvel that doesn’t just look pretty but offers beauty in everything it does. No matter where you are there are tons of beaty to be seen. Early mornings or dark nights. There is beauty in everything.

The game blends are shadows and lighting very well to further enhance the visuals of the game; it is the little things after all! The entire game is one massive world that is so vibrant and filled so bright and unique colours and themes, you can’t help but be amazed by the living art style that the game has to offer.

Character models were also created quite decently, with unique appearances and behaviours for every enemy type. NB NPC’s received a whole lot more attention and it is clearly visible through their marvelous characteristics and detailed appearances.

Sounds:

Superb, absolutely amazing! The Soundtrack makes this game so much more enticing! It not only entertains you, but it captivates you! The Soundtrack was chosen well for the game.

The background sounds bring the game world to life and enhances the overall experience immensely. Voice over artists did a fantastic job with their characters and lines, ensuring they bring their characters to life. 

Replayability:

Darsksiders may not have multiplayer or co op mode but it has quite the replay value nonetheless. You can always replay the game on a higher difficulty once you had your fun with story mode. 

Completing your playthrough though will keep you busy seeing as there are numerous collectables and secrets to find hidden throughout the world as well.

MGR Gaming’s Conclusions:
Spoilers Ahead:

Through and through a masterful game! They did an absolutely fantastic job bringing the Horseman of the Apocalypse to life with this game. The lore, the story line and the execution are pretty much perfect. I want more, I simply couldn’t get enough of Darksiders. 

The Boss fights were an absolute blast, the world is gorgeous and so welcoming and then there is War! Loyal and honourable to a fault! The journey you two undertake to prove his innocence is so memorable and captivating it just leaves you wanting more! The deeper mystery and conspiracy that takes place makes the entire experience that much more enticing, 

Level design and layout is pretty decent and fun to explore. It is never that difficult or complicated, it offers the right amount of challenge and excitement. The hidden secrets and chests aren’t that hard to find or open once you retrieve the proper tools either. World navigation is simple and quite an enjoyable experience. They pretty much executed this game and its mechanics really well to ensure there is an abundance of fun to be had. As a new game and new franchise, I can’t criticize it for what it doesn’t have yet. However, I would like to see more side quests, and a bigger more open world to explore… But what we have is totally amazing so far!

This game and franchise have so much potential and there is so much room for it to grow and expand. I can’t wait to see where they are going to go with this game… 

The Official trailer for Darksiders.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1fx-IWy9hkQ

Score 9

82559073.review:
Obnoxiously good game and series. I've been playing through all existing Darksiders games including Warmastered and Deathinitive remakes several times and i just love them!! (which is up to genesis atm of this review)

The Hack and Slash Action Adventure type has always been my personal favorite type of game and the very most important aspects for me personally to really dive in and enjoy the game is first the character design and cutscenes, second the story, third flashy fighting with good mechanics. Ooooooh boy does Darksiders (ALL games) hit the nail on all of those.
+ One of the, if not the single best character design I've ever seen and throughout ALL games of the series. I just so love the attitude and personality of every single one of the horsemen. But the one character I absolutely love the most is Samael. He's like the goddamn big babbo ultra doomlord of badassness.
+ I also really like the Darksiders story and I think most people who do have a thing for the whole apocalypse, end war, demons and angles beating the sh*t out of each other type of story will like it it as well. Though I do admit that it is maybe a bit thin throughout some of the games.
+ The fighting mechanics themselves throughout all games are awesome I think. Though there different approaches for leveling weapons/gear, upgrading or crafting throughout the series and not everyone might enjoy all of them and I personally do also not like every aspect of it, but for the fighting itself I personally love it. It's flashy while easy to control and there are a lot of boss fights with cool strategies involved. Though please keep in mind that by the time I am writing this review Darksiders 1 is already out for over 10 years, so if you're getting started with the series just now you should not compare it to the fighting mechanics to say for example Devil May Cry 5. But I personally think it is even now still far from being too boring to play the game or unfun or anything. Of course, if the game just released in 2020 you might have expected a bit more depth to the fighting though but for a game that released over 10 years ago this is really good sh*t.

Though I do also have some minor points of critique for all the games of the series, they are in fact minor in my opinion and I would MOST DEFINITELY recommend all games of the series. For Darksiders 1 specifically there is only maybe one really, really minor critique I may have which is a bug that has that seems easy enough but never has been fixed. There is an item which lets you locate artifacts, chests, etc on the map and there is one chest (in Drowned Pass I think) within the game displayed on the map by that item which simply doesn't exist. Many players (including myself) tried to find it for quite a while before it has been confirmed to be a bug, but as I said it was never fixed though it seems to me to be really easy to fix.

--> buy it, play it, love it

74078649.review:
What can I say about this game except that it is awesome!

I still remember the time I bought it, back in the xbox 360, one of the first games I got. I played the hell out of this game, beat it every single week, idk why, but it was so fun and simple, no complex combo system, just a simple hack and slash combo system.
The story is so intriguing and interesting. I really don't know what to say, but I really love this game.
Playing and discovering stuff, backtracking and such.
Be sure to choose the hardest difficult, you take a lot of damage, but it's still fun :3
It felt like a good ps2 game (not diminishing it, just saying how good it was). So the best part was playing and having fun with it.

Pros:
- Ruin
- An interesting story where you're between hell and heaven
- Post apocalyptic world
- Childhood friend
- Thr environment, solving puzzles and discovering stuff, seeing how the world ended
- Its fun
- One of the few games that made me love it and play it without getting bored, so it's a very good game, it's simple yet it fun and entertaining, especially an adventure/hack slash game that has nothing to do after beating it.

Cons:
- It has a very simple battle system, you press attack a few times, hold the attack button to launch the enemy in the air, press the attack button a few times in the air and hold it again. That's literally all the combo you can do in the game. It's very simple and the game doesn't ask for you to do too much, but still, they should've added some more.
- The gear, only two are good, the pistol and the chakran, tho the last one is op and make the gun obsolete, the gauntlet and scythe are practically useless, as far as combo goes.
- Near the end you lose the option to use the sword upgrades, forcing you to use that op sword.
- The story, it's very interesting, however it isn't shown in a good way, some characters are shown and talked about, but little are told about them.
- The game is very easy even choosing the hardest difficult.
- There were 2 poop sequels, one that turned the game into a rpg and the other that made it soulslike, and there's also a remaster.

[h1] Achievements [/h1]
There is a problem with the achievements that you need to restart steam and make Darksiders the first game you play Every Time, otherwise the achievements will not pop up.
This is kinda annoying, every time you are going to play you need to restart steam first.
If you close the game and want to play the game right after, you need to restart steam to make the achievements count.
[h1] Story [/h1] 
The story is perfect, The 4 Horseman of the Apocalypse, The End of the World, Hell and Heaven, its similar to the history at the Christian Bible but with some differences that don't even mention the Holy Bible itself, you don't need to be religious or anything, the game isn't religious or going to make you religious but the concept of the game was taken from the words of the Holy Text.
[h1] Bugs [/h1]
I have seen only the one from the Achievements.
[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
i have played the game on apocalyptic and was quite easy, also unlocked the achievements for completing the game on normal and easy at the same time.
The game makes you go to the prior maps you have done to collect all the lifestones (increase life) and wrath cores (increase wrath) and abyssal armor shards (ultimate armor) when you acquire the new weapons later in game, and its hard to remember the location of all the chests you have encountered and couldn't be opened at the time.
The combat is good, its not so much fun but its good, its not bad and there is a lot of puzzles too. The game is well balanced between puzzles, combat and history, there is a new puzzle every time.
[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
-Perfect History
-Combat is Ok
-Puzzles are Ok
-Not Even Close to Repetitive in any aspects
-Collectibles and Achievements Hard To Get

71486417.review:
I stopped playing singleplayers a long time back in 2016 after I moved on to multiplayers (by this I mean CSGO mostly). But after the country wide lockdown was announced on 24th March 2020 (and extended for several months) we all became literally stuck in our houses with nothing to do mostly. So, I decided to play a couple of singleplayer games and since I have a dual core CPU, I only had a few options mainly so I zeroed in on Darksiders. I started playing on 3rd June 2020 and finished it on 26th June 2020. This is a typical hack and slash game like DMC (that I have played and finished before) though not that colorful and entertaining. The game is heavily inspired from the Prince of Persia (PoP) series in terms of puzzles (door opening, adjusting mirrors for reflection, weighing puzzle etc.) with a look and feel like Gears of War (PC version of 2007). The only difference with PoP here is you can’t walk on walls and you can’t take time backwards. Here you control one of the three horsemen called War who wields a sword (called the Chaoseater) as a primary weapon and there are a handful number of secondary weapons (like a scythe, a chakra (Crossblade), tremor gauntlet used for tremor punches and also a gun quite similar to DMC though the gun is not that powerful). War can also call on spikes from the ground whenever needed in a fight. You also get a grappling chain and a horse (called Ruin) in later parts in the game. The horse can be called upon in certain places but not everywhere throughout the game. The Voidwalker is used to open portals at certain points from where you can hop into some other points. A few weapons (type of laser guns) can also be picked up at some points from the enemies and can also be used against them. There are a wide range of enemies with different attacking styles some easy and some pretty much hard to defeat. Even the fishes underwater are hostile towards you – they give electric shocks when you come in contact with them. Personally, I had a hard time defeating the teleporting double sword wielding flying blue witches that came in the middle of the game. The game is too long than normal standards and might seem a bit repetitive in the second half when you need to backtrack to the same locations again and again. But the boss fights were like a breath of fresh air as fighting them were challenging as well as pretty entertaining. Before the final boss battle (Abaddon) you get a Mask of Shadows that enables you to see shadowy objects that are usually hidden in an environment. The first thing that you do after getting it is fight your own shadowy self – that was really good. The final battle requires you to find seven pieces of the Armageddon Blade scattered in seven different locations in the map. There are ten total locations in the map and you need to meet Vulgrim (a merchant) in all those locations otherwise you won’t be able to fast travel (called the Serpent Hole) to all the seven locations from where you need to find the pieces. I missed Vulgrim in one of those ten locations (The Dry Roads) and I had to backtrack there manually to find the final piece of the Blade as fast travel was not available for that location. In the end after killing the Dragon form (The Destroyer) of Abaddon I thought the game ended but then he took the human form and I had to kill him again that pretty much surprised me. The game is no doubt well made and good except for the frustrating backtracking every now and then. I rate it 7 out of 10. But my advice is to play the game with joystick controllers otherwise it will difficult for you to make most of the combos.  
P.S. My achievements on Steam were not unlocking properly. For example, I defeated the boss Tiamat but that achievement is still locked. This is because this game has an issue with Steam. In order to unlock achievements, you need to play Darksiders immediately after opening Steam but if you play some other games or do something else after opening Steam then the achievements won’t get unlocked properly.

70610821.review: If God of War and Legend of Zelda had a baby with some warped classic mythology about the Four Horseman this would be the game. Upgrading weapons, one button executions, exploration, dungeons and upgrade to your health and Wrath can be found in four-piece increments. All this wrapped up in a cohesive large map of varying areas, all torn and weathered from the apocalypse. Enemies are fair in intelligence to provide a challenge; apocalyptic difficulty will have you becoming friends with your dodge button. The story is decent with a few twists and turns backed by some well-done voice acting. While the concept is dark and gritty the cartoonish style of some of the characters and other elements left me a little disappointed. Prime opportunity for some more blood but there is some. Regardless, these are minor gripes and complaints. A major complaint would be the achievement issue. If you close the game and reopen it, any achievements gained will not proc. This means you need to close the game, then steam completely then start it again. The in-game barriers are also an issue, a majority of the time these look accessible but can get you stuck. I wiggled my way out of most but three times I needed to restart the game. 20.00$ not a bad deal since you also get the Warmastered Edition but let's be honest, just played the Warmastered version. At least they fixed the achievement issue in the remaster.

70482992.review:
Darksiders  is an incredible game. I was expecting a cheap God of War clone, but it's far better than that. For one thing the Horseman War is a far more interesting character than Kratos, whose one-note vengeance act is wearing pretty thin. Great atmosphere, fun combat, very creative puzzles, and some of the best creature design ever. It's a long game with tons of bosses, and they're all awesome looking. New elements are constantly introduced to keep it fresh: grappling hook, horseback combat, and even some portal dynamics near the end. The biggest criticism is that Darksiders doesn't do anything new, but combining all these great elements from other games so successfully is something new.

I highly recommend this game: Darksiders is a beautiful game that is going to keep you wholly entertained throughout it's 30-hours campaign.

This is a review from somebody who got 100% achievements in the game.

Look at the epic opening screen and the menu screen, you should know that this game is awesome. The combat is inspired and by God of War and so good. You can level up weapons, you have side weapons, chests skill upgrade. Combat is never dull. This game have a system similar to Devil May Cry where you have to kill enemies before progressing, and the story is very well written. The story is so interesting that gives game +++ to everything. Lastly, the price of the game Darksiders and Darksiders Warmastered Edition (same game 1 with normal graphics and Warmastered with updated graphics) is good

Now on the opposite side of things. The game is amazing but short. You can do the whole game in 14 hours may be - or + 2 hours for puzzles. Yes the whole game sadly is short. With 100% achievements you can finish the game in 16 to 40 hours (40 cuz some achievements are missable). The game has some puzzles (if you are not a puzzle person, likely we have YouTube) The game was released in 2010 and graphics(good) are not 2020. Now in Dakrsiders Original the graphics did not age well

At the end if you have time for an amazing story and awesome combat Darksiders will easily be a good purchase

P.S. for 100% the game is goodish. 2 achievements that take time. 1st Dark Rider where you have to ride a lot (just make your horse ride in circles and go do something else) and Battle Hardened where you have to farm ex for your weapons. + Save every new game area you enter as the game has a lot of missable but easy achievements

Bueno si, muchas horas, pero porque queda en pausa y me dedico a otras cosas.

Es más parecido a un Zelda que a otra cosa. El juego va de pasar un área llena de puzles, para abrir ciertas áreas, obtener items que te haran posible llegar a otras áreas.
Bastante largo, con mucho backtraking, demasiado para mi gusto. En fin la historia alucinante, buenas armas, llevadero, con ciertos momentos de refresco; como uno que montas un Griffing, y cosas que te sacan de la normalidad. 65444059.review:
[h1] RESEÑA DEL JUEGO 8.5/10 [/h1]
[b] La verdad es juego es muy bueno, combina buena banda sonora, buenos jefes, ambientación acorde a lo que pasa en el momento. [/b]
En general el juego me gusto mucho, me hizo recordar en su mayor parte a TLOZ.
Ya que habrá que:
-Recorrer Mazmorras
-Resolver Puzzles
-Obtener ciertos objetos que nos ayudaran en nuestro camino
Eso y muchas otras cosas más me hizo pensar que tenía como esa estetica de los juegos de Zelda.
Además de que al ser un juego basado en el apocalipsis se mencionan a varios personajes biblicos.
En este juego tomamos el control del [b]Jinete Del Apocalipsis: Guerra[/b] el cual al ir avanzando la historia nos damos cuenta que fue traicionado y obligado a cumplir con lo que le dice el "consejo".

[h1] PUNTOS MALOS DEL JUEGO [/h1]
[b] A lo largo del juego vi que tenia un par de cosas malas. [/b]

[i] 1.-Las Cinematicas [/i]
Cuando inicie el juego note que las cinematicas no iban acorde al sonido de estas, ya que, aparecian entre cortadas, se quedaban trabadas o simplemente transcurrian con lentitud.
Para poder "Solucionar" esto tuve que ver tutoriales y consejos que decían que había que instalar varios codecs de video, ya que el formato de estos estaba en .mwv y no se si exista ese problema en la versión Warmastered o si tenga que ver el sistema operativo (Lo Jugue Con Windows 10)

[i] 2.-Los Logros [/i]
Y no me refiero a que sean difíciles de conseguir, sino que, existe un problema en el cual notaras que solo te dará los primeros logros.
Y eso es porque al estar leyendo, parece que cada vez que cierras el juego pareciera que este pierde conexión con los servidores de Steam, por lo que si vuelves a iniciar el juego no te dará ningún logro que vayas a realizar.
Por fortuna esto se arregla saliendo se Steam y volviendo a iniciar. Esto se tiene que hacer cada vez que cierras el juego y quieres tener los logros.
Aunque es algo molesto estar cerrando e iniciar Steam cada vez que quiero iniciar el juego para que me puedan dar los logros.

[i] 3.-HORAS DE JUEGO [/i]
Si bien es cierto que me divertí cada segundo en este juego la verdad es que su duración es algo corta.
Para dar un ejemplo: Me pase el juego en 14 Horas en la máxima dificultad, eso incluyendo que estuve buscando la armadura abisal, y tratando de farmear un poco de almas (dinero del juego).
No quiero decir que esto en si sea un punto en desventaja, pero como mencione, el juego me lo pase relativamente rápido a pesar de estar en la dificultad máxima. 
Sobre la dificultad no puedo decir con certeza dado a que no lo jugue en sus dificultades mas bajas (Fácil, Normal) 
Lo que si note es que a veces el tiempo de reacción de los enemigos es algo lenta (No todos los enemigos)

En conclusión, es un buen juego, tiene un par de errores pero que no logran arruinar la experiencia del juego.
Recomiendo comprarlo en rebajas o de forma normal y si te es posible, juegues la versión "Warmastered"
Yo jugué esta versión dado a que pesaba menos y pues ya lo quería probar.

63569857.review:
Darksiders is a pretty alright game that I never in my life plan to play ever again.

TLDR: a good first episode that has pacing issues. There is room for improvement for many things, but none of them really fall in the bad category to begin with.

First reason for it: it's so incredibly angsty-edgy that it's mindblowing, I'm too old for this. The dialogues are all made in this style, and it's just so far from me it was hard to bear.  The art direction is coherent and unique, the actually story underlying is pretty good but spread thinly, you're just doing the next thing because you were told to do 4 things.  Last 2-3 hours got a lot better as the storytelling department realised they can tell a story and that would give more personality for characters, paint the bigger picture, start storytelling and such :)

Second reason: It's puzzles and progression are... trivial? Basic? Absolutely not stupid because it has some really fun times, but most of the time the various equipment you have just excuses for speedbumps. The gauntlet that can break ice is essential to progress the story at a point, but later just completely random iceblockades take the path you need to take. They are just there to slow you down, but give no "sense of accomplishment" that you could pass through them.  Most of the puzzles are so little and self-contained, that it takes seconds to figure out what you need to do then minutes to pull it off simply because of movement speed, running around, draggings stuff. [spoiler] The portal gun allows for some really-really good puzzles though. [/spoiler] I would have loved more of the same caliber puzzles.

Combat in general is pretty solid. Killed about 2k enemies in a playthrough, and while they are unique, they are not *too* unique. Many has same or sameish combos, but what really matters: they can be learnt. You have a very-very generous block/parry, a good dash, and by paying attention to the fight you can combo/control a lot of enemies while dancing around attacks. It's not hard on normal, and I risk to say it's likely newbie-friendly on easy. Just don't buttonsmash. Bosses are gimmicky but good, except the worm one, that was just super boring.

Also, abyssal chain? More like abysmal chain. It's great fun that you fire it two times to the same spot, and the first one just goes through the hook. Or when the hook's hitbox is two reticle's worth to the right from the texture..

57410220.review:
I'm currently in the last bit of the game, having beaten 4 bosses and in the final tower area I have come to the conclusion that this is either a really bad port from console, or the creators didn't/don't use computers very often.

The graphics for its age are wonderful, the voice acting is pretty good, and the story is not bad. It fits the same story genre as Devil May Cry.

However, the controls for this game are just utterly horrendous. The tutorial, or lack thereof, doesn't explain any of the controls or how they work. Sure I don't like everything handed to me, but having never played a game like this on PC I spent the first hour trying to deduce them before I gave up and had to look at the key bindings. 

Other than many of the key bindings being a series of keys that I've never had to use for a game before, some of them are just atrocious. Who the fuck puts more importance in terms of key binding into the mouse wheel than the your right click? Sure lets just make the thing that scrolls (because it's a fucking wheel) serve two completely different functions depending on if you press it down, or scroll, even if accidentally.

So I did the only logical thing and switched the key bindings to the less retarded option to actually make them combat viable. Sure it became a pain in the ass to use the scythe or the gauntlet, but only the gauntlet is important, infrequently so as I only used it to break ice. However, this led to another problem. Switching these key bindings makes throwing environmental items impossible as no matter how much focus after pressing Q to aim at something, your character will forever throw in a straight line directly in front of himself. Wishful thinking on that keybind I suppose.

The above reason alone is enough to stop me from ever replaying the game as it just isn't streamlined for PC playing. The terrible camera controls, sometimes buggy movement whilst parkouring, the utter uselessness of blocking/parrying compared to dodging, and the infrequent, but extremely annoying, times where you missclick and end up having to restart the game because you ended up in a spot you can't get out of are all just icing on the cake to me.

55681437.review:
The story revolves around the horseman War who was being reserved until the end of the world to be unleashed against everyone in order to bring balance in a war between Angels, Humans and Demons... Graphics still hold up well even for the original, but overall the game hasn't aged well...

Pros:
*Graphics are easy on the eyes and have a comic vibe to them
*Some combos are satisfying
*Characters are pretty cool
*Story is interesting and original

Cons:

*War is slow as hell and this becomes a huge con in the game because I spent more time walking around than anything else, you get wings early on which at first got me excited until I figured out that you can only glide with them for a couple feet and then they disappear, and you also get your horse (Ruin) but only after you complete about 80% of the game and you can only ride him on dirt terrain which only added to my frustration because most of the game takes place in concrete and stone levels...

*Movement is clunky, and for someone who can wield a sword the size of a car like a feather, you would at least expect him to jump a few feet higher, but no, War skips leg day...

*Puzzles suck, I'm not a big puzzle fan to begin with, but I can appreciate a good puzzle when it is good, and let me tell you, the ones in this game are not, they are easy and the very definition of tedium... You can figure out what to do within a few moments, but they decided to add platforming into the mix with floating slates of rock, laser beams, and s***, and War sucks a** at this, I spent a whole level without making a single mistake and still spent an hour moving from one place to another.

*Then there are weapons, gear, items, and leveling up (this is a long and major gripe), if you thought War was slow just wait until you try leveling up, you get a total of five main weapons throughout the story, I finished the entire game and only got to max out his main weapon, you get so little in game currency for upgrades that you eventually find yourself in a situation where all the enemies aside from the zombies take more damage than a hooker during an orgy... So your practically forced to focus on leveling one weapon or suffer the consequences of being completely under-powered for the entirety of the game...

*When it comes to Gear they don't give you stuff to compliment your fighting style at all, its more like trinkets to access other parts of the map that you get to keep after completing more damn puzzles, and some of them serve absolutely no use at all outside of their main purpose...

*Items are simply not worth your time, mainly because of how expensive they are, putting it into perspective you only get around 75,000 to 80,000 soul in the entire game and that's with moderate grinding, if memory serves me right one thing of regular health runs for 750 soul and a large one runs for 1500 soul, which is absolutely absurd since this is the same currency you use to upgrade your weapons as well... To make matters worse, you can only carry one potion at a time and they are disposable after each use... Also, the health potion is the only potion that I ever found to be useful in the game, the others give temporary rage or poison alterations for your weapon, neither of which add a reasonable amount of damage to your attacks, and in combat the enemies, like I said before, are few and far apart so if your lucky enough to kill one or two enemies before the potion runs out then you still wasted a ton of soul, so unless you found the potion lying around in one of the levels (you'll have a higher chance of finding a unicorn, that won't respawn for your information), then you just spent the soul that you could have used to upgrade your weapon instead... 

*The camera does what it want's and doesn't give a rat's a** about your opinion...

*Combat is difficult, which wouldn't be a bad thing at all, but it's difficult in the wrong way, war has slow and clunky movements and this doesn't mix well with the hack and slash genre, reason being that your often surrounded and would get combos broken either because the camera didn't let you see that one guy about to rock your world from behind, or the huge gaps between War's attacks gave the jerk the opportunity to hit you anyway, you can't counter or block between attacks, not only that but some attacks can't be countered or will damage you nonetheless, and there is no indicator to tell you what War can and can't block or counter, so your kinda just left to hope for the best, you can also try dodging but Wars mobility is so low that you often get hit anyway, you can eventually find a way to strategize some crowd control; and by that I mean retreating after every single attack, but at that point I personally rather not...

*Everything is scarce in this game, from enemies to items, there are no survivors, just crows which you can mercilessly chase and hack down for a sip of health, whatever soul or rage or health you manage to squeeze from whatever enemy you happen to cross by is so minimal that it barely makes an impact on any of your bars or income, the game is a very linear open world where you get one or two routes towards an end destination and though pretty, I had a very lonely, boring, and frustrating experience crawling through the maps in this game.

***Conclusion, War is actually the deadly sin of Sloth, and he's always late...***

When I bought this game maybe 6-7 years ago, it was honestly a good game.  It did have game breaking bugs tho, which did cause me to rage quit my infamous 'Apocalypse' run which had at most 2hrs left of game time -_- I wasn't happy. Now years later, other problems have appeared. I had to run the game in 'Compatibility Mode' (I think it was Windows XP2 or 3) because if I didn't the game would crash just by starting a new game. This led to stuttering throughout gameplay, freezing, and audio not synching through most cutscenes. The achievements also glitch out if you tab out, don't play darksiders first when lauching STEAM or probably if you don't give the game enough attention.
The game was great when I first played it, now though its too much effort just to get it to work and then try and enjoy a playthrough. Darksiders: Warmastered Edition has since been released and should be the version you buy now. 

In 2012: 7/10     In 2019: 3/10

Time to put this one on the pyre and send it to Valhalla.

51274819.review:
Controls are clunky, with the character seeming rather unresponsive at times during platforming bits. Puzzles are ridiculously easy - to the point of boredom and frustration. The combat is boring unless you're faced with hordes of monsters, but that's rare in this hack and slash title. There is little variety in the enemies you fight in the game. 

They obviously contracted out the world design, because that's one of this game's few redeeming factors. However, when it came to adding content to the world they failed miserably. So many empty spaces. You spend most of your time walking back and forth in an empty world.

The game is incredibly linear. The story is pretty much non-existent; they give you about a 1 minute summary of the background. Boss battles are pathetic; they have maybe 1 or 2 unique moves that they repeat over and over and over... The bosses are so easy. Cutscenes are forced and there are a lot of them. Often times there are forced cutscenes to show you the door you just unlocked ... in front of you next to the lever.

Camera control is rather awkward, which makes the underwater combat annoying. 

This is a direct console port, so it is a buggy mess that crashes if you ALT-TAB away. The UI will completely disappear at times if you ALT-TAB while playing in borderless windowed mode. If you don't remove the 20 loading videos, you'll spend more time waiting to press 'continue' then you will playing the game.

Want a similar game? Play Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 1. Better combat, better story, better puzzles, (way) better bosses, and better graphics.
