50643239.review:
Imagine the Legend of Zelda, if its design team had been headed up by Todd Macfarlane.
That's basically Darksiders. And, you're enjoyment of the game will depend almost entirely upon your immediate reaction to that mental image. 

I am an unrepentant 90s kid at heart. So Joe Madureira's ludicrously over-detailed characters and worlds made for a delightful throwback. However, I completely understand those who feel as though this game is designed to replicate the sense of sandpaper being ground into their eyes. It's aesthetic choices are divisive to say the least.

Fortunately, the gameplay is solid. Again, that's mainly because Darksiders is a blatant LoZ clone. However, it at least has the decency to be a competent one. There's a lot of effort and care put into the puzzles and enemies that populate the game's varied dungeons. It offers nothing revolutionary, but Darksiders constantly strives to match the quality of its predecessors. And honestly, there aren't many games I can honestly cay make so sincere an effort.

Great fun, if you can stomach the visuals.
Which are slightly blurrier, since this isn't the Warmastered edition.
This may actually be considered an improvement by some players.

50279128.review:
[h1][b]If you dont know about Darksiders, it might look like a typical RPG. It might look clunky and wierd and a copycat of lots of tropes you've seen before. [/b][/h1]

[h1]And tbh, it is. But it also intends to be - in a good way![/h1]
Hear me out for a second, okay? I'll explain.

[i]EDIT: oh yeah, it has lots of influence from zelda, btw.
If you like playing Zelda games (or copycats of it, as you probably know there are A LOT of them/this playstyle)
This playes just like it. -- Not BotW ofc, more like the older ones! -- so if you like the Zelda series, you should probably check this out[/i]

[b]This game is one of those that kinda playes around with tropes and cliches you've come to know[/b]
Most of the plot is superficial and just playing to tropes, at the beginning i was super let down and didnt know why i did this to myelf - i started making fun about this game to my friends but somehow i didnt stop playing. And after a while it hit me, bc the game actually makes this on purpos and it does actually make fun of itself in a lot of ways. I had fun BECEAUSE OF THIS.
Its like a fever dream of all the fantasy games (or books/movies) you've seen around the earlier fantasy scene (90s/2000s).
And it works. One you stop expecting something new, it starts to get refreshing just by playing into the things you know and probably love. Its like a warm and funny and gritty reminder of why you probably like the genre.

Art style is probably an homage to WoW now that i think about it, haha.
Anyhow, i think before you know it, you'll grow to like it. Its likely not changing your world, it wont impress you by having a big, suprising story - but it will let you have raw, wacky fun. And let you life out one of your fantasy-power fantasies 
--- i mean you are a god and basically punch everything dead xD

[h1] So yeah. Its simple, but fun. I cant sell something new or extraordinary to you bc there frankly isnt. But somehow - somehow its something really worthwhile, that i probably wont forget. And i know, when i just want a good time, and enjoy all that fantasy has become, i'll likely check out the sequels. [/h1]
[b]Ordinary doesnt mean bad, y'know? Lots of things we like and love are, but sometimes there is beauty in it. This game has exactly this kind of beauty.[/b]

Darksiders is one of my favorite franchises and it took me minutes to say if the 2010 title is worth buying or not.

+ The sound is pretty decent and the voices too.

Cons :

- War could be taller and not so fatty.
- Very bad port. No advanced display settings, might getting low fps on low hardware.
- Also, a co-op story campaign would have been more entertaining.
- The throwing system is totally shit.

In conclusion, Darksiders gets an 8/10 from me. Totally worth buying.

49780541.review:
I forget how I came to be in possession of Darksiders, or even how I became aware of it. But I do know that I first played it on Xbox 360 and it is a shining example of what a "Triple-A" release can be if it is allowed to: A game that has almost nothing new but does almost everything right. It's a fusion of PS2-era God-of-War-style hack-and-slash combat with Zelda-style dungeon crawling and equipment gathering, dressed up in a comic-book retelling of the biblical apocalypse, with bulging muscles and growling voices, born from the mind of noted X-Men author Joe Madureira. Darksiders is a spectacle of visual effects and button mashing that looks ridiculous on the surface- but it absolutely works in practice. As a life-long non-fan of the Zelda series, my frequent refrain is that Darksiders is my favorite iteration. 

The player takes the role of no-one less then War, horseman of the apocalypse. Banished to a wasted Earth following a premature triggering of Armageddon, for which he has been blamed, War must tear his way through demons, angels, the walking dead and towering monstrosities to discover the truth. He has his trusty sword Chaoseater and horse Ruin, a variety of other weapons and magic artifacts, and help from small handful of non-hostile NPCs. 

A lengthy and meaty game without excessive difficulty, Darksiders is an entertaining romp and certainly one of the better large titles of it's generation. It would then be exceeded by it's sequel, this time starring Death and taking on an Action-RPG bent with upgradable weapons and armor, new worlds beyond Earth and a quest system.

The death of THQ cast the future of the series in doubt, though not forever, as there is now a much-awaited third entry in the series that I have yet to play. But I will.

In some situations the player must throw the inert bomb on a certain enemies to destroy them. However, to activate the inert bomb you must first hit a fire source with a crossblade (which is a range attack weapon requiring you to aim at the target) then redirect the crossblade to hit the bomb. If the bomb is attached on the enemy and the enemy is a boss who moves all around on the field, then it is extremely difficult to complete all the actions required to ignite the bomb during the fight using keyboard and mouse. (You must dodge all of the boss' attack while you are aiming. Otherwise it will be interupted and you need to do it all over again.)

And if you fail to beat any boss, then you are stuck and won't be able to move on.

Do not purchase this game if you plan to play it using keyboard and mouse.

48111672.review:
Después de 18 horas explorando y seguir una historia perfecta, matando bestias, realizando muchos combos, mejoras de poderes y armas. Debo realizar una reseña sobre este GRAN JUEGO.

Darksiders es un juego que vale la pena tener en la biblioteca de STEAM, si te encantan los juegos del genero "Hack and slash" (cómo DmC, God of War, Bayonetta, etc) este es un título para ti. La historia se basa en nuestro personaje llamado Guerra, que pertenece al grupo los "Cuatro Jinetes", donde es engañado y rompe el Pacto entre Cielo e Infierno. Todo transcurre en la Tierra y se desata el Apocalipsis. De allí empezamos en un espiral de venganza y redención para averiguar qué es lo que realmente ha pasado y recuperar tanto sus poderes como su honor. 

Historia 10/10
Jugabilidad 10/10
Gráficos 10/10
Banda sonora 10/10

Lo que me encantó:

- La exploración entre cada uno de los escenarios es impresionante con un gran detalle artístico.
- Gran realización de combos con distintas armas y mucha sangre.
- Desbloquear poderes mientras que vayas avazando y regresar a zonas donde no podías pasar. Ya que necesitas un poder específico y conseguir tu recompensa.
- Muchos puzzles donde pasaba minutos para tratar de resolverlos.
- Excelente rendimiento en la parte de los FPS.

Quedé impresionado con este juego y estaré esperando una rebaja para comprar el Darksiders 2.

47807966.review:
[h1]Darksiders[/h1]

Darksiders is primarily a hack and slash action game developed by The Vigil Games and produced by THQ Nordic in the year 2010. It is based on the biblical story of  the arrival of four horsemen of Apocalypse to end the battle between Heaven's Hellguard and Hell's legions to maintain the balance whenever the seven seals are broken.

[h1]"The Seventh Seal Is Not Broken"[/h1]

The game starts off with Earth being a battleground for a barbaric war between angels and demons.Our protagonist WAR( the youngest among the horsemen) arrives to put an end to the Apocalypse.But to his surprise he doesn't find his brothers joining him in this cleansing act.

Confused and angry WAR wreaks hell on anything that comes in his path, killing a large number of heaven's and hell's forces without any hesitation. Soon he ends up fighting a giant mechanical monster called destroyer and during this fight he overhears the conversation between two angelic leaders of their plan to bring the apocalypse on Earth without breaking the seventh seal.

Furious and filled with rage WAR charges at the Destroyer but is easily overpowered and mocked. Seemingly killed during this brutal battle WAR finds himself saved by the Charred Council ( the entites charged by the creator to ensure balance). WAR pleads them of a wicked trickery and manages to get their allowance to uncover the truth and prove his innocence.Will WAR survive the hostile Apocalyptic Earth and its challenges to raise the curtains from a well devised plan or will he succumb, which is left to the player to find out and enjoy this roller coaster of a apocalyptic ride.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Players control WAR through a third person perspective where the game requires players to fight hordes of varied enemies and engrossing boss battles. Another aspect of the game is puzzle soving which needs the usage of correct equipment at the right time to progress through the levels.

Throughout the game there are a number of scattered Vulgrim shops which can be accessed to improve or buy new gear in exchange of souls received by killing opponents. There are also parts in the game where WAR can summon his horse Ruin to assist him in combat and is absolutely essential while facing some specific boss battles.

Combat is the usual hacking and slashing, along with some ground shattering earthquake intensity punches. Different types of weapons for different playstyles are instilled to avoid repetitiveness. Along with combat comes blocking and dash which is needed to avoid incoming attacks or to send a devastating counter blow.

[h1]Graphics and Sounds[/h1]

Graphics and sound quality of this game fail to produce the desired effect. Even with the presence of different play areas the visuals are boringly same all around with exception to a few select areas such as Eden which is visitable only once throughout the game.  On the contrary the cutscenes of Darksiders are really well done and are quite motivating for a player to explore the game. The music and in game music gets irritating really soon and there is no major change in this field till the game ends.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
 [list]
  [*]Interesting plot.
  [*]Satisfactory and enjoyable combat.
  [*]Awesome Boss Battles.
  [*]Well created cutscences.
 [/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
 [list]
  [*]Repetitive gameplay and low replayability.
  [*]Music is well created.
  [*]Mediocre graphics.
  [*]Slow mechanics of WAR and under use of Ruin.
 [/list]

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

Darksiders is a good enough game to enjoy for the gamers having a taste of Hack-Slash with a really captivating story line. It does lack big time in some areas but it can surely be enjoyed for the first time around. I would recommend it to specific gamers with a liking of fast paced action. The game does have an awesome ending which generates interest for the second Darkisder game.

45799729.review:
This game is so much like Zelda, it's sometimes hard to tell the difference.
So here's a 12 step guide for you people who can't tell the difference : 

1 - Link open doors. War kicks them open.
2 - Link open locked doors with keys. In a world where Keyholes are eyes, War stab them with fist dagger.
3 - Link open chests. War punches the chests until they break, then loot what's inside.
4 - Link befriends winged fairy folks. War rip or cut the wings of everything that has a pair of wings.
5 - Link rides Epona, a noble steed. War's horse is on fire, and it's name is Ruin.
6 - Link takes advice from a Fairy. War is stalked by a sadistic torture demon.
7 - Link moves blocks to solve puzzles. War only pushes blocks when he is upstairs, to create holes in the floors to jump in. War knows the REAL puzzles are underground.
8 - Link collects rupees. War collects the souls of murdered foes.
9 - Link is an only son. War's big brother is Death. Litteraly.
10 - Link can transform into an adult. War can change into a fiery demon behemoth.
11 - Link has a sword and a shield. War wields a sword bigger than two Links, and his left hand is his shield.
12 - Link works to save the world. War works to save it, until the time he is called to actually end it.
13 - Link fishes in his minigame. War murders demons by throwing cars at them during his.

I hope it helped.

Note : Awesome game, lots of fun.

45455676.review:
The early game of Darksiders starts off a bit slow as you're fairly underpowered but you steadily pick up gear and new powers and by the time you've hit the midgame you've gotten into a good flow of killing demons and solving puzzles.

Then the end game hits. The combats become less frequent, instead being drowned out by boring puzzles where the hardest part is hitting a button at the right time instead of solving them. I found there was a lot of backtracking at this point through levels and War isn't the hastiest thing alive. The last major dungeon was very boring, consisting mostly of solving the same type of puzzle 3 times, but slightly harder each time.

After this you've to backtrack and find the pieces of the magic Maguffin that are hidden throughout a bunch of the areas you've been through. Finally, you get to the final boss, the bosses so have far generally been pretty interesting and challenging so I was pretty hyped up for this one.

It was woeful. The first phase involved doing the same attack to knock down the boss three times and then pressing the dodge button whenever they telegraphed an attack. After that, you went to a new phase where you dodged whenever the boss did one of their incredibly obvious tells with loads of lead time and then hit them a few times. Rinse, repeat, throw in the odd button mash and there you go. Final boss.

No using all the cool gear you've picked up, no puzzle elements, nothing. Just press dodge and slash. 

The post boss scene wasn't very exciting or interesting and overall the ending left a lot to desire.

I'd probably still recommend the game as the majority of the time I spent playing, I enjoyed. I'm not sure if the Warmastered edition is better as I don't know what it changes, I only realised near the very end that I had the Warmastered edition in my Steam library. 

Overall, don't rush to clear it out of the backlog.

45311580.review:
Darksiders is a beautifully made, very fun and addictive adventure hack and slash game with a gripping story, badass combat, and so much more.

The story itself is very interesting, focused on the chaos of the war between heaven, and hell. You play as War, one of the four horsemen of the apocalypse summoned to earth after the war was mysteriously started prematurely, before mankind had a way to defend itself against angels and demons. Framed for staring this war, you venture out into the now destroyed, demon-infested world only to find that mankind has gone extinct, and it's up to you to clear your name, and prove your innocence. 

The hack and slash combat is madly entertaining, very well done, and not easy to get bored of or feel like it's getting repetitive. Interesting combos and weapons, allowing you to mix up how you choose to destroy your enemies, whilst feeling like a total badass doing so. And of course there's nothing more satisfying than unleashing the fury of a million
gods on that one spider you missed that got lucky and attacked you, screwing you up mid-combo.

Exploration is also very fun, with hidden goodies and things to find around the world, there's always some goal driving you clear the whole map. The characters were decent, albeit a bit, boring sometimes, maybe? Namely speaking, War. He felt a bit lacking of personality. While yes okay, he is War, supposed to be super serious and all, he just seemed very bland in my opinion.

All in all, I'd say the game is definitely worth it, maybe not at default price for everyone, but then again it never hurts to get games on a discount instead. Good amount of gameplay, around 30 hours or so. And, of course, achievements! Please note that if you are an achievement hunter, these ones can be very buggy and don't unlock, but there is a simple way to bypass it. Some very fun achievements, although you should expect a bit of grinding as well.

So, in conclusion if you're a fan of adventure hack and slash games, I'd say give this one a go, you won't regret it.

45298249.review:
Estamos ante un gran juego hack and slash con tintes de RPG. Controlaremos a Guerra, uno de los cuatro jinentes del apocalipsis que es llamado a la tierra porque, supuestamente, se ha desencadenado. Cuando llegamos nos encontramos una masacre por parte del infierno, algo no anda bien y tendremos que descubrir que es.

La historia es muy entretenida, con bastante trasfondo y algún que otro giro inesperado. Guerra es sin duda uno de los personajes mas carismáticos que he jugado, con mucha personalidad y sin duda se hace querer.

Las mecánicas, tanto de plataformeo como de combate son fáciles de controlar y vamos a tener una amplia variedad de movimientos tanto con la espada como con las armas secundarias para segar la vida de todo aquello que se cruce en nuestro camino. Loz puzzles son bastante sencillos aunque en muchos de ellos necesitaremos un buen timing para logar superarlos.

Los gráficos son muy buenos, dado cuando salió el juego, y te sumerje muy bien en el ambiente postapocalíptico y vienen aderezados con una, a mi ver, gran banda sonora.

Como puntos negativos, el uso de Ruina (caballo de Guerra) mas allá del boss donde es necesario queda reducido a un nivel puramente anecdótico (recluido a una zona de mapa muy concreta, que es muy muy grande, pero también vacía) y me parece muy poco explotado. Al mismo tiempo, una vez llegamos a cierto nivel de poder los enemigos son irrelevantes y el mapa se queda un poco vacío de enemigos. Salvando el conseguir los coleccionables o subir de nivel todas las armas no hay necesidad alguna de volver a los escenarios periféricos, lo que hace irrelevante el que puedas teleportarte a ellos de nuevo. Personalmente, he tenido muchos problemas con el juego a nivel de errores críticos (salirse del juego) lo que ha provocado que no haya conseguido algunos logros de historia pese a pasarme el 99% del juego (me falta subir el ultimo nivel de la guadaña).

He jugado este juego 100% con Steam Controller en dificultad Apocalíptica con mucha satisfacción, pese a algunos problemas de no detección del mando a causa de algunas actualizaciones de la plataforma, ya resueltos.

45208135.review:
darksiders is post apocalyptic hack and slash adventure released in 2010.  
the story takes place on earth 100 years after the war between heaven and hell. you play as war, one of the four horsemen of the apocalypse, which are responsible for keeping the balance. you are sent to earth by charred council, in order to find out who started the war and to restore the balance.

the plot is very engaging and well thought out. the game also has interesting backstory which you can learn about by reading digital comic book that you get when you buy the game. characters are very interesting, but the dialogue can be a bit cringy sometimes.
combat is very good in my opinion. at the beginning it can be a bit repetitive, but once you unlock more moves, abilities and secondary weapons it becomes much more fluid and satisfying. the game is console port, but they have done good job with the controls on pc. i played with mouse & keyboard and it was perfectly fine.
the world is pretty large and diverse. there are more then 10 major areas in the game, and each one is very different and unique, it's really a joy to explore. the fast travel system is done very well, and you can always go back to previous areas whenever you want despite the actual story being completely linear, which i don't mind since they deliver it very nicely.
both music and voice acting are extremely good and epic. it really makes the game much more immersive.
there's quite a few puzzles in the game, and i think that difficulty is on point for this type of game. each area has a boss, and unique mechanic for beating it.
on my first playthrough on normal difficulty it took me over 25 hours to beat the game. that includes a lot of exploring, backtracking and achievement grinding. my second playthrough on apocalyptic took me around 12 hours to complete.
the graphics overall have aged very well, but there's a few low res textures. at least it runs extremely smooth, without any stuttering. there's quite a few bugs, for example the game doesn't like alt tabbing or steam overlay; there's some game breaking bugs (i haven't experienced them myself though)...
warmastered edition brings some new graphical options, better textures and fixes some bugs mentioned above.

tldr: great story, interesting characters, fluid combat & controls, and immersive world. i highly recommend this game.

44917546.review:
Ah Darksiders, proof that everything can be an inspiration, even Bible.
Darksiders is a hack and slash action-adventure video game developed by Vigil Games and published by THQ. 
It takes inspiration from the apocalypse and battle of armageddon described in the Bible's Book of Revelation.

You play as War, one of the four horsemen of the apocalypse, who is charged in causing premature Apocalypse and destroying Earth. War makes a deal to be placed back on Earth to find out who was behind the catastrophe and punish them. 

In terms of gameplay Darksiders dosen't stand out from other hack and slash games.
Game combines combat and puzzle-solving/platforming and has a linear story with semi-open world.

Combat is similar to Devil May Cry or God of War and focuses on combo based sword combat, that means that typical smashing of a one attack shouldn't allow you to make far. But in practice...it's 50/50. Yes, you will use your main attack the most, but you won't get far without others, especially against tougher opponents. 
Here is a problem, after unlocking stun attacks you are basically jacked as they work against 80% of enemies in game, making fights one sided, even more at the later stages where you have all unlockables. 
Game features executions system which dosen't help you in making a game harder, as even near death, enemies could stab you instead of smashin E everytime someone is near death. 
Oh and because you can do that on every enemy, those will get repetitive really soon.
Speaking of enemies, issue lies in those aswell. Mostly what I can point out is lack of attacks. 
"Smaller" enemies in game have only 1 attack, bigger ones and bosses, expect last boss in game, about 2-3 in total. 
Easy to predict and avoid, often those attacks fail and game tries to balance that with more waves or simply, more enemies in one wave. Still, even with those issues, combat is fast paced, fluid and enjoyable. Just too easy, even for a hack and slash newbie like me.

War main weapon is a sword, he also has two secondaries, and few items in equipment you will get along your journey, yet those often are used only in specific boss  (I will talk about that a little later) or for collectibles. In a fight you should rely on a sword and secondaries much more.

Souls are in game currency which you can get by killing enemies, destroying enviroment, or opening chests.
You can spend them in your friendly merchant for new toys, enhancements, attacks, and more!
Besides that, you can upgrade your health and rage meter by collecting shards, you can use wrath meter to show off your true nature of a demon for a short amount of time, upgrade weapons damage by simply using them, add enhancements to each of them to get bonuses, collect armor, and more. A lot, but afterall, you are War so you better be prepared for a fight. 

Second part of a game is focused on semi-open world and puzzles.
Semi open world biggest issue is lack of content. Expect collectibles to upgrade yourself, you don't have anything to do. No arenas, no challenges, no sub quests, no nothing. It's beautiful, and I liked to explore it, but it lacks content. 

Puzzles are great! But. There is but. I hate that game treats them not as puzzles. What I want to say is, game holds your hand really strong though the game, in puzzle sections aswell. Most of them could be difficult or atleast challenging if game didn't show me what to do in first few seconds. There is only 2 or 3 real puzzles where game dosen't tell you what to do. Shame. Still, enjoyed "solving" them.

Expect problems I already mentioned, game boss fights are weak. Most of them includes usage of a item you got in their arena more than the sword fight itself. The last boss fight is the only really good one. Which is a shame because boss fights should show off your skill and performance, not your new toy. Or rather, balance it, atleast!

Performance was bad for me. Game overall crashed about 5 times, plus I had weird bug with muffled sound like I was underwater, and once I had a game breaking bug which caused me to start the game all over again. 
Atleast FPS didn't freak out, had constant 60 FPS thoughout whole game.

Game dosen't have Multiplayer or Coop mode.

Sound design is great!
Voice acting is good, maybe beside War, he just dosen't click with me, besides that everything else is fine.
Enemies sound just like they want to rip you apart, soundtrack in game adds climat it should add.

Overall, even with issues, game is great and enjoyable. 
Combat even when too easy, is fun, story and lore in game is interesting, and locations are really good looking as for a game about Apocalypse. Game manages to combine puzzles with combat perfectly! 
Still, have to include many issues this game has, a rather empty world, pretty weak boss fights, and performance.

7/10! "It's not *death* that you should fear."

If you enjoyed that review check out my curator page!
https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31947302/

44338419.review:
[h1][b]Review of:[/b] [i]Darksiders[/i][/h1]

Although [i]Darksiders[/i] was originally released for Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3, the game lived to see the day when it was ported to PC, which definitely wasn’t a bad idea after all. Well, actually it’s still as good as it was if you’re looking for a gory, adventurous experience filled with fast-paced action. The game was developed by [b]Vigil Games[/b] and released by [b]THQ[/b].

At first glance it looks like when Joe Madureira was designing characters and the setting of [i]Darksiders[/i], he was inspired by the [i]Book of Revelation[/i], simply because the game begins with the Apocalypse - angels and demons falling from the sky fighting each other, defenseless people fleeing and trying to save themselves… and out of nowhere, in the middle of this pure madness appears one of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse: War. However, it turns out that the protagonist arrived unsummoned and the so-called Charred Council blames him for disturbing the balance between Heaven and Hell, which ended up with the demise of the entire humanity. Well, that certainly doesn’t sound good. Anyway, in order to set things right, War is sent back to the Earth not only to restore the balance, but also to find and punish those who are responsible for this whole mess.

In short, [i]Darksiders[/i] is a well-optimised game that runs smoothly, presents decent graphics along with the atmospheric soundtrack as well as rather unique gameplay. On the way to War’s redemption, there’s a few weapons offering different combat styles, a lot of combos to master, numerous epic boss battles and many challenging puzzles.

Since [i]Darksiders[/i] is a third-person hack-and-slash action adventure game, it focuses mostly on dynamic and aggressive combat, but the storyline is also really well-written and serves as a great completion of the whole game’s image. The combat system itself is simply spectacular in its goriness and flow, especially in terms of finishing moves when enemies are left with just a tiny bit of health, however, those animations don’t work as quick time event (QTE) sequences - you just press the button and voila! No mashing your gamepad or keyboard. The gameplay is rather linear and as War progresses through the game, he unlocks new weapons and abilities, but I’d say that his primary sword Chaoseater is the best all-round and I stick to it most of the time during my playthroughs. Then, there are also the so-called Wrath Abilities, but they’re rather limited, even when fully upgraded. And last but certainly not least, War’s ace in the hole known as Chaos Form; after building up enough chaos energy, he is able to transform into an incredibly powerful fiery demon, being invulnerable and hitting harder.

Considering that [i]Darksiders[/i] was ported to PC, I highly recommend playing through the game with a gamepad, but if someone is out of options, then a mouse and keyboard will do. Still, controlling War may be sometimes troublesome, especially when it comes to climbing or dropping off the ledges.

All in all, [i]Darksiders[/i] is a solid hack-and-slash based game with unique gameplay and design. Decent graphics, the atmospheric soundtrack along with a well-written storyline make it even better. Overall, the game is definitely worth playing. So, in the end, 9/10 would slay some angels and demons again. And, lastly, thanks for reading my review.

44288068.review:
Darksiders es un juego de aventura con toques de plataformas, rol, exploración, puzzles y combate hack ‘n slash. Una mezcla de géneros que originan una épica historia de fantasía con una larga duración, de entre 30 a 40 horas.

Basado en el mito de los 4 jinetes del apocalipsis, en esta primera entrega de la saga manejamos a Guerra en una lucha por el descubrimiento de una verdad oculta. Con numerosos elementos extraídos de la religión y de las leyendas relacionadas con el cielo y el infierno, Darksiders muestra un rico mundo lleno de personajes con una trama llena de traiciones y secretos, en ocasiones algo confusa si no se presta mucha atención.

Guerra se verá envuelto en una encerrona de la que tratará de salir airoso tras un enfrentamiento entre el cielo y el infierno. Un consejo convoca a nuestro protagonista para darle la oportunidad de redimirse por algo que realmente él no ha provocado, pero castigándole despojándole de muchos poderes que más tarde iremos recuperando en el juego.

El mundo de Darksiders está dividido en varias secciones grandes interconectadas entre sí alrededor de una zona central a la que habrá que volver en varias ocasiones a lo largo de la historia. Aún siendo un juego lineal, hay escenarios bastante amplios, y la exploración es casi siempre algo prioritario. En los primeros escenarios hay menos posibilidades, pero a medida que se avanza éstos poseen más caminos escondidos y más profundidad de exploración. Escondidos en los niveles encontraremos reliquias que podremos vender para conseguir almas con las que comprar y mejorar nuestro equipo-, habilidades especiales, cofres con partes de una armadura especial o mejoras de vida y de nuestro nivel de furia.
Con una gran similitud a los esquemas jugables que proponía Soul reaver o Zelda, este juego trata de abarcar una jugabilidad bastante extensa que se va desarrollando lentamente, aunque es cierto que algunos puntos son más explotados que otros.

Guerra tiene una gran libertad de movimiento pudiendo correr, saltar, hacer doble salto, escalar, nadar, bucear, colgarse de cornisas, empujar bloques, etc. Además irá ganando nuevas habilidades y herramientas que expandirán aún más sus movimientos. El juego es muy inteligente al ir añadiendo con cuentagotas todas las nuevas habilidades que se van sumando, llegando a tener hacia el final tantas posibilidades que incluso se nos olvidará todo lo que somos capaces de hacer. Una de las habilidades más destacadas es la que nos permite abrir portales de entrada y salida gracias a una herramienta especial. Los puzzles y pruebas diseñados para usar esta pistola abreportales son muy imaginativas y resultan totalmente satisfactorios y divertidos de ejecutar. Otras posibilidades serán la de ralentizar el tiempo para poder sortear peligros rápidos, lanzar bolas explosivas y romper barreras para abrir nuevos caminos o la posibilidad de montar a Ruina, el caballo de Guerra, con el que podremos sortear grandes distancias en poco tiempo, así como luchar montados en él.

En la 2º mitad del juego todas estas posibilidades se combinan acertadamente originando una jugabilidad muy rica. De hecho el último escenario del juego es el que mejor diseño de niveles y puzzles tiene. La parte mala es que el ritmo de juego no está tan bien llevado, ya que en esta última parte del juego se concentran la mayoría de puzzles donde tendremos que explotar nuestro gran set de habilidades, dejando muchos compases carentes de estas pruebas y saturados de combates muy similares, que pueden resultar monótonos.
Algo similar ocurre con el plataformeo, que en la 1º mitad del juego es bastante sencillo y fácil de ejecutar, no demasiado estimulante, pero después se enriquece y los escenarios nos retan debiendo ejecutar movimientos más precisos y calculando mejor nuestros pasos. El control y movimiento de Guerra se siente relativamente tosco. No responde con rapidez si lo comparamos con otros juegos similares, y lo peor es que realmente entorpece la jugabilidad porque no será difícil que muramos en secciones plataformeras por culpa de este poco ágil control. Además, en mi opinión, los movimientos suelen ir algo acelerados, lo que vuelve el juego algo alocado en ocasiones además de dificultar el control y de no resultar estéticamente vistoso.

En general los puzzles son diversos e involucran grandes escenarios y sus mecanismos, así como las posibilidades de Guerra para avanzar. Su complejidad va en aumento mientras progresamos, encontrando pruebas muy variadas que poco tienen que ver entre sí, ya que constantemente se introducen nuevos elementos con los que interactuar.


El combate es bastante solvente. No está tan desarrollado como en otros hack and slash como God of War, ni tiene tantos combos ni posibilidades, aunque disponemos de muchas armas con sus pequeñas variaciones. Una de las particularidades para que el combate resulte más divertido es la posibilidad de usar el escenario y varios objetos en él para combatir a los enemigos. Así por ejemplo podremos arrancar algunas vigas y golpear o lanzárselas a las criaturas. También podremos utilizar coches, mobiliario variado o trampas naturales como lava o fosos para acabar con ellos. Tendremos la opción de golpear a enemigos voladores desde la distancia con una pistola o un shuriken gigante, aunque ciertamente no son muy eficaces. Podremos también agarrar a algunos enemigos y realizar ejecuciones finales bastante explícitas cuando éstos se encuentran debilitados. También Guerra posee una barra de furia que iremos ampliando, gracias a la que podremos ejecutar algunas habilidades potentes como mejorar nuestra defensa o un ataque de gran alcance.

Los jefes finales son un elemento a destacar, con un diseño chulísimo todos ellos, muy diferentes entre sí, y bastante complejos en general para derrotar. Habrá que seguir una estrategia diferente (o varias) para cada uno de ellos, normalmente implicando elementos del escenario para usar a nuestro favor. Así, los enemigos básicos no poseen siempre un diseño tan trabajado ni tienen este toque táctico particular para derrotarlos con alguna pequeña excepción, pero sí es cierto que hay un buen puñado de diferentes tipos de ellos.

El diseño de niveles es muy creativo, además de captar la atención del jugador con una ambientación muy cuidada. Aún dada la gran diversidad que hay entre los escenarios, el juego exhibe una gran cohesión en su estilo, dotándolo de una gran personalidad artística, aunque recuerda mucho a la imaginería del mundo de World of Warcraft. Se encuentran ciertos altibajos en este apartado, ya que a pesar de que la mayoría de niveles son bastante imaginativos, hay algunos bastante sosos y vacíos, con pocos elementos y que resultan genéricos. Es importante destacar que la mayoría de escenarios se sienten vivos, con muchos elementos dinámicos y rompibles, por lo que la sensación de decorados de cartón-piedra no tiene lugar en este juego, como sí ocurría en el similar Castlevania Lords of the Shadows.

Tanto en el diseño gráfico como el sonoro, así como la historia, se percibe un gran tono oscuro. El juego es bastante maduro y ofrece escenarios desolados, con una paleta de colores apagados y una música sombría. La historia que se nos cuenta es bastante elaborada, con unos personajes muy cuidados y bien representados, incluso los jefes a los que nos enfrentaremos tienen su propia personalidad, ejerciendo de personajes secundarios. Hay muchas escenas de vídeo donde transcurre la historia con más o menos interés, aunque tampoco el guión se desmarca ni puede sacar pecho, sí que funciona bien a la hora de presentar nuevos personajes y escenarios.

La BSO es notable, así como los efectos de sonido, aunque en ocasiones éstos no están lo suficientemente cuidados y se escucha cierto ruido general, sobre todo en secciones de combates. También hay algún problema con la sincronización de vídeo y sonido en las escenas cinemáticas que empobrece el resultado.

Puntuación final: 9/10

44246335.review:
[h1]Opinión[/h1]
Juego [i]"hack and slash"[/i] con un estilo comic-book americano que narra las aventuras de [b]Guerra[/b], uno de los cuatro jinetes del apocalipsis.

Bebe muchísimo de juegos como [b]God of War[/b] o [b]Zelda[/b], pero consiguiendo su propia personalidad gracias a la fantástica labor artística de [b]Joe Madureira[/b]. Además de ser un juego generoso de duración y relativamente sencillo de completar sus logros...

[h1]Contras[/h1]
Salidas y bugs en la versión de [b]Steam[/b], cosa que no ocurre en consolas. Puede llegar a ser bastante facilón y acabar tornándose algo repetitivo.

[h1]¿¿Lo recomiendo??[/h1]
✔️ Muy recomendable, sobre todo si buscas una especie de [b]Zelda[/b] con más golpes y menos puzles (que los hay). El estilo cómic le sienta genial.

Encima, tuvieron la decencia de regalar la versión [b]Darksiders Warmastered[/b] a todo el que tuviera la versión original (cosa que no hizo por ejemplo [b]Dark Souls[/b] y su edición [b]Remastered[/b]).

[h1]Valoración: 8'5/10[/h1]

44204306.review:
Fairly enjoyable at first as a slightly less polished God-of-War-type action platfomers. Unfortunately combat gets kind of old relatively quickly. Despite the diversity of moves, there is not a ton of incentive to move beyond mashing the attack button as that is usually equally effective when compared to fancier, more visually appealing combos. The story is a pretty basic narrative that serves its purpose but doesn't really add a ton of depth. 

The biggest failing of this game for me is that it often feels tedious and is pretty challenging to navigate without a lot of running back and forth to determine the next area you need to travel to or next puzzle you need to solve. It just got to be a chore for me. 

Overall: A good concept for a setting and basic action game style,but lacks in polish. Combat gets repetitive. Navigating through the game becomes tedious very quickly for me. I'm fine with some puzzle solving and careful exploration in many games, but something about this one often feels like a chore in terms of exploring the world.  Story is lackluster. 

A fairly mediocre game in terms of entertainment and recreational value for me.

Review ภาค Remastered แล้วก็ต้อง Review ภาค Standard ด้วย 
เป็นเก่าแล้วแต่เป็นเกมเก่าที่ยอดเยี่ยมมากได้อารมณ์แบบเดียวกับ God Of War เป๊ะๆ ทุกอย่างเหมือนกันแทบจะหมด เพียงแต่เราเป็น Horsemen เป็นผู้พิทักษณ์ 1 ใน 4 Horsemen นามว่า War เนื้อเรื่องคือมีปีศาจจากนรกบุกมาที่โลกโดยตกมาจากฟ้าและได้ทำลายผู้คนมากมาย และเราก็ถูกส่งมาจากนรกเช่นกันเพื่อมากำจัดปีศาจพวกนี้แต่นอกจากปีศาจแล้วก็ยังมีพวกเทพบางส่วนที่ไม่ถูกกับเราเท่าไหร่โผล่มาเป็นศัตรูด้วย เกมเพรย์ในภาคนี้ จะคล้ายกับ God Of War แต่เพียงระยะการโจมตีจะสั้งกว่าเพราะเราใช้ดาบแต่ถ้าตัวเราเทียบกับ Kratos แล้วเราตัวใหญ่กว่า และดาบก็ใหญ่กว่ามากแต่ที่ ตอนเล่นดูตัวเล็กเพราะ มุมกล้อง และเป็นเกม Hack and Slash ก็เรยต้องใช้มุมกล้องที่กว้าง แต่ก็ไม่มีปัญหาใดๆ เกมนี้เป็นเกมที่ยอดเยี่ยมอย่างมากรวมถึงผู้พัฒนาอีกด้วย THQ ค่ายพัฒนาเกมสุดเจ๋ง ที่สร้างเกมไหนก็มันทุกเกมแล้วได้หายไปนานหลายปีมากจนตอนนี้ก็ได้กลับมาพร้อมกับ Darksiders 3 แล้วจะต้องมีภาค 4 แน่นอนเพราะ THQ กลับมาแล้ว Graphics เกมนี้ไม่ได้สวยเท่า God Of War เท่าไหร่ แต่ Effect แสงสี ในเกมสุดยอดกว่าแน่นอน รับบเกมเพรย์ลื่นไหลมากแต่ก็มีข้อเสียหน่อยในเรื่องของการใช้อาวุธระยะไกล ปืน และ วงจักร เพราะการที่เราใช้อาวุธระยะไกลคู่กับอาวุธระยะประชิดจะทำให้เสียจังหวะการต่อสู้ระยะประชิิดในทันที แถมกระสุนแืนมีจำกัดด้วย ยิงหมดแล้วต้องรอชาจกระสุน และยิงช้ามาก พูดถึงเรื่องบัก เกมนี้บักน้อยมาก แต่ใหญ่โคตร เพราะตอนเล่นเกมมาแทบจะไม่เจอบักเรย แต่พอเจอปุ๊บทุกอย่างจบ เป็นด่านตอนใกล้จบเกม เป็นด่านในวิหารที่ต้องขึ้นลิฟไปตีบอสก่อนแล้วค่อยเปิดประตูจากด่านในที่ถูกพลังเวทย์ปิดไว้จากด่านนอก แต่ผมใช้ท่าพุ่ง เล่นๆจน ยังไม่ได้ขึ้นลิฟไปตีบอสเรยก็เข้าไปติดแล้ว ออกยังใงก็ไม่ได้ ออกเกมก็ไม่หาย โหลด save ก็อยู่ที่เดิม แล้วโชคร้ายกว่านั้นคือ มีแค่สอง Save คือล่าสุดที่ไปติดอยู่ด่านใน แล้ว อีก Save หนึ่ง ไกลมากเพิ่งจะเริ่มเนื้อเรื่อง เอาเป็นว่าถ้าจะเล่นเกมนี้ต้องเซฟแยกบ่อยๆ เพราะเกมนี้ไม่มี Select Mission มีแต่ Newgame Plus

43630347.review:
Before I get to my opinion, major issue with this game as listed here: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=218846633

Besides the major issue, the game itself has bugs, though I've heard the "Warmastered" edition has even more, but that's just heresay. The game itself is quite fun, it's a God-Of-War like game (to the point where you are actually playing one of the four horsemen, War) where you gather souls to buy ability upgrades, weapon movesets and upgrades for certain weapons. Your main and secondary weapons, however, are only upgraded through useage which can become a real drain if you're aiming for that 100%, since the gauntlets are very slow and have a simple moveset.

Your teritiary weapons are what you use to unlock new locations, get to hidden items and so on for upgrades. The story is ok, it's certainly not one that'd win awards, but it's enough to get you motivated to want to complete the game and see what happens at the end and who framed you. It has some mild puzzles throughout the game, however bosses are pretty simple in combat, usually requiring use of whatever new item you unlocked to kill it.
Overall, I'd say it's a decent and fun game, but I wouldn't have bought it at full price.

43163028.review:
[quote]It's not DEATH that you should fear.[/quote]

I've been playing this game a few times before even the Warmastered Edition and it is really unique to me. I started to love it from the first chapter up to the last one, from the first game quest and up to the last boss fight. Its colorful and history attract to it like a magnet, the heroes are charismatic and vivid, and the plot makes you devote yourself to the game on 110%

The plot causes me the most curiosity - we are met by the ruins of a large and modern city, which are filled with demons of all possible kinds and they all oppose to the angels from the Heavenly Kingdom. It comes to us like The Last Battle, the apocalypse, and in fact, we - the War - is one of the unholy riders of the apocalypse. But something immediately becomes suspicious, and we have to confront both the one side and the other - we were not expected on this party. Later, we get that we have been fabricated and the apocalypse started just through our appearance. War requires all the strength and power to find who started the Last Battle and clean his own name...

Gameplay wise this game is a blast to play and its almost hilarious how much Darksiders borrows from the God of War franchise, right down to the combat style, loot system, and platforming, but does it all so brilliantly that it's a cut above it in every way. As I was never a big fan of Kratos and I could not understand why that franchise was as highly rated as it was. Darksiders is a classic case of taking what's already been but build on it until perfection.

But knock-offs Darksiders earns tones of creative points in its level design, characters, puzzles, diverse environments and intriguing boss battles. The art style is superbly done, and in this day and age with the AAA games industry focusing too much on realism there is something refreshing about playing a quirky game over the top of the world where the nothings real, but everything just looks cool. With the post-apocalyptic sense of nature reclaiming the decimated city streets being taken over by the demons at the same time, the visual style falls somewhere between 'The Last of Us' and 'The Lords of the Fallen'. Unlike most puzzle-based games, the puzzles in Darksiders are actually unique to any game of these genera and fun to traverse and conquer require a fair amount of thought without pushing the player to give up and look up the quick guide on Youtube.

[h1]The verdict[/h1]
The game is definitely worth the attention. And even more - you [b]must[/b] finish with the highest complexity to achieve a real War experience. 

10 souls out of 10

You know what is most extraordinary about this game. You don't save the world. Being one of four Horsemen means you that you came to play only when apocalypse is now.

[i]Design[/i]. I like Darksiders very much for its catchy desing of weapons and armors. I would not say that it is very original but the level is pretty high. Characters and monsters(excluding few low level generic) have great concept aswell.
[i]Atmospheric.[/i] Ruins of modern civilization mixed with a pieces of hells interior look great. Designers did really good job here. (Ever though that people are more easely facinated with ruins than with functioning architecture?)
[i]Combat.[/i] Standard. Three main wepons, projectiles, a hadful of combos. Nothing innovative, yet no complaints.
[i]Difficulty.[/i] If you are some kind of Darksouls fan you won't be close to testing your skills here. Also if you are experienced with slashers, I would recommend hitting hard-difficulty setting righ away.
[i]Plot.[/i] Does not look poorly, but overall is delivered somehow roughly. An unbelivebly strong being is going to set things right, you probaly know how it's gonna end. So basically the starting point is ravange and War is professinal warrior who doesn't talk much(Death on a contrary is a joker), so without some side stories (and there are none) you can't build intresting script. So no hard feelings.
[i]Linear.[/i] Wrath of war is "old-style" slasher. You basically run corridors and there are forks, but you can't go one of ways because you need to acquire some key or item or ability. You can go back some times to find treasures or to farm, but thas not open world.

Well, you might feel a bit discoureged, cause I named a lot problems. But they are more disclaimers, that you should know about. Over all game is great. Depending on what you seek in hack and slash game it can make in top 5 -10 best. It aged very well and looks good even today. So if you are into swingin swords, Wrath of War if a must try, and worry not...

... War [i]would[/i] laugh even at his own funeral.

41483934.review:
Darksiders came out in the middle of the Second Golden Age of gaming, when 3-D action was finally hitting it's stride and new, mind-blowing gameplay concepts were commonplace, as was the tendency of subsequent games to rip them off (or pay homage to them). It's tough to play describe Darksiders without going down the rabbit hole of comparing it to other games; “It's like a more mature Zelda”, “It's like God of War”, “You get a literal Portal gun”, etc. Thankfully, the mix and match nature of the design steals (borrows) the best elements from legendary sources, and the fantastic art from Joe Madureira lets it stand on it's own.
 
  You play as War, one of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse, arriving on Earth to partake in the final battle between the forces of Heaven and Hell. You've arrived to the party early, and are swept up in a plot of revenge, backstabbing, and servitude involving the defeated army of Heaven, some demon creatures, and The Council of Something or Other. It's a twisted, rather convoluted story that's relayed through sporadic cutscenes varying in tone from epic drama, comic book heroics, lighthearted comic relief, and being metal as fuck. I could barely follow it (it's full of hyperlinks and the game comes with a digital comic if you care), but it sets up a nice background for the brutal action and ruined, fantastic landscapes you must explore to get revenge... on someone. For something.
 
  Darksiders is heavy on the action; you're not going to travel very far without running into a pack of demons to dismember with sword, scythe, pistol, or any of the various tools you collect throughout the adventure. The combat system is more free-form than most other “character action” games, asking you to chain together simple special moves rather than memorize long strings of button presses to pull off intricate combos. The game does a good job of slowly introducing the basics of the combat, then adding onto it once you grasp how it works; you'll go from button mashing to finger-twisting controller acrobatics by the end. As you use each main weapon it increases in level, allowing you to unlock more moves for them or upgrade the ones you already have by spending Souls (currency awarded for defeating enemies) at a shop.
 
  While most encounters are typical melee affairs where you beat on hordes of enemies until a prompt appears above their heads and you deliver a gruesome finishing move, there is plenty of variety to keep the action from getting stale. Aside from the expected arena fights and boss battles, many of the objectives in Darksiders are based around to puzzle-solving, be it figuring out how to reach areas with the many tools you're given or how to deal with a group of creatures blocking your progress. As previously stated, the exploration is not far off from a Zelda game; You'll enter themed “dungeons” (some of them incredibly massive and complex), discover tools to help you advance, and fight a boss at the end of the stage that most likely involves the newest addition to your arsenal being it's weakness. There isn't much hand-holding here; you're expected to experiment with what you're given and use observational skills to get to the solution. It's rewarding to puzzle things out on your own, even if the goals aren't always apparent.
 
  A couple issues arise from the game constantly adding new abilities to War. One is the menu system; while it looks slick, it's rather daunting and isn't the best at conveying information. Just when you get used to the controls and have your hotkeys nailed down, you're given yet another tool or sub-weapon and have to shuffle everything around again. If you're playing on a controller it's not uncommon to run into an environmental puzzle and have to pause the game completely, making sure you have access to quick-swapping the abilities needed. Another is some of the cooler concepts are underutilized. For instance: You gain access to a badass-looking horse, only to ride it a short distance before you're dismounted and have to go into a claustrophobic, lengthy dungeon. Once you emerge, you've all but forgotten about it and it's only available in very limited areas. Same goes for the Portal gun... after the initial dungeon where it's introduced, it's barely a factor. Kind of disappointing for a game that let's you revisit most of it's stages.
 
  Darksiders is a competent and solid action game. With it's unique art style and mind-bending dungeons, it's still a blast to play even eight years after it's initial release. It's deceptively lengthy, but remains engaging until the end thanks to the constant evolution of War's toolkit. It might be guilty of “borrowing” from other games piecemeal, but it does so with the purpose of creating it's own unique vision of comic book apocalypse badassery and it succeeds.

41346808.review:
Darksiders es un juego de aventura con toques de plataformas, rol, exploración, puzzles y combate hack ‘n slash. Una mezcla de géneros que originan una épica historia de fantasía con una larga duración, de entre 20 a 25 horas.

Basado en el mito de los 4 jinetes del apocalipsis, en esta primera entrega de la saga manejamos a Guerra en una lucha por el descubrimiento de una verdad oculta. Con numerosos elementos extraídos de la religión y de las leyendas relacionadas con el cielo y el infierno, Darksiders muestra un rico mundo lleno de personajes con una trama llena de traiciones y secretos, en ocasiones algo confusa si no se presta mucha atención.

Guerra se verá envuelto en una encerrona de la que tratará de salir airoso tras un enfrentamiento entre el cielo y el infierno. Un consejo convoca a nuestro protagonista para darle la oportunidad de redimirse por algo que realmente él no ha provocado, pero castigándole despojándole de muchos poderes que más tarde iremos recuperando en el juego.

El mundo de Darksiders está dividido en varias secciones grandes interconectadas entre sí alrededor de una zona central a la que habrá que volver en varias ocasiones a lo largo de la historia.  Aún siendo un juego lineal, hay escenarios bastante amplios, y la exploración es casi siempre algo prioritario. En los primeros escenarios hay menos posibilidades, pero a medida que se avanza éstos poseen más caminos escondidos y más profundidad de exploración. Escondidos en los niveles encontraremos reliquias que podremos vender para conseguir almas con las que comprar y mejorar nuestro equipo-, habilidades especiales, cofres con partes de una armadura especial o mejoras de vida y de nuestro nivel de furia.
Con una gran similitud a los esquemas jugables que proponía Soul reaver o Zelda, este juego trata de abarcar una jugabilidad bastante extensa que se va desarrollando lentamente, aunque es cierto que algunos puntos son más explotados que otros.

Guerra tiene una gran libertad de movimiento pudiendo correr, saltar, hacer doble salto, escalar, nadar, bucear, colgarse de cornisas, empujar bloques, etc. Además irá ganando nuevas habilidades y herramientas que expandirán aún más sus movimientos. El juego es muy inteligente al ir añadiendo con cuentagotas todas las nuevas habilidades que se van sumando, llegando a tener hacia el final tantas posibilidades que incluso se nos olvidará todo lo que somos capaces de hacer. Una de las habilidades más destacadas es la que nos permite abrir portales de entrada y salida gracias a una herramienta especial. Los puzzles y pruebas diseñados para usar esta pistola abreportales son muy imaginativas y resultan totalmente satisfactorios y divertidos de ejecutar. Otras posibilidades serán la de ralentizar el tiempo para poder sortear peligros rápidos, lanzar bolas explosivas y romper barreras para abrir nuevos caminos o la posibilidad de montar a Ruina, el caballo de Guerra, con el que podremos sortear grandes distancias en poco tiempo, así como luchar montados en él.

En la 2º mitad del juego todas estas posibilidades se combinan acertadamente originando una jugabilidad muy rica. De hecho el último escenario del juego es el que mejor diseño de niveles y puzzles tiene. La parte mala es que el ritmo de juego no está tan bien llevado, ya que en esta última parte del juego se concentran la mayoría de puzzles donde tendremos que explotar nuestro gran set de habilidades, dejando muchos compases carentes de estas pruebas y saturados de combates muy similares, que pueden resultar monótonos.
Algo similar ocurre con el plataformeo, que en la 1º mitad del juego es bastante sencillo y fácil de ejecutar, no demasiado estimulante, pero después se enriquece y los escenarios nos retan debiendo ejecutar movimientos más precisos y calculando mejor nuestros pasos. El control y movimiento de Guerra se siente relativamente tosco. No responde con rapidez si lo comparamos con otros juegos similares, y lo peor es que realmente entorpece la jugabilidad porque no será difícil que muramos en secciones plataformeras por culpa de este poco ágil control. Además, en mi opinión, los movimientos suelen ir algo acelerados, lo que vuelve el juego algo alocado en ocasiones además de dificultar el control y de no resultar estéticamente vistoso.

En general los puzzles son diversos e involucran grandes escenarios y sus mecanismos, así como las posibilidades de Guerra para avanzar. Su complejidad va en aumento mientras progresamos, encontrando pruebas muy variadas que poco tienen que ver entre sí, ya que constantemente se introducen nuevos elementos con los que interactuar.


El combate es bastante solvente. No está tan desarrollado como en otros hack and slash como God of War, ni tiene tantos combos ni posibilidades, aunque disponemos de muchas armas con sus pequeñas variaciones. Una de las particularidades para que el combate resulte más divertido es la posibilidad de usar el escenario y varios objetos en él para combatir a los enemigos. Así por ejemplo podremos arrancar algunas vigas y golpear o lanzárselas a las criaturas. También podremos utilizar coches, mobiliario variado o trampas naturales como lava o fosos para acabar con ellos. Tendremos la opción de golpear a enemigos voladores desde la distancia con una pistola o un shuriken gigante, aunque ciertamente no son muy eficaces. Podremos también agarrar a algunos enemigos y realizar ejecuciones finales bastante explícitas cuando éstos se encuentran debilitados. También Guerra posee una barra de furia que iremos ampliando, gracias a la que podremos ejecutar algunas habilidades potentes como mejorar nuestra defensa o un ataque de gran alcance.

Los jefes finales son un elemento a destacar, con un diseño chulísimo todos ellos, muy diferentes entre sí, y bastante complejos en general para derrotar. Habrá que seguir una estrategia diferente (o varias) para cada uno de ellos, normalmente implicando elementos del escenario para usar a nuestro favor. Así, los enemigos básicos no poseen siempre un diseño tan trabajado ni tienen este toque táctico particular para derrotarlos con alguna pequeña excepción, pero sí es cierto que hay un buen puñado de diferentes tipos de ellos.

El diseño de niveles es muy creativo, además de captar la atención del jugador con una ambientación muy cuidada. Aún dada la gran diversidad que hay entre los escenarios, el juego exhibe una gran cohesión en su estilo, dotándolo de una gran personalidad artística, aunque recuerda mucho a la imaginería del mundo de World of Warcraft. Se encuentran ciertos altibajos en este apartado, ya que a pesar de que la mayoría de niveles son bastante imaginativos, hay algunos bastante sosos y vacíos, con pocos elementos y que resultan genéricos. Es importante destacar que la mayoría de escenarios se sienten vivos, con muchos elementos dinámicos y rompibles, por lo que la sensación de decorados de cartón-piedra no tiene lugar en este juego, como sí ocurría en el similar Castlevania Lords of the Shadows.

Tanto en el diseño gráfico como el sonoro, así como la historia, se percibe un gran tono oscuro. El juego es bastante maduro y ofrece escenarios desolados, con una paleta de colores apagados y una música sombría.  La historia que se nos cuenta es bastante elaborada, con unos personajes muy cuidados y bien representados, incluso los jefes a los que nos enfrentaremos tienen su propia personalidad, ejerciendo de personajes secundarios. Hay muchas escenas de vídeo donde transcurre la historia con más o menos interés, aunque tampoco el guión se desmarca ni puede sacar pecho, sí que funciona bien a la hora de presentar nuevos personajes y escenarios.

La BSO es notable, así como los efectos de sonido, aunque en ocasiones éstos no están lo suficientemente cuidados y se escucha cierto ruido general, sobre todo en secciones de combates. También hay algún problema con la sincronización de vídeo y sonido en las escenas cinemáticas que empobrece el resultado.

8'2

If you're a fan of games like The Legend of Zelda, Soul Reaver or Devil May Cry you may love the Darksiders series! You ask me why? Because it's the perfect mix of #1 Dungeons #2 Hack&Slay #3 Puzzle #4 Mythology (Story)

The gameplay ist just like a mixture of the 3 games I talked before. You're one of the 4 Horseman but because of a big betray you've lost all of your power and have to gain it again! Kill demons and other monsters to gain souls, upgrade your weapons while using it, buy new upgrades and abilitys, solve puzzles in huge and interesting dungeons like in the Zelda-Series, defeat different bosses with different strategies and claim your reward!
Play through an epic story of angels, devils and the mythology about the 4 horseman and the apocalypse.

Play it, it's an underestimated masterpiece!

40242231.review:
When it comes to hack-and-slash games, there's usually a huge focus on the combat since that's where the complexity of the game really shine. From games like Devil May Cry to even God of War, combat has always been a prime focus on their respective games, and the same can be said for a lot of hack-and-slash games out there. However in a game like Darksiders, it does something pretty rare that you don't see in a lot of games in its genre, and that's combining the hack-and-slash combat to a more puzzle/exploration driven game like you'd see in the Legend of Zelda series.

First off lets focus on the gameplay. in terms of the combat-side of the gameplay, it's your typical hack-and-slash affair, with your weapons doing different comboes based on the button input, upgrading them as you use them overtime, and buying new comboes to add to your arsenal, however that's where the combat goes as it's a bit bare bones. While you do get to buy new comboes for more choice, it doesn't really add much depth considering a lot of the attacks don't mesh well with each other. Regardless if you're in a middle of a combo with your Chaoseater (the primary weapon of the game) there's nothing new you can do when you switch to your scythe or gauntlets, the latter being the most underdeveloped in the game (unless you count the tools then Strife's gun takes the cake.) While this may be a turn off for plenty of hack-and-slash fans, I'd argue that it makes up for it with it's other side of the gameplay: the exploration and the puzzles. Now if you've ever played a Legend of Zelda game, you will find your familiar bells and whistles. You have a bunch of tools (some of them can be used for combat) to traverse the land you roam. The tools being the key to help you solve the puzzles in their respective dungeons, fighting a boss in the end that's weak to the tool that you gained in said dungeon, and increasing your health cap when the boss is finished, or you can stray away from the destination to find some chests that give you some items or collectibles that may aid you in your journey. Now considering the exploration based gameplay integrated here, some people may be turned off by the fact that you have to backtrack all over the world to find some collectibles that you missed, but it's not that annoying due to the shopkeeper being a fast travel area for you once you find more than one of his spots. When you look at it on paper, it seems like a weird concept, but it does pay off, even though there were some setbacks (the combat being an example).

In terms of graphics and Artstyle, the game looks pretty good for it's time. Nothing majorly fantastic like say Metroid Prime 3 or the Arkham games, but the game does hold up, and the artstyle really looks good. It does give off the vibe that you're in a post-apocalyptic earth while having some diverse areas that make a lot of the places stand out from each other, and more easier to remember them by. Some of the monsters in the game look pretty cool, from the big brute demons, to the bosses, to even the high tech gear that the angels in the game contrast with each other pretty well. One thing I cannot for the life of me take seriously is the design for War, the main protagonist of the game. His design is so needlessly complex to the point that he looks like he's trying way to hard to be dark and edgy for the sake of it.

Both the music and the story are easily the weakest aspects of the game, with the former being pretty non-existant majority of the game, and the latter being a story about a horseman of the apocalypse trying to prove his innocent by finding the man responsible for bringing armagheddon, and that's pretty much it. 

So if you're a fan of hack-and-slash games, and wants to try out something new, or if you are a Legend of Zelda fan and want to try out a non-TLOZ game,  I'd recommend this. If you're neither of those fans, then I'd hesitate to recommend this since it's more of it's own experimental thing (which it does fine, don't get me wrong) rather than a game that shows what hack-and-slash or puzzle/exploration based games are all about.

39165446.review:
Estamos ante un titulo antiguo (23 sep 2.010) y el cual tiene una versión remasterizada con mejoras visuales.


 http://store.steampowered.com/app/462780/Darksiders_Warmastered_Edition/


[h1] HISTORIA	[/h1]

En este titulo nos narran la historia de uno de los cuatro jinetes del apocalipsis, GUERRA, el cual debe afrontar una ardua aventura tras ser engañado y acusado de desatar el apocalipsis en la tierra, siento este la guerra entre los ángeles y demonios, cielo e infierno.

[h1] JUGABILIDAD	[/h1]

Los controles son sencillos, a casi todo lo que veas deberás matarlo o al menos herirlo. Tendrás armas desde la devoracaos, tu espada, pasando por misericordia, una pistola, hasta crossblade, un shuriken, war scythe, su guadaña o incluso la espada del armageddon. También podremos cabalgar sobre Ruina, el caballo de guerra y usar la ira de guerra para transformarnos en un monstruo apocalíptico.

Recomiendo jugarlo con un control, pero también se puede con teclado y ratón.


[h1] PROS Y CONTRAS	[/h1]

[h1] PROS	[/h1]
[list]
    [*]+ Logros y coleccionables, a mi me encantan.
    [*]+ Música: Tiene varias soundtracks muy buenas.
    [*]+ Duración: El juego en si apenas dura 10-15 horas, recomiendo jugarlo en modo apocalíptico e intentar conseguir todos los logros, así alargaremos la vida de este juego. (ver CONTRAS)
    [*]+ Controles: Los controles son sencillos, a medida que avanza el juego nos irán dando mas mejoras y cosas, pero se va aprendiendo gradualmente.
[/list]


[h1] CONTRAS	[/h1]
[list]
    [*]- Se puede hacer muy repetitivo en algunas ocasiones.
    [*]- Gráficos: Al ser un juego antiguo, los gráficos no han pasado bien con los años.
    [*]- Dificultad: Si comenzamos en la máxima dificultad sufriremos al comienzo.
[/list]


[h1] CONCLUSION: Juego 9/10, muy recomendado para 1 jugador.	[/h1]

39087838.review:
Antes de alarmarse por el "No Recomendado" que le he soltado, dejad que me explique.

God Of War ha sido una de mis sagas favoritas desde hace bastante tiempo, por lo que anduve buscando juegos del estilo para ver qué tenían que ofrecer. Comencé pasandome aquel reboot de Devil May Cry (y algunos fans se me echarán al cuello por empezar por ese y no por los de PS2). El caso es que me dejó muy buen sabor de boca. Poco después me compré Darksiders.

¿CUÁL ES MI PROBLEMA CON DARKSIDERS?

Mi problema con Darksiders es, de forma muy breve, que me cansa jugarlo.
Pero ésto no lo digo porque me dé la gana o por aquello de "es mi opinión y mi exeperiencia subjetiva bla bla bla", sino que tengo una serie de críticas que hacerle al juego las cuales (creo yo) son las razones por las que me ha resultado tedioso y hasta agotador pasármelo.

PROBLEMA 1, LA CÁMARA: Mi problema con la cámara de Darksiders seguramente sea mi problema más subjetivo de todos los que diré a continuación. La cámara está cerca de nuestro personaje, lo cual te obliga a moverla bastante para mirar a tu alrededor, fijarte en los escenarios, buscar objetos escondidos... Si esto lo combinas con que su velocidad de movimiento es relativamente lenta y que en cuanto nos ponemos a andar la cámara vuelve a fijarse mirando al frente (sin mucha visión periférica); nos queda que, o bien me paso todo el juego peleándome con la cámara cada vez que quiero observar el mundo que me rodea, o bien me canso de luchar y me limito a mirar al frente e ir directo al lugar de la misión.

PROBLEMA 2, EL DETALLE: En todo el recorrido del juego no recuerdo ni unas vistas espectaculares, pequeños momentos que me hayan llamado la atención ni ningún decorado hecho con especial cariño. Simplemente recuerdo más o menos el mismo tipo de texturas de ruinas en todos lados y unos JPG ahí plantados como fondos de escenario. Si antes me quejaba de que agotaba mover la cámara para explorar y fijarme en los detalles, mejor aún cuando te das cuenta de que no hay detalles en los que fijarte y de que los escenarios están hechos casi a granel.

PROBLEMA 3, LOS PUZZLES: ¿Por qué profundizar en 2 o 3 objetos especiales para resolver algunos puzzles cuando puedes meter 7 u 8 para usarlos de la misma manera todo el juego? El recopilatorio es impresionante: El gancho, la pistola de portales, el puño que rompe cosas, una máscara que usas una sola vez en el juego... Todas estas mecánicas apenas avanzan o progresan y siguen usandose prácticamente igual desde que los consigues, terminando por ser tediosas y repetitivas.

Aún así, el sistema de combate es divertido de jugar y la historia (aunque no me haya enterado al 100% en mi primera partida) promete de cara a posteriores títulos, por lo que voy a ir poniendo la mano sobre Darksiders 2 y ver así si arregló los errores de su predecesor.

Que decir de este juego, definitivamente una joya subvalorada en cualquier plataforma de videojuegos, pc, Xbox 360, ps3, etc. En fin el juego es una belleza, en mi opinión es el primer juego que me ha generado tanto hype y la verdad no me decepcionó, el apartado gráfico está bien, no es el mejor pero para el 2009 considero que esta bien, en cierto punto de la historia se vuelve muy adictivo matar y matar demonios, ángeles, zombies, monstruos, etc tanto asi que no quieres dejar la partida en el último punto de guardado si no continuar y continuar hasta acabarlo pero a no ser que seas un enfermo lo lograras debido a que es un juego medianamente extenso. Su historia esta muy buena, aunque siempre deja uno que otro hueco que supongo se complementara con los siguientes juegos de la saga, el tema de los objetos y sus funciones es fenomenal, todos tienen un papel importante para el desarrollo de la historia, los personajes están bien para mi gusto aunque algunas veces logra fastidiar un poco la personalidad toda badass del protagonista (Guerra) pero de resto esta genial. Finalizando, el juego lo disfruté muchísimo aunque no puedo terminar este análisis sin resaltar o hacer nombre a factores negativos. Lamentablemente y muy pero muy lamentablemente la banda sonora no es relevante y se nota mucho su ausencia, en el transcurso del juego logré encontrar aproximadamente 3 bugs que fastidiaron un poco pero solo aparecieron en una pequeña parte de alguna de las múltiples zonas, aunque también hay uno supermolesto con los logros de Steam, no los marco y ya lo acabé. También me hubiera gustado que la historia fuera más profunda porque ofrece un buen material, pero solo es esperar lo que nos ofrecen los siguientes DarkSiders.

En conclusión a Darksiders lo puntúo 7.5 / 10, aunque es uno de mis juegos favoritos creo que es la apreciación justa debido a que le hace falta un poco más aunque es justificable para un juego del 2009, lo recomiendo al 100% para todo tipo de personas en general, no se arrepentirán de hacer esta compra y sobre todo si aprovechan el Darksiders Franchise Pack en ofertas, es muy económico y es una buena inversión.

P.D. No se guíen de los análisis negativos porque la mayoría de estos habla de problemas de optimización, supongo que es por la GPU que tienen, a mi me ando perfectamente.

36876058.review:
Darksiders is a pretty solid hack and slash game. Set in an apocalyptic Earth, after the "End War" between Heaven and Hell has started, you play as War, one of the four Horsemen of the Apocalypse. The story starts with War being sent to Earth during the Apocalypse, only to be accused of causing it himself; he must then embark on a quest to clear his name, by finding those responsible.

The gameplay is pretty solid; I've seen it mentioned as a mix of God of War and Legend of Zelda; while I'm not familiar with Zelda games, I can see the similarities to God of War, which I've played. The combat is great, there's three different weapons, plus several enhancements that you can equip your weapons with. There's also exploration and puzzle-solving, which make a good portion of the gameplay, and it's very well implemented. And that's without mentioning the collectibles, as there's lots of them, going from the already mentioned enhancements, to special items that grant you souls (which work as currency).

The story is excellent. While it draws inspiration from the biblical tales of the Apocalypse, having four horsemen and all, it still has its own spin to it. A creator is mentioned in passing, but has no real relevance to the story; War works for the "Charred Council", which seeks to maintain a balance between the forces of Heaven and Hell, and each of those factions has its own leader. The soundtrack is another solid point for this game, with some pretty good tracks.

Well, I think that's all I have to say about Darksiders. It's a pretty good game, so I recommend it.

36195739.review:
[h1]A Zelda-ish demon-slashing end-of-the-world party[/h1]

You are War, one of the four Horseman of the Apocalypse whose job is to wipe out everyone when the end comes. However, someone have started the apocalypse before its time, and War takes the blame; so he sets out to find the one who did.
The game progresses in a Zelda-like manner: open-world; there are areas which you cannot access because you don't have the proper items, so you have to get back to previously visited areas to find all the goodies. In the dungeons you find these items, and you'll have to use them on the boss of that area.
The story is unraveled slowly, with nice characters. The fighting mechanics are good.
Get it if you like hack and slash, or Zelda-like games.

[b]Prons[/b]
[list]
[*]Nice story, with its mysteries being solved slowly, keeping you hooked
[*]Fantastic lore
[*]Great voice acting
[*]Figthing mechanics
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]You're gonna have to wait a long time for all of the sequences to lauch and the main story to end, if it ever will
[/list]

33692448.review:
Let me start off by saying I'm not a fan of open-world games, and nor am I a fan of God of War's hack 'n slash genre. But this game finds a perfect balance between those two. I really enjoy 'limited' open-world games, such as The Witcher 2, where you get a big hub to explore, but it is still possible to explore the entire map without sinking hundreds of hours into it.  I didn't enjoy The Witcher 3 or games like Skyrim. 

First, let me explain how the game works exactly without spoiling. You play as War, one of the Four Horsemen, and you've basically been summoned to save the world from demons. Killing enemies and finding certain chests reward you with Souls. Souls can be spent on Life Essence (Health Potions), Rage Essence (which fills you with Rage, allowing you to use a super-ability, there's like 5 you can choose from) and permanent life increases, ability upgrades, new attacks,...
The game is semi-open-world, meaning you get to reasonably big hubs across the world and get to explore them one by one, much like the first two Witcher games.

So what exactly makes this game good? Well, here's a list of pro's & cons that came off the top of my head.

Pro's:
-Visually fine, it's clearly outdated but it doesn't look like complete rubbish and is still appealing
-Entertaining combat
-Travelling: Running across the world with your horse can be entertaining, but also boring. There's 'serpent holes' in the game, which is pretty much just a quick travel feature, making it easy to go to objectives around the map.
-Parcour: The parcour in this game is quite smooth and entertaining. Just climbing walls, but also using your grappling hook, portals,... is fun.
-Puzzles are fun!

Cons:
-Repetitiveness and drawn out: At the start it's not much of a problem, but towards the end, when you've unlocked all skills, the combat does get a bit stale. The last 6 hours or so are all with the same skill set, and unless I'm terrible wrong, you always perform the same, optimal combo. The surroundings and opponents cause for the same issue. There's a lot of gray and sand/dust around the world, with the exception of a small jungle and a few bits of snow. The story felt drawn out towards the end, when I thought I was near the ending, I had to do another few long quests that felt a bit unnecessary. I should add that I played through this entire game like 8-10 hours a day, but when I got to the end I got stuck and quit the game for a good month because it started feeling repetitive.
-Serpent holes: though the quick travel is fun, for some reason you always have to run and jump across this weird path in some kind of space environment whenever you want to quick travel, and it felt really boring after a while.

If you have any questions, feel free to ask!
