33456252.review:
[u][b]This review is done all by memory since I’ve haven't played it since I beat it; which I believe was a few years ago now. So please take this review with some heavy salt, I liked this game & I may not remember all the flaws this game had/has instead remembering all the good.[/b][/u]

I bought [b]Darksiders[/b] on December 1, 2013, for [i]$3.99[/i] US dollars on the Winter sale 2013 & I played a total of [i]40 hours[/i]. I’ve aslo got the [b]Darksiders Warmastered Edition[/b], for free since I owned the original game, but this review is for [b]Darksiders[/b] the non-warmastered edtion.

[b]Darksiders[/b] is a [i]3D, Single-player, 3rd Person, Hack & Slash, Plat-former, Puzzle, Action, Adventure Game[/i] with [i]Zelda-isk/God Of War[/i] (& Other Games too*) elements.

This game is best played with a Game-Pad, Yes I did play this game with a Game-Pad, & the Achievements are broken in this title. If you alt-tab &/or ctrl-alt-deleted out of the game, then you may not get the Achievements; this is a known & old bug from this game! I’ve beat the game and many of the Achievements you get for killing of the bosses I did not get due to that reason.

This game is a simple one at it’s core. You play as one of the Horsemen of the Apocalypse; [b]War[/b]. As [b]War[/b], you smack things with your Giant As **** Sword till they die a Bloody & Gory Deaths; you need to dodge too though. You do get some side weapons, but Sword is here to stay; same with armor. If/when you upgraded your sword, if you can call it that, you can’t switch out the sword; same goes for the “armor” if you found it that is, you where stuck with it.
The combat is fun but they tied the Dodge button with the block, if I remember right. Blocking was all but forgot by me, since I dodge and never used Block if at all. Though if I did block, I had a hard time doing so due to the Dodge & Block buttons where bound. Some executions can get old pretty quick, but the combat still holds up threw out the game.
The Bosses are not INSANELY hard, though seeing them die is fun to watch. War likes to be all that dude who is all ****** and at.
The platforming was okay, but it could be nightmare to get around since some levels are Mazes. Since there was a lot of back tracking, the map does help if you can find it in the level, but no one likes back tracking; even more so if you hunt the chests in the game...
The story though is rather interesting one. [b]War[/b] is quiet but angry fellow, he doesn’t talk that much but he loves to kill stuff though. His “[i]companion[/i]” is called the “[i]Watcher[/i]”, his character is interesting but in-game he is useless to the player & he is [i]Navi[/i] reincarnated in this world; and yes I do mean he is [i]Navi[/i] reincarnated, yes I did like [i]Navi[/i] has much as the next person, but good lord was she annouying. I can’t go into too much detail on the story since this is the focus of the whole Game; it is a Single-Player Adventure title after all. However, the story is very dark, gritty & depressing one. And most of the character within game are rather interesting to say the least.
Graphic wise this game was pretty, but it’s dated nowadays; then again this is a 7+ year old game. This game did come out in 2010!

Conclusion. I recommend this game. However, this game is for those who like Hack & Slash, though don’t expect it to be HARD; well at least it shouldn’t be for veterans of Hack & Slash games. Also, I played it on normal and not on Apocalyptic difficulty; so take that into account. Not everyone is going to like it, but I like a good Dark, Gritty & Gloomy story and a ****** Hero in games. This game does have both.
This game is [i]$19.99[/i] US dollars and you are getting TWO games with that as well; though you do get [b]Darksiders[/b] (original) & the [b]Darksiders Warmastered Edition[/b]. (It a remaster.) But if you don’t want to spend that much wait for a sale, you can get it for very cheap these days.

[i]* Regrettably, I’ve only played Zelda games. I’ve never played God of War Games & other that this game borrow from; or from what I’ve read another people compare this game too. Ya I know, laugh at this poor fool.[/i]

33400357.review:
This game is a major surprise package, and may well fare better than some of the more illustrious titles and deservedly so. It may lack a certain level of polish, but for the sheer fun you will be hard pressed to do much better, as the combat and puzzles are spot on and hark back to the classic Zelda games. The story does let things down a bit and the graphics are ragged in places, but as a slice of entertainment, this does a damn fine job.

+ Playability - Bags of fun, and with just enough action and puzzles to make this feel like the classic Zelda games of old. Things never get repetitive either tanks to the paced introduction of new items and abilities.
+ Delivery - A top notch action game that only really falls down due to some rough edges and the fact it is far too easy. Still you will be transfixed while it lasts.

- Audio - A little over-the-top voice-acting and the music is only so-so and kind of gets lost in the midst of al the action.
- Visuals - Decent, but hardly stellar. There are some clipping and screen tearing issues at times too which is hardly ideal.

32289750.review:
I have finished the game. some of my achievements have not registered properly. But I did. 

Small semi disjointed plot summary:

The armies of heaven and hell wage an endless war. This war was stopped by the charred council and its enforcers, the four horsemen. Eventually a third race, that of man was discovered. Man became the peace timer, for once these weak yet cunning creatures were ready to take their place in the grand scheme of things, the seven seals would be broken, the war would resume and four horsemen would rain judgement down on all three sides.

Safe to say, shit hits the fan like a riding horsemen. You play as War, supposedly the strongest horsemen (measured purely in physical strength) and go down to earth do your job, only to notice your fellow horsemen haven't been summoned as well. And the shit keeps snowballing down hill.

Let's start off with the good:

The combat (the thing you shall be doing for most of this game) feels amazing, when you hit something, you feel like 
you've really hit something.

Combos feel nice.

There is decent variety in weapons and combos. (despite the fact I only used one of these weapons in real combat.)

Characters were overal pretty good. Though there are very few side characters, they do all serve a purpose.


Next up the mediocre:

The puzzles are meh, the real problem with them is that you are given no real hints, the best you get is a panning shot that hints vaguely in the general direction of the answer. 

The boss fights aren't all that interesting, doing the whole "do it three times and it dies" thing for the most part. Though there are the "bash it ti'll it's dead" bosses. It was hard to distinguish between those and a health bar for therm would have been nice. 

Enemy variety is a bit lacking. (I do not consider a colour change and some more health and damage as "variety.")

The story isn't all that amazing either, but it's servicable and works for the most part.

None of these things were a deal breaker for me.


The bad:

The game (at least for me) handled alt tabbing badly, to the point of crashing when I did, on occasion, alt tab. (my guess is that this was the reason some of my achievements didn't get counted.)


I do recommend this game though, it's not perfect, but nothing is and if you can live with the flaws it has, it's a good game.

32007424.review:
*******IF YOU ARE HAVING ISSUES WITH THE ACHIEVEMENTS ON THIS GAME NOT UNLOCKING, READ AT THE END OF THE REVIEW*******

What a marvelous game this was. Everyone kept talking to me about it back then but I simply thought  it was another repetitive hack and slash game. Turns out it is not. It is a very well done combination between The Legend of Zelda and Devil May Cry with RPG elements to it.

Gameplay is fluent and surprisingly addictive while it maintains it's action packed sections and also with puzzle solving in dungeons. There is not much place to get lost, and it is "kinda" linear, now, you can still backtrack and get items you couldn't get before, like places you cannot reach without an specific item, very much like Metroid in a sense. Music is outstanding and also the voice acting, included Mark Hamill himself.

Graphics are well done for a game of it's era, so no dissapointment there. Just stay away from the Warmastered Edition which has a lot of bugs.

9/10

******ACHIEVEMENTS NOT UNLOCKING?******

Turns out the main game it's "glitched" so follow these steps so you can have them unlocked Legit:

1) Make sure Darksiders is the FIRST game you load from Steam. If you played another one before, exit out of Steam, log back in, and launch the game.

2) While in game, NEVER use Steam overlay, you're better off disabling it for it.

3) NEVER ALT TAB out of the game.

If you follow these 3 steps, your achievements will unlock properly when you get them.

31936741.review:
God of War meets Legend of Zelda. Definitely a must for the hack-and-slash crowd. 

This game plays like a harder version of Legend of Zelda, and a slightly easier version of Dark Souls with perhaps more satisfying combat. The setting makes the world a post-apocalyptic hellscape, though more visually interesting and varied than, say, Fallout 3.

 The story, though an exercise in pure demon killing-action shlock, is engaging enough, you play the disgraced horseman of war, blamed for starting the apocalypse and you are charged with slaughtering your way through hordes of demons and angels to redeem your good name. There is an satisfying variety of weapons/equipment and number of combos leading to a cathartic, meaty combat system. I should note that the writing of the main character makes him inhuman, apathetic, and brooding so as to make him nearly unsympathetic, but the game's aesthetic and combat more than make up for the shortcomings in story, which play out like a passable Warcraft fan fiction.

 My version featured a number of glitches and crashes, but nothing that broke the game, but did stop me from being able to equip the unlockable top tier armor. For this reason, consider the Warmastered edition, which is more expensive but less buggy.

31922483.review:
Darksiders is a really good game, especially if you are into action RPG's along the line of Legend of Zelda and God of War.
Darksiders gameplay is mainly just slashing your way through enemies, with the different weapons and attacks you obtain through the game. Using the different weapons and attacks you can string neat combo's together to work the enemies HP low enough to execute them. You can dodge, block and counter incoming attacks, but that's really all there is to it. The combo system and variety of weapons and attacks is enough to keep the battles fun and engaging.

Other then just fighting, you will be spending quite some time solving puzzles through the game's different dungeons. Using the tools you obtain in them, you really need to think about your possibilities within every puzzle. The puzzles are all well put together, but can be a little repetitive at times.

Which brings mw to my main complaint about this game, the repetitiveness.
The puzzles have enough variety to them, to stay fun, but I can't say that about the variety in enemies.
The game has this really bad habit of using old enemies you already fought quite oftenly in earlier zones (and are probably already sick of), give them a flashy new color, make them do more damage and make them have more health. Because of this I only actually remember encoutering new enemies in the last couple dungeons like, 5 times. And when it does not reskin enemies, it simply takes a tough enemy you fought earlier and then makes you fight two at a time to make it 'more challenging'. This seems really cheap to do and just kind of makes you go "Oh come on now" a lot more then is necessary. This is not at all a major problem, it was just a complaint I felt needed to be adressed.

Verdict:
So this review is waay to long already, so imma just get to the point.
Darksiders is a really good game, and I had a lot of fun with it. It seems to be suffering of déjà vu every now and then, but that is never a big problem to me. I recommend this game to anyone why likes the Legend of Zelda or God of War games.

7/10

31813997.review:
Darksiders es un juego que mezcla puzzles y acción, con un estilo similar a la saga Zelda. 
Mazmorras que te dan objetos para alcanzar nuevas zonas, trozos de mejoras para aumentar tu vida y tu ira (magia), etc. La mayor diferencia es que el combate es mucho más machacabotones (más hack&slash, puedes pasarte el juego simplemente dando a un botón prácticamente).

Historia: es interesante, con varios personajes algo arquetípicos pero bien narrados, y coherente. No es una maravilla en cuanto a originalidad, pero sí el contexto, que nos presenta un mundo desolado en el que el humano ha desaparecido, y sin embargo no le importa a nadie.

Controles: en general son sencillos. El combate permite hacer diferentes combos que te ayudan a acabar antes, pero no son necesarios en general. Con pulsar el botón de ataque sobra en casi todos los combates. El uso de objetos sí tiene, en cambio, algunos fallos, sobre todo en cuestión de manejo de la cámara. Nada muy molesto, pero podría estar más pulido.

Gráficos: si bien es un juego no muy bien optimizado, el diseño me parece una maravilla. Unos dibujos que no buscan en absoluto realismo, sino más bien un toque comiquero, con diseños cuidados que hacen de cada personaje único. Colores muy bien elegidos, y escenarios bien diseñados. Por buscar un pero en cuanto al diseño, algunos enemigos están demasiado repetidos, y el diseño de las llaves parece un poco absurdo. EL JUEGO PRÁCTICAMENTE NO TE DEJA MODIFICAR OPCIONES, así que si no tienes un PC muy potente, cuidado...

Sonido: no es memorable, pero cumple su función.

CONCLUSIÓN: Si te gustan los juegos con puzzles, este es para ti. Si no, quizá también, ya que el estilo de combate lo hace ameno en las partes que no son puzzle. Es un juego completo, con una duración correcta.

31404867.review:
I wanted to like this game. It looked really cool, and the story was great. Kill animations are seamless and look awesome, the voice acting is great, and War is a great character. The music was good, the collectibles were cool to try and find, and each level/area looks great. 

However, the gameplay itself kills it for me. Combat is more or less mashing the same button over and over. You can change timing and directions to execute different moves and you can switch weapons, but each different weapon feels like pretty much the same thing. Building up combos and introducing move variety has no tangible benefits, at least not from what I saw. It started out interesting and I was always entertained watching kill animations and stuff, but by about 2/3 of the way through the game I realized I just wasn't enjoying combat anymore, and hadn't been for a while. I just wanted to finish the game for the sake of completion, not because I was having fun.

Part of that is from the puzzles. The puzzles are pretty easy to figure out, but a real pain in the ass to actually execute. You can almost immediately see what has to be done at any given point, but actually doing it can require a lot of tedious running around and platforming. 

Boss fights, as well, are really hit or miss. Some of them were really cool, but others were just an excuse to force you to use some new ability you just got, and just went on for way too long without adding any new attack patterns or anything to keep the fight interesting.

On the whole, Darksiders looks like a really good game, and it's enjoyable for the first half or so. If you like hack n' slash and don't mind button mashing you'd definitely like this game. However, going to this game from Devil May Cry just left me wanting more out of the combat in Darksiders. No amount of great animations can make up to me the lack of variety in moves and weapons. This game is also hurt by the fact that building combos is much harder than in other hack n' slash titles, and without any of the benefits of using stylish combos or move variety. Darksiders does a lot of things well, but I can't rate it favorably due to the issues expounded upon above.

30270703.review:
Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a third person action game.


[h1]Interface/Menu/Settings[/h1]

There is a volume slidebar available for Music, Sound, Voice and video.
There is an Aim sensitivity for X and Y.
You are able to change the controls on the keyboard.
You are able to toggle the subtitles or game tips.
There are some resolution sizes available.
There is a difficulty settings available.
You are able to play on a xbox controller.
YOU ARE NOT ABLE TO CHANGE THE CONTROLS ON THE CONTROLLER.
There is Vibration. :D

[h1]About the game.[/h1]

There is a war going on between heaven and hell and you will be playing as WAR, one of the four horsemens of the apocalypse. After a fight with a boss demon, You will be sent to hell to get punished. Instead of getting punished, you will have to slay enemies and capture their souls as a tribute. The Camera is third person but you are able to switch to focus mode for better combat control. Some say it's like "legend of zelda", which is partly true as some of the things are the same. Grabbing a weak unit will most likely kill it instantly, providing alot of health. During the grab execution you can't be killed. But you will get less souls. You can trade souls for upgrades and unlocking new power. Enemies are able to hurt another or even kill them, which will give you an easier time finishing them.

Really great soundtrack.
There are collectables. :'(
The game could be pretty grindy.
Game gives you tips if turned on.
There are lifeshards, Like in legend of zelda. Collecting 4 of them will grant you an extra life.
During an enemy execution you will not receive any damage in the progress.
Brutal executions :D
Enemies are able to hurt or even kill others.
You can manually save and load your game.
There is a minimap at the bottom right corner.
You can ask for a reminder if you forget what you have to do.

[h1]Other things.[/h1]

You might want to change some controls or control position as some of them aren't in a great spot for a quick reach.
Quitting the game without saving. Will still lose your progress. As quitting the game will NOT AUTOMATICALLY SAVE FOR YOU! You have to do it MANUALLY!

-------------------

I Give this game a 8/10

29417080.review:
First of I played this in 1080p on a keyboard and on Easy. I wanted to finish it quickly so i can move onto other games.

I have put in a few hours and have reached near the end of the game and i'm not going to be finishing it. 
This game has such great potential to be an excellent game but it suffers from huge design flaws. I was really looking forward to enjoying this game and wanted it to be a good game, but its not, small annoyances riddled throughout this game build up and render it unplayable towards the end. One of the biggest downsides is the "Trap Rooms" which seem to be every second room each one having a 2-5 waves of enemies in them, which is completely unnecessary and don't add any reward for the player once completed, not even a small amount of health. The Health is very sparse only coming in one use only chests and is not drop by common enemies. The only enemies that drop health are smaller "Action Kill" enemies, one of which only spawn in the overworld/hubworld. The others being bats and birds which again are Action Kill enemies which if you kill normally give you a reduced amount of health, the normal amount is quite small. 
The Story i feel isn't as important as what this game is about, Killing things and making you feel quite the baddass while doing so. It loosely revolves around you redeeming your reputation as a Horseman by doing things for Demons.
Dungeon Design is reminiscent of The Legend of Zelda, so i will loosely compare to that. The dungeons have the normal elements of Fire, Water and Earth along with a Heaven and a Hell, I haven't seen a Hell Dungeon in a Zelda game yet but a Heaven/Sky one though. (I only got upto the Heaven part but i'm guessing you get to hell from where the game was heading) The Dungeon puzzels are quite easy to figure out although not every well explained from the entering fly though. If you were to play a board game you would read the instruction on how to play, the fly though at the start is the instructions for the player if they are not clear then the puzzle needs to be rethought. The Puzzles are often just throwing your boomerang though fire light a bomb, pushing blocks into place or hitting a switch to move some platforms to jump on. I should also mention that there will be instances were you get stuck and fall though the world, happened to me about 4-5 times causing me to reload a save file.
As mentioned before the biggest problem with the game are Trap Rooms in what seems like every room. They have no variety or strategy to them, the same 2-5 monsters come in 2-5 waves per room. The smaller monsters all have the same predictable attacks which are easy to dodge and finish off with an Action Kill. Some of the larger Monsters, not all, are the problem. Their attacking rage is greater than your dodging range so you have no choice but to soak the damage and continue slashing your sword on them until you kill them. After each Trap Room in a game like Zelda you would expect that classic tune to play and you unlock a chest with some loot in it. In Darksiders Trap Rooms you get nothing, no reward no health absolutely nothing, so what is the point of having a Trap Room there? Why are you trapping me in there, there is nothing of value, there is no chest of gold or health (which is the same as gold in Darksiders), its just a hallway with literally nothing in there. This is one of the best examples of the awful design. If you find yourself with little health and your unable to beat the next Trap Room, then congratulations your stuck and cannot progress until you get more health (more of this later) When you reach the end of a dungeon your faced with a "Boss". 
The Boss fights are boring, easier than the dungeon itself and a good few don't include the item that you got whilst progressing though the dungeon. If your going to make a dungeon based game, make sure that the Bosses inside each dungeon use the item they hid away because its their weakness. You use it against them to defeat them, not just wack 'em with a sword a few times and they they say 'f**k it, you win'. That means any old person with a sword can do it make the player feel special and as if he/she was the only person who could have done it and not Divorced Doug with the failing lawn mowing business from across the road (no offence to any doug's). After you have "defeated" each boss you go back to the same guy and he says go to this place and kill this Monster, you get the point you've played Zelda before. You go though another repetitive dungeon, solve a few puzzles, kill the "boss" and head back. 
While you are exploring the dungeons you might end up doing some platforming, if fact you will. The platforming is nothing special just your standard Jumping, Climbing, Swimming, Sliding and Grabbing. The game does a somewhat nice job of this each dungeon is varied but it still similar to the last in terms of enemies. When preforming said platforming acts sometimes, not all the time, your button presses are unresponsive and you will fall to your death. Which brings me to my next point, Life and Death.
Death is a good thing in this game. If you die, you will spawn with more health then you started with. Some Monsters will do up to 2 whole health bars/skulls in one attack on easy. Health comes from smaller enemies like zombies, bats, birds and spiders, killing them will give you a small amount of health. You can also get health from one use only treasure chests, which don't completely fill your health bars/skulls. because of the shear lack of health in the game you will find yourself stuck in numerous locations, usually before an unnecessary Trap Room. If your in a situation where your on your last bit of health, find a cliff and jump off it your better off, really your are, you will respawn with 3 and a half bars ready to fight again. 
The Art style for this game is great. I love it. Its reminds me of Warhammer 40k crossed with World of Warcraft crossed with Gothic Architecture. Its just a shame it was wasted on a game like this.
The PC Port for this game is better than most, the controls are okay, not the best but okay. The frame rate is great sitting on 60+ FPS. What bugs me is the lack of options for graphics, there is none. Just select your Resolution and if you want VSync then apply. You can't select Texture detail, Anti Aliasing or Model Detail. I have a low end system so i was pretty happy to be getting 60+ FPS in this game. Key mapping works good, the only problem i have is that Num Enter should be normal enter as well, i just like it like that so i don't have to move my hand off the mouse. I know i'm lazy. 

In conclusion this game has its fun parts, but its mostly bad. The design of everything is bad, the story is forgettable and unengaging to say the least. What the games tries to do it fails in and it doesn't fail in the bad design will make you put the game down and never play it again. The best part about the game is the Art its everything i like Dark, Gothic and gritty, It really does complement the game but not so much im going to start playing it again. If you already own the game just avoid it and if you want to play it look up a Lets Play on youtube its not worth your time, just play a Zelda game again i would suggest Twilight Princess as its the closest to a game like this. (I didn't proof read this so it might be unintelligible nonsense, i wanted to go to bed.) Thanks for reading.

TL;DR - 3/10 Good Art style wasted on a game that is badly designed.

Want to hack and slash some stuff?
-Go play through the Devil May Cry games again.
Want to solve puzzles creatively?
-Go play some Sudoku with crayons.
Want to enjoy a good story?
-Go read a book.
Genuinely curious about the story of Darksiders?
-That's what Let's Plays are for.
Want to slowly learn to hate yourself?
-Spend your hard earned cash on this game. :)

28729544.review:
[url=http://www.shdownloads.com.ar/2016/12/ya-jugaste-darksiders.html] Analisis Completo en SHD - Survival Horror Downloads [/url]

Desde tiempos inmemoriales, el Cielo y el Infierno han estado en guerra librando encarnizadas batallas. Por ese motivo el Concejo Abrasado, una entidad formada para mediar entre los dos reinos para mantener el equilibrio, exigió que se honren sus leyes con el fin de preservar los cimientos del universo. Tiempo más tarde, aparecieron los primeros humanos, creándose así un tercer reino: El Reino de los Hombres. El Consejo auguró que estos seres formarían parte vital del Equilibrio, por lo que se crearon siete sellos para mantener la tregua en el tercer reino, asegurando de esta manera la prosperidad del mismo alejado de los conflictos ancestrales. Los sellos se romperían en el momento oportuno en el que se libraría el apocalipsis, llamando a su vez a una hermandad conocida como Los Cuatro Jinetes; jueces encargados de erradicar a los malvados y pecadores, ya sean estos Señores del Cielo, Criaturas del Infierno o simples mortales.

Así es como un día, ángeles y demonios caen envueltos en llamas en la Tierra luchando nuevamente entre sí. Por este motivo el jinete rojo, Guerra, aparece para castigar a aquellos que lo merezcan. Pero... algo anda mal... sus hermanos no han acudido al llamado. ¿Dónde se encuentran Disputa, Furia y Muerte? ¿A caso el séptimo sello no se ha roto? ¿Qué es lo que está sucediendo?

Así damos inicio, con un Jinete con pocos recursos a su disposición pero los suficientes como para abrirse paso por un mundo hecho escombros. Esto es posible gracias a unos controles ya clásicos de este género y un sistema de combate bastante divertido. Podremos desencadenar ataques rápidos y combos que descuartizarán a nuestros enemigos al combinarlos en el momento adecuado, también se cuenta con la posibilidad de esquivar y bloquear ataques, realizar ejecuciones y cambiar de forma -Guerra puede adoptar La Forma del Caos, una criatura enorme con una fuerza descomunal-.

Es verdad que es posible generar paralelismos a nivel jugable entre Darksiders y God of War, a estas alturas poco se puede inventar, pero su gran variedad y la fusión de tantos otros elementos (que de tratarse de otro videojuego resultaría un desastre) que suman a la jugabilidad hacen de éste un título genuino, que si bien no redefine el género, si llega a posicionarse como un gran exponente.

Visualmente, Darksiders cumple con todas las expectativas. El arte de Joe Madureira se ha trasladado con creces al videojuego -una característica para nada sencilla de lograr-, haciendo uso de una paleta de colores bastante variada para establecer su propio estilo utilizando colores vivos y muy vibrantes para no caer en la monotonía de un universo post-apocalíptico representado a base de tonos oscuros o monocromáticos.

El apartado sonoro es de lo más brillante, compuesto por una banda sonora con 26 pistas musicales, que si bien no demuestran mucha personalidad, estas resultan espectaculares encajando con cada situación presentada en la aventura. Los efectos de sonido para cada criatura que enfrentemos es estruendosa, por lo que aumenta la sensación de adrenalina en los combates.

Darksiders es un título muy completo. Posee momentos de acción desenfrenada, jefes de nivel grandes y sistemáticos, puzzles, buena variedad de objetos en el inventario y combos interesantes para comprarle a Vulgrim. Tiene una duración aproximada de 15 horas y solo se te haría pesado el tramo final en el que hay que hacer uso del "Viajero del vacío" a una velocidad muy diferente a la que se manifestaba hasta el momento. No presenta un incentivo verdadero de rejugabilidad más allá de encontrar todos los objetos ocultos y secretos. No es un videojuego que redefina el género, pero si logra ubicarse como un gran exponente. Absolutamente recomendado.

Lo Bueno:
- Diseño artístico
- Sistema de combate
- Variedad del inventario
- Aventura diversa y entretenida

Lo Malo:	
- Tramo final denso
- Jefe final poco explorado

Puntuación Final: 8 jóvenes y puras almas para Vulgrim.

28275530.review: Totaly one of the best games ever

28272613.review: This game is amazing! It's like a mix of Devil May Cry, Legend of Zelda, Portal, and Fable The Lost Chapters and balanced nearly perfectly. Combat is fluid and fun and the insane amount of combos and moves makes itfresh and not repetitive (unless you make it repetitive by just spamming the mouse button :P) Power ups are cool and are utilized well IMO. There's a lot of action but also a lot of puzzles and many oppurtunities for exploration. It's an open world and many paths to other areas require puzzles and such and most of the puzzles don't feel tedious and are challenging but very intuitive. There are few exceptions (freeing Azrael took FOREVER and was kinda tedious). Boss fights were a highlight in this game. Bosses were tough but had patterns that you'll pick up on after a while. But using the patterns to your advantage takes skill and precise timing. There are collectibles that help you, like finding artifacts that you can trade in for currency, 10 pieces of armor you can find, chests that include either currency, wrath, health, health or wrath shards to increase your total capacities, trinkets that show you where chests and artifacts are in the area, keys, etc. Cool gadgets and gear offer more variety and also help in puzzles such as a grapple, the voidwalker which is essentially a Portal gun, the shadow mask to go back and forth between the shadow realm and your realm (no this isn't Yu-Gi-Oh in any way), etc. Plus you get to ride a horse that can even help in combat. Controls are great IMO, and I played on the keyboard. Left Alt for dash felt weird at first, but after finding a good placement of my hand on the keyboard it became easy and flowed well. It took me about five minutes or less to get used to. The using CAPS LOCK + 1, 2, or 3 for abilities was the only thing I thought was a bit tricky. I rarely felt the need to use them, though. Also underwater movement was fluid and fun, which is rare I think in a game. The story was really engaging. The ending also had a great little twist. Voice acting was great, save for a few parts, with Mark Hamill doing a full-on Joker voice for the Watcher and Liam O'Brien, the guy who voices Gaara in the english dubbed Naruto series sounding like an ancient version of Gaara as War, the main character. Yes, it's just as awesome as it sounds. The added ability to pick up items in the environment such as cars or telephone poles and use as weapons only added to all the chaotic fun. The boss death scenes were all brutal and soooooo satisfying. I highly recommend this game, it is amazing and the exploration and hidden places and objects adds to replayability.

27978167.review:
At first glance Darksiders looked to me just like any other 3rd person adventure. In fact in the first level or so there is nothing more to it, but after that the game really picks up and gets interesting. I was mostly drawn in by its great setting that takes place in a post-Armageddon world where both angels and demons deem you as an enemy. The art style and the environments were really beautiful as well, what enhanced the atmosphere. After you've gotten past the first level, that's when your character starts to learn new moves, making combat very fun and engaging. In addition you get some new weapons as well, like the Scythe, for more crowd control, and also a Tremor Gauntlet, if you fancy power punching. Among all the combat, the boss fights especially stood out for me. Each and every boss fight was both challenging and enjoyable at the same time and this is perhaps the game's biggest strength in my opinion. The cool cutscenes and the special kills were an icing on the cake. Although there are so many good things about this game and although I've given it a 9, I also have several criticisms. First of all, the game is not exactly a very good console port. The keyboard and mouse control scheme was more or less playable, but it's the fact that you couldn't change graphics options apart from resolution. Of course this isn't much of a problem for someone with a powerful PC, but for those of us with average machines, even on low resolution there is a noticeable drop in framerate in some areas of the game, making it quite stuttery. Another thing that I disliked - some areas were just a bit too long, like the Hollows and the Ashlands. Not sure whose bright idea it was that the sewers and the desert are good candidates for lengthy levels, since those usually tend to be amongst the most boring of the environments in any game. The Black Throne level was perhaps the biggest offender. Although it was a very beautiful level with some cool battles, it had way too much backtracking and also made you do the same thing 3 times! And my last criticism would be towards the puzzles. Although there were some great puzzles in the game, some others were really annoying. They weren't hard or anything. You could figure out most of them right away. It's just that to execute those solutions usually took too long, requiring too much running and jumping about, as well as tonnes of trial and error, and hence that was breaking the pace of the game. All those criticisms are quite strong for me and I guess if I wasn't so charmed by the game's setting and art style, I probably would've given it an 8 rather than a 9. Overall the game is highly entertaining and worth checking out. Going to be trying out the second one no doubt... 
Vote 8/10

After just finishing this game, I have time to give a little review.
So here it is, real brief; if you are looking for a good story, with fun characters and pretty good gameplay, come on over, get the game. A typical hack-n-slash combined with dungeon adventure (often and not-inaccurately compared to Zelda games), Darksiders is a pretty good game.  The oversized weapons, the lack of fall damage, the incredible feats of strength, and the executions all make you feel pretty powerful, in a very God of War-like fashion.  My personal largest complaint is that the control scheme, specifically when it comes to using powers or consumables mid-combat, is a bit less than ideal, though it is possible a controller could help with that.

Is it worth the $20 price tag? Sure.  In no way could my playing be described as masterful, and oftentimes not very efficient, but as of just completing it, I have 20 hours of gameplay.  That is about a dollar per hour of entertainment, so it's much cheaper than a movie in that case.  If you can't bring yourself to spend 20 bucks on it though, wait until a Steam sale or see if it ever shows up in a Humble Bundle or something, get it for 5 bucks.  No reason not to swing 5 bucks at the game, it's well worth your money at that point.

27607027.review:
This is hands-down one of my favorite games of all time. It's typically called a mash up of God of War and The Legend of Zelda and if the sound of that makes you feel a little tingly, make the jump! The combat is 3rd person hack n' slash at its finest, just the way I like it! There is also a great deal of platforming and puzzle solving weaved into this fine tapestry. Prepare to pick your jaw up off the ground after stepping into gloriously apocolyptic environments of varying degrees, whether it's the ruins of a great city long past or a massive desert made of the ashes of millions of dead people.

 The theme of this game combines elements of various religeous mythologies, primarily those of Judeo-Christion myth, to craft an epic world full of very powerful entities and monsters intermingled with elemnets of modern human society. You play as War, one of the 4 Horsemen of the Apocolypse, who has been blamed for the premature destruction of Earth in an eon's long war between the forces of Angels and Demons. The Horsemen are extremely powerful enities who serve as judge, jury, and executioner, also serving as the middleground between the 2 warring sides, led by the mysterious Charred Council who attempt to maintain balance between Heaven and Hell. All throughout the adventure, you will move Heaven and Earth(sometimes literally) to clear your name, leaving a mountain of bloody corpses in your wake.

 As the embodiment of all that is War, you weild the mighty Chaoseater, your weapon of choice, cleaving your way through Angel and Demon alike. Along with your signiture sword, you will find other powerful weapons along the way like the powerful Harvester Scythe borrowed from your brother Death, Mercy, a pistol borrowed from your brother Srife, the Crossblade, and the mighty Tremor Gauntlet. On top of that, there are varois abbillities and other objects of power, used in similar ways to items in Zelda games, to help you progress as well as gain advantages to certain enemies. There is also an upgrade system for abillities and your 3 main weapons level up and gain experience as you use them. They can also be augmented with various runes found throught the world. Later into the game, you gain access to your horse, Ruin, who you then be able to ride in amany places in the game map. If all of that isn't enough for you, the deviously selfish creature called the Watcher, an entity bound to you who acts as your guide and a leash for the Council, is voiced by none other than Mark Hamill! So what are you waiting for? Give it a try!

TL:DR: Fly like Link, Sting like Kratos!

11/10 Would pluck pidgeons with Ulthane again.

Darksiders remains one of the criminally underrated games I've ever played. Sure, it is a little too sluggish to be a full-blown slasher, the platforming is not especially inspired, and the plot is very standard. 

But the devil is in the execution. 

Combat feels just solid enough to believe we control a 9ft tall god of war who rips monsters apart with his bare hands, and the combos are visually pleasing. The traversal and platforming are clear, leave little doubt where to go and fully use the gadgetry we collect throughout the game. And the plot? It's very well voice-acted, the world is interesting and creative.

Visually, the designs are very vivid, created by one of the more distinctive comic artists of modern era.

Overall Darksiders are a great game I love coming back to, even if just for a moment.

26572763.review:
Cool game overall. Basically a later 3D Zelda, with art and writing thats more "Warcrafty" in tone. 

The overworld is pretty empty, but at least the zones looks different. The early game has alot of filler, in the form of combat challenges that have to be completed to progress. The late game has you return to empty areas for a very short, not that involved, triforce hunt.

Dungeons are a linear series of rooms that have to be tackled in a certain order without any opportunities to break from the script. Occasionaly after beating the midboss, and picking up a new item, you can backtrack to get a heart piece in an earlier room but thats about it. Most dungeons have some sort of gimmick or set piece moment to stop the game from feeling too repetitive, which does work, but the dungeons are still super linear.

Combat is good, not amazing, but good. Attacking enemies is satisfying, you have access to a large diverse tool set, all of which has a variety of uses, not all of which are telegraphed, enemies don't just constantly bum rush you, and upgrades aren't so good that they nullify combat altogether, so... none of the glaring issues that usually bog down western action games. No real pros other than a lack of cons, I would put the combat somewhere between God of War and DMC1 in terms of quality.

Heavily inspired by Zelda and God of War which is ultimately a positive thing because both of those franchises are awesome but there is no aspect of the game that does anything better than those two. The combat is pretty basic and very repetitive, it’s not very enjoyable especially compared to other hack and slash games. The story is just a very average fantasy plot, nothing about it feels very unique, interesting or different. The Zelda like dungeons, progression and exploration is the highlight of the game, however there is no music to accompany you while you are doing these things it just kind of makes things feel a little empty, dour and less enjoyable. I also just want to point out how awful and drawn out the portal sequence towards the end of the game was, it completely killed the pacing on the game. My experience with this game was ultimately very boring, the pros of the game are not good enough for me to recommend the game but I can’t say it’s a bad game either. It's overall just a very average action adventure game that can easily be skipped.
5/10 (Average)

26064184.review:
Heard a lot about this being the closest to a Zelda title on PC and one of the best third person platformers on here too. Looking at footage and images, I was skeptical and decided to wait for sale.

But now after playing through the game I can see why people felt this way about the game. It offers beautiful visuals, great third person control, enjoyable combat, a cool story and quite intelligent puzzles.
It's something you should definitely experience for yourself. It's much more action-y and 'western' than your typical Zelda game, but it's a good spin on the formula. It's not the longest game either, took me just under 20 hours to beat, but at no point does it ever recycle any gameplay mechanic and each area, each room has its own unique puzzle. No boring sidequests; well, no sidequests at all really, and some neat collectables to find along the way make it a very enjoyable game.

I'd definitely recommend trying it at least, and give it at least a couple of hours to get a decent taste of the game.

25934651.review:
I wanted to like Darksiders almost as hard as Darksiders kept trying to be God of War. I tried really, really hard.

The concept is cool. Book of Revelation, four horsemen of the apocalypse, yaddayadda. Like any brawler the point is simple: smash dudes. Lots of dudes. Even if I don't much care for the Warhammer 40,000/World of Warcraft proportions and pauldrons fetish that Darksiders's art direction makes ample use of, the visuals are pretty good. The voice acting is fitting, given what script the VAs had to work with. And on that note, the characterization is about as shallow as either W40K or WoW's; angry guy is angry, thus, he does angry things. I didn't expect masterful writing going in, but when even mediocrity counts as a positive bullet point in a review, it heralds bad things to come.

There's only one category where Darksiders really shines, and that's the boss fights. The introductory cutscenes are great, the battle mechanics themselves are usually pretty neat, you feel great for fighting and winning, you get to watch War perform some pretty brutal finishers on the bosses at the end, and there is no annoying underwater fight to speak of. A+.

The final boss is the worst, though. No, not The Destroyer. The [i]final[/i] final boss.

The protagonist, War, and the final final boss, the camera, are introduced in the same cutscene sequence when you first fire up Darksiders and select New Game. And if you know anything about the camera angles in pre-rendered cutscenes, it's that you can't actually move them. Get used to a lot of that; Darksiders is an ongoing and constant battle of atrition against atrocious perspective shots, awkward lock-on phases, and jarring transitions.

[list]
[*]When clinging to platform edges and ledges embedded in walls that you can strafeclimb across, it can be difficult to see where you're going- especially if you need to leap to something behind you and you're in an enclosed area. The camera often can't be coerced to give you a view of where you're headed in such cramped quarters, so prepare to make many a leap of faith.

[*]At times, the target lockon feature avoids traditional third-person, over-the-shoulder camera angles in favor of side-facing perspectives that skew your controls by 90 degrees and throw your depth of field off, resulting in many swing-and-a-miss and failed dodge scenarios on your part.

[*]The lockon feature lets you cycle through enemies, but not consistently. On occasion, it will only toggle back and forth between the same two enemies instead of cycling over to whichever bigger threat you're trying to look at.

[*]During battle sequences the camera will often be hijacked to show the arrival of more enemies from somewhere near the area. When control is reluctantly returned to the player, you are often not facing exactly the same direction you were when the camera was stolen from you. You are not always finished fighting when this happens, either, which only exacerbates the problem.

[*]The awful teleportation mechanic introduced in the later part of the game wreaks havoc with the camera angle, snapping it to a fixed position and holding it there for just a second too long. Even if you look through your portals to preview where you're going, your perspective will be seized from you the moment you step through them, forcing you to react the way the game wants you to instead of the way you planned. Trial-and-error is not a fun mechanic.

[*]Sensitivity is not consistent between different game views. In the handful of shooter segments, your aim is off-the-walls oversensitive. In the brawler and platformer segments, the camera is much less sensitive. I found myself switching the game's camera sensitivity back and forth to try to compensate.
[/list]

Entire swaths of the puzzles in Darksiders feel unnecessary. There's a lot of time-based puzzle mechanics that involve a lot of waiting to reset if you make a mistake.

Toss in an uncooperative camera that won't let you look up to see when it's safe to proceed until you're already hanging from the ceiling and the time-slowing Chronospheres to make you wait that much longer when the spinning fan blade you couldn't see coming knocks you down, and you've got a recipe for half an hour wasted on multiple, identical, really badly-designed obstacles in the Ashlands.

Or, worse than player-controlled timers, there are entire rooms in the Dark Throne area in the later part of the game with floors that automatically build and remove themselves in cycles. If you miss the chance to step onto the path when it appears near you, you have to wait for the cycle to circle the entire room in order to continue. At least one of these also features a player timing puzzle.

Darksiders features what most gaming circles call "artificial difficulty." The harder game modes bump up the damage enemies do and, possibly, the number of enemies and the number of waves of enemies you face, but they don't become more intelligent or actually more challenging to destroy; they just take longer to finish off. My first run was on Apocalyptic, the hardest difficulty setting. When I briefly tried again on Easy to see what the differences were for this review I noticed a stark difference in survivability- mine and the enemy's- but I didn't play long enough to really see if there were fewer enemies to fight. It felt that way but I can't confirm.

My biggest complaint with the artificial difficulty is that it's irritating to be one-shot by some of the bigger baddies in the early game when you don't know how to fight them. Dark Souls players might find the challenge enjoyable, but the difficulty spike feels out of place in a brawler like this one. As I played, however, I picked up more Lifestones and was able to mitigate this problem. But it's still a problem.

In the beginning of the game, when I was instructed how to toggle between running and walking, I was ecstatic. My joy quickly turned to despair when I realized that the player's default state [i]is[/i] running. War's movement speed is agonizingly slow. This could be mitigated by Ruin, the demonic steed depicted in the game's promotional matierals, but Darksiders has a huge problem: you play one of the four horsemen, but you don't get many opportunities to [i]ride his horse.[/i]

It's unfortunate because everything in the game is either far too speedy or War is much too slow, though I suspect it's a combination of both. The result is a lot of chasing enemies around or trying to wade through piles of mooks to deal with the real threats and failing because everything can strafe circles around you. Thanks to a really jarring pause at the end, your dash is useless as a way to close real distance and seems to feature variable invincibility frames on top of it. I could never figure out what I did differently when I succeeded or failed; dodging always felt like a gamble.

I experienced a handful of bugs while playing Darksiders, and if you look into my screenshot gallery for the game, you'll be able to see the few I had time to snag pictures of. In my playthrough of Darksiders, I...
[list][*]...fell through the world, twice
[*]...got stuck in level geometry and couldn't escape, several times
[*]...got stuck in the Serpent Holes because the end portal didn't appear, once
[*]...got stuck in midair after being knocked out of an aerial combo attack, once
[*]...got pushed out of bounds underwater, "died", and respawned on land with less health, once[/list]
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=776105436
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=776098965
I can't speak for the original PS3 and Xbox 360 releases, but this first PC port is garbage. Maybe the remastered version is playable, but this one isn't unless you're into sadomasochism. Skip it. I'm going to complete Darksiders, because I don't want to let it sit unfinished in my Steam library... but it isn't going to be fun.

Darksiders juego que inicia con Guerra, uno de los 4 caballeros de apocalipsis. Que es convocado ya que fueron rotos los 7 sellos para liberar la batalla final entre el reino del cielo, el inframundo, y el reino de los Humanos. Tras su llegada al mundo de los humanos, Guerra se da cuenta que algo no pinta bien, puesto que sus hermanos no estan con él. Es en este punto con de el conciliio, acusa a Guerra de llegar el caos y la destruccion al mundo de los humanos sin si quiera haber sido convocado, y Guerra en un intento de limpiar su nombre y reputacion, inicia un busqueda de respuestas a lo largo de mapas extensos, llenos de enemigos y secretos que hacen bastante interesante. En el apartado grafico puedo decir que es increible, para su epoca aunque siendo un port de consola, esta bastante mal optimizado. Si tienes problemas con caidas de fps existen tutos para eliminar algunos archivos de efectos del juego, que te van a ayudar a mejorar el rendimiento y la experiencia del juego. Si eres amante los hack and slash, y no haz jugado este, que esperas es un juego obligado dentro de tu biblioteca. 
En cuestion de jugablidad, al menos necesitaras 20 horas de juego para cubrir la compaña completa(quizás menos), cuentas con varios secretos y detalles en mapas que de primera visita no vas a poder recabar hasta que tengas los elementos necesarios. Mas alla de la excelente historia, los buenos graficos, no hay nada, es decir; no hay rejugablidad mas alla de comenzar una nueva partida en modo apocaliptico y tratar de pasarlo. 
Recomiendo este juego, si lo vez de oferta en steam, y no lo haz jugado.

25817455.review:
Darksiders is an 3rd person single-player RPG, which contains about 15 hours of gameplay.
Many people tend to compare this to God of War, because both games have a bunch of similarities.

You play as War, one of the horsemen of the Apocalypse. You are being accused of breaking the truce between Heaven and Hell, and thus bringing doom to all humanity. Your mission is simply put; to find the real culprits.

As War, you find yourself travelling through marvelous landscapes, fighting against tougher enemies, exploring dungeons and solving puzzles. These puzzles are designed for older audiences, and in fact, i find that rather amusing. It takes time to figure out what to do, and when to do. You will often be rewarded with souls, mana or health points.
Souls can be used to upgrade weapons, learn new combos and to upgrade them as well.

Combat is slow-paced, combos aren't hard to master, and enemies are forgiving.
You start by only using your sword, Chaoseater, but you gain more weapons and gear throughout the game.
Good examples are large scythe called The Harvester, and revolver called Mercy.

Art style is maybe the thing i liked the most - it's cartoon-like, uses lots of color, has all these little details like ash floating mid-air, and spider webs hanging out of windows. The artist team sure knew what they did, environment changes from fires of hell to desolate lands, gothic-style manors and terrains crowded with grass and waterfalls.

Game sometimes has little frame problems, but those can be simply fixed by changing angle of view.
I also had some glitches throughout the game, none of them caused game crashes or anything bad.

Overall it's a good game. It looks good and plays good, you're going to enjoy every minute of it.
When it ends, you wish it would have not, not so soon. It's so much fun.

+ It's available for only 19,99€ on Store, and that, is a bargain.

Thanks for reading, hopefully this helped.
Constructive criticism appreciated!

-Nate

25785880.review:
Antes que nada una breve introducción :

Darksiders es un juego de Hack "n" Slash y Acción con una historia bastante mediocre.
Abarca temas como la venganza y la desesperacion como por ejemplo cuando un amigo tuyo hace un sinpa y te toca pagarle la cerveza, o cuando te quieres tirar a tu novia, no te quedan condones y te toca bajar empalmado al 24h mas cercano para mojarla en caliente.
Ahora fuera tonterias, lo que respecta al gameplay, bastante bueno, no excelente, un hack n slash mas con un par de combos que no le hacen sobresalir nada de otros en su genero, abunda mucho la repetición, salir de una sala y mas zombies, que si, que es lo propio de su género pero si lo jugais ya vereis a que me refiero.
Un punto flaco y negativo por el cual me hace no recomendar este juego es el tema "puzzle" si se pueden llamar asi.
Cada cierto avance, obtendremos un nuevo objeto que desbloquea una mecanica en el juego, pues bueno, la cosa es que los desarrolladores no sabian como rellenar el juego y repiten los mismos puzzles vez tras vez hasta que acabas desquiciado y con ganas de mandar el juego a tomar por culo.
Gráficamente es bastante chusta, pero teniendo en cuenta su tiempo le daremos ese pase, los sonidos son una completa caca, de repente te pueden sorprender con un sonido nordico que no viene a nada que con un grito de demonio extreñido.
Su duración es totalmente innecesaria como he dicho antes y repito que la manera en la que han rellenado el juego no ha sido de mi agrado.
Personalmente me encantan muchisisimo los hack n slash pero este juego me ha dejado muy mal sabor de boca, cosa que espero que su secuela sepa endulzar.
No recomiendo este juego a nadie personalmente, pero si eres paciente pues dale un intento no se me vayan a echar los fanboys al cuello a meter ciberpuñetazos.

Nota : 5/10

25707614.review:
I was searching for a game like this after playing Bioshock series, Dishonored, Deus Ex etc. That is a game with both a good story and gameplay. That is what I (kinda) found here.

 The [b]gameplay[/b] seems similar to the Batman games (not that positive for me). Sometimes, espessialy when you're getting closer to the end, the combat seems a bit boring. Yes, as you progress you encounter new, stronger units but if you repeatedly block/dodge and hit then your fine. There are many puzzles you need to solve (some would say a bit complicated), yet none of them are hard if you've played portal. There are some collectables that are kinda easy to find, thus there are not that many. It offers *roughly* 15-16 hours of gameplay (add another 5 hours for 100% completion. Gameplay wise, I wouldn't buy it for killing demons or angels.

BUT!

The [b]story[/b] of the game seemed really appealing to me from the first minute! I was finding myself getting too bored to play (because it was dodge - kill, dodge - kill all over again) but at the same time I was magnetized by the story and wouldn't let go. I haven't played the sequel yet but I really look forward to.

[b]OVERALL[/b] [spoiler]I DO recommend the game, yet I'd wait for sales.[/spoiler]

25581303.review:
Game is OK, the backtracking killed it for me. With no way to know which areas you need to go back for collectibles you're gonna be spending a lot of time wandering aimlessly unless you follow a guide.

This game needed some serious QoL changes. The fast travel sucks. Not only do you have to walk all the way to a a waypoint but after you activate the waypoint, you also gotta run through an alternate dimension area to get where you want to go. Why? This is just a waste of time.

Why are there so few hotkeys for your equipment? There's about 5-6 tools you need to use to roam the world but only 3 of those can be hotkeyed at any time.

Why is there no way to hastily leave a previously completed dungeon? I went into the Twilight Cathedral in search of upgrades I didn't collect. After about 5 minutes I decided I couldn't be arsed to find my way out again. Closed the game and uninstalled on the spot.

25497653.review:
Short and sweet: It's a good game! However --do not-- get this for PC if you can avoid it. It is TERRIBLY optimised and BARELY functions without the proper settings.

Here's the only way I could get it to work for Windows 10 Professional: it WILL NOT function or run unless forced to run in windows 98 compatibility mode (Yes Windows 98! Not even XP or anything past could make it run).

Here's the only way I could get it to minimize the BRUTAL stuttering issues down to moderate stuttering through the whole game after lots of research: Google "Skyrim Stutter Fix" and use the d3d9.dll and antilag.cfg to help lower the degree (but not get rid of) all the stuttering in the game.

Deleting two of the start up films helps reduce load up times but --does not-- affect any of the booting issues in Windows 10 Professional.

Also other known issues: DO NOT tab out of the game when it is running or it will often desync achievements with Steam if not outright crash. In order to make sure Steam achievements work then exit steam, re-open steam and open DarkSiders as the first fresh game on steam start up. Never tab out. Once done playing, fully exit steam and re-open before playign DarkSiders again.

That's about all the major issues to cover if you just want to even try to play the game among possible other issues and crashing. Do yourself a favor and play this somewhere other than PC.

25426333.review:
I've heard a lot of people call this a Zelda ripoff, which I think is misleading. It's true that a lot of mechanics are ripped straight from Zelda, but it plays very differently.

The biggest differences are that it is much more linear and has a higher emphasis on combat. It is definitely closer to a hack'n'slash than an RPG. Fights are almost constant except in some of the more puzzly dungeons and you frequently need to battle wave after wave of enemies. It helps that the combat system has a lot more depth than Zelda games, with six(ish) different weapons, unlockable combos, weapon modifiers, and weapon levels (you gain XP as you fight).

It has some minor issues on modern systems (it takes some work to get the in-game cutscenes working and to run at 2560x1440) and can get a little repetitious towards the end but it's still an enjoyable, solid experience.

25417011.review:
* Reseña en mi blagh: http://www.agustinfest.com/2016/09/darksiders-un-perro-de-guerra-bien-entrenado/

Esta es la historia de Guerra, uno de los jinetes del Apocalipsis, y como fue traicionado por un consejo místico de seres, quienes en su totalidad ocultan la vergonzosa presencia de Dios. Es un juego de ángeles, demonios, monstruos, espíritus célticos que no son espíritus célticos, sombras y traiciones.

El juego es una plataforma tridimensional al estilo de Legacy of Kain, Prince of Persia, The Legend of Zelda (estoy asombrado por la cantidad de usuarios que lo comparan, pero es entendible por qué), entre muchos, muchos otros. El jueguillo, además, tiene elementos de Hack & Slash, RPG y Metroidvania. Una combinación aparatosa que funciona y mantiene entretenido al jugador entre unas 15 y 30 horas, dependiendo que tanto desee entregarse a la tarea. Odié los acertijos pero son necesarios para alargar este tipo de juegos y hacerle creer al jugador que no todo es empaparse con la sangre de tus enemigos.

El juego tiene una colección muy respetable de artefactos que ayudarán a Guerra a completar su misión. No sólo está la variedad de armas, las cuáles son un deleite en su uso y su aprendizaje: un puño, una pistola, una hoz y una espada; pero también la variedad de objetos y de modos de juego, por ejemplo la máscara de sombras, el arma de portal (sí, piensa en portales) y del caballo. Es muy satisfactorio recorrer los mapas o matar a un puñado de enemigos con las armas, así como aprender el sistema de combos del juego (aunque también, seamos sinceros, no necesitas más de uno o dos combos). Aunque algunos de estos objetos, o ayudas, parecen solamente brillar para el área que fueron destinados y francamente, algunas veces recorrer todos los mapas, al momento de obtener algo nuevo, podía convertirse en una rutina un poco tediosa. Darksiders se reserva varios objetos hasta muy pasada la historia y justo cuando crees que es una buena idea regresar para ver si puedes obtener algo nuevo, te dan algo más que contradice estas bonitas esperanzas o descubres un área nueva inalcanzable.

La historia se me hizo normalona, convencional. No hay personaje con el cual sentirse identificado, ni siquiera el personaje principal, pues todos parecen muy enojados, muy metidos en su papel, pues finalmente su origen, su naturaleza misma, ha excedido inevitablemente a la humanidad y eso parece quitarles emociones fiables, sinceras y todos parecen cartones o estereotipos. Sin embargo, las actuaciones de voz son imponentes y muy adecuadas (Mark Hamill, como siempre, engalanando con sus dotes una historia que podría ser olvidable), y ello mismo, incluso, me hizo disfrutar la historia a pesar de insulsa y carente de giros interesantes.

Los gráficos están muy bien pero los videos sufren en sistemas más actuales. Tuve problemas para ajusta el V-Sync. Hay que moverle un poco pero nada que Google y un par de reajustes en los drivers de video no resuelvan. Pero advertencia: aún así, algunos videos saltaban o estaban desfasados.

Convendría comprar esta versión antes de Octubre o Noviembre 2016, porque están a punto de sacar una versión remasterizada del juego y puede que suban el valor. Y de verdad, es un buen juego, a pesar de sus detallitos. Me entretuvo durante horas y mi espíritu masoquista recorrió algunas áreas diversas veces en búsqueda de encontrar algo nuevo. Va calado, recomendado y garantizado. Es el Let’s Play más largo que he grabado a la fecha (más de 40 videos los cuales estoy subiendo poquito a poco. Espero acabar antes del Apocalipsis).

Let's Play (40 partes que iré subiendo poco a poco):  

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZkvZ7mrkLRM&index=1&list=PLf3hSHJ6VZaO4676K1k1NdAnEvVEMU1z4

25338205.review:
If you don't mind solving puzzles in an action-adventure game, then please skip my review and buy this game. Darksiders runs smoothly, has great art style, fun and brutal combat and a cool sword.

BUT if you're not into puzzles, then this game might not be for you.

At first, the game feels very much like an epic metroidvania God of War, which is cool. There are puzzles here and there and that's fine.

But later in the game, the dev got too carried away with puzzles and the balance shifts heavily from action-and-puzzle to puzzle-and-puzzle-and-puzzle-and-puzzles. I don't mind repetitive combat and weapon/skill upgrades that don't evolve to anything much. However, running around trying to figure out seemingly endless stream of puzzles with not enough actions in between isn't something I expect from a guy named War.

Again, if you like a lot of puzzles in your action-adenture game, then you'll have a great time. But this isn't for me.

This is not a classic hack and slash game – it's one of those All in One console titles, and a good one too. The action itself is great: enemies are different by design and behaviour, boss fights are creative, combat system has decent variations (though to my opinion not realized to its full potential) finishing moves are gory and induced at will. But fighting and killing takes not as much time as you'd expect: my walkthrough was 14 hours and only 3 hours in combat. The rest of the Darksiders is puzzles. In that respect it takes inspiration not solely in DMC games, but from Prince of Persia, Legacy of Kain, hell - even Portal. Some of the puzzles feel forced and artifitial, but most of them are creative and engaging.
One of the best hack and slash titles on PC for sure

25097072.review:
This is an almost 8 year old game. And however, it stands out as one of the best of its genre.
I played first when it came out, and my expectations were low, as I thought this was going to be a cheap God of War clone. It turned out I was wrong: combat was simple but satisfying, landscapes were imaginative and vibrant, and the story, while not deserving an Oscar, was mildly interesting. But what won me over was the puzzles. You see, this is in some way a Metroidvania: you can revisit previous locations with abilities you gain during your playthrough in order to get to new areas. The ways you get to use your new gear are sometimes not straightforward and there are more than a couple of clever puzzles in the game. Yes, many abilities we have seen in other games, like Portal, but when you copy things that work and are well implemented in the gameplay like this game does, then it's totally forgivable. Some people I know claim this is the best Zelda title ever, and I agree. Besides War, the main character is a total badass. 

When I revisited the game for my second playthrough a month or so ago, I tried to temper my expectations thinking 7 years have gone by and maybe it wasn´t going to hold up well. How wrong was I. Despite, the comparatively low polygon count of the models and backgrounds, the choice of colors and the exceptional design make them look great (this is the old tech vs art design debate), the combat without being as refined as DmC is responsive and satisfying, and puzzles and exploration are as good as ever. 

A sign of the quality of the game is that the company that bought the rights to the title is going to release  a 1080p/60fps version soon. Obviously if you have an average PC you should be able to play it at that resolution with no issues.

Do yourself a favor and play this!

25072777.review:
This game is excellent, and I enjoyed it greatly. It reminds me of the Soul Reaver series, which I also loved, but with a higher focus on combat rather than puzzles (although there are puzzles).

The game is kind of linear - the main path is, but you can explore around to get some benefits, and revisit old places with your new abilities to reach extra rewards (such as increasing your max health). You will unlock big new abilities and mechanics at specific points in the game, but many combat abilities and upgrades are bought using the game's currency (souls).

The combat is quite entertaining. You have (and unlock) many combat abilities and tools. Your main ways to avoid damage are blocking (which is more useful than it is in other games, though some big attacks are unblockable) and moving out of the way (usually using a dash). Your main weapon is a huge sword, but there's also two alternate weapons (one focused on a bigger are, and the other on stuns and sending people flying away), and they're all quite satisfying to use. These three weapons gain experience by using them to hit your enemies, and you can assign trinkets to them to add small bonuses. You get several ranged weapons, but they're not the main focus (they don't gain experience and you can't assign trinkets to them, but you can buy some upgrades for them). There's also other combat mechanics which you'll unlock, but I don't want to spoil them.

The story is quite good, and it doesn't end too abruptly, even if you do want to learn more about several things (though I haven't played the sequel yet). The story includes characters from several mythologies, but doesn't exactly follow any of them (many details are different from those mythologies), and other characters are new, creating the game's new mythological cosmology.

The graphics are relatively good, although the game's not that recent. The design of the characters and locations is excellent. The music's alright, but it's not particularly memorable. The voice acting is high quality.

The port is good, thought to unlock steam achievements, you should run the game after starting steam (you can restart steam before playing to be safe). It runs pretty well on oldish computers.

24909202.review:
[h1]Una gran aventura de acción como las de antaño.[/h1] 

Antes que nada, me gustaría clasificar a Darksiders dentro del género de aventura de acción, con grandes toques de hack n slash. Esto resulta importante para los amantes del género hack n slash, pues Darksiders no es un hack n slash puro sino un juego de aventuras en el que con dar mamporros a lo loco es suficiente para acabarse el juego. No hay exigencia técnica, aunque eso no es malo ya que el juego tiene personalidad propia y, de hecho, me recuerda a esas aventuras de acción de los tiempos de ps2.

Gráficamente es difícil de analizar a estas fechas y sospecho que en su día no era puntero en este aspecto, aunque siempre ayudan las bondades del PC, como por ejemplo las altas resoluciones y el excelente rendimiento. Los diseños de los personajes principales y los escenarios son realmente buenos. Obviamente, teniendo que diseñar ángeles, demonios y uno de los cuatro jinetes del apocalipsis, tenían un buen material con el que trabajar.

Darksiders también cuenta con un buen apartado sonoro, con buenas composiciones musicales y además con unas voces en español agradables de escuchar. Algunos personajes tienen voces más serias o dramáticas mientras que otros cuentan con voces en un tono más acorde al de una película de animación. Algunos podrían preferir voces más serias para una aventura de este tipo, aunque no son las voces algo negativo en este juego.

El argumento es interesante y nos ayuda a estar interesados en todo momento. Siempre resulta atractiva la lucha entre el bien y el mal, pero si a eso le añadimos a un jinete del apocalipsis en medio de todo el “jaleo”, pues hay trama para rato.

Por último, sólo queda hablar del aspecto donde más “peros” se encuentran en este juego: el control. Y aunque no es un obstáculo para acabar el juego, ya que Darksiders no es un juego difícil, si se echa en falta un control más cómodo y preciso. Por poner algunos ejemplos, los botones de ataque y bloqueo se encuentran en el mismo lado, y se hace raro atacar y bloquear con la misma mano. Se usa el gatillo izquierdo para fijar enemigos pero para apuntar con el arma se usa R3. Hay que estar cambiando ciertos objetos desde el menú porque la cruceta solo da cuatro opciones. Esto se hubiese solucionado con la típica “rueda” de selección que se despliega al pulsar un botón…

Bueno, pues para terminar sólo me queda decir que me ha encantado Darksiders y sin duda lo recomiendo, aunque como es un juego ya viejo es mejor conseguirlo en oferta. Veo una saga con potencial y creo que su segunda parte me va a parecer incluso mejor juego que el primero.

24780096.review:
Darksiders es un 3D brawler con muchas armas y mejoras desbloqueables y puzzles estilo Zelda. La parte brawler está bien, tiene un buen sistema de combos que son fáciles de memorizar y ejecutar con el gamepad una vez son desbloqueados, aunque como todos los brawler al final puedes acabar cansado de matar a tantos enemigos constantemente. Las mejoras son bastante impresionantes también, ya que partimos de una simple espada y para el final habremos acumulado 3 armas principales con diferentes combos y 6 secundarias que dan solución a los diferentes puzzles. En cuanto a los puzzles, también están bien pensados, son al estilo Zelda de arrastrar objetos, cortar cuerdas o mover pesos y se hacen bastante interesantes. Los jefes finales también son muy variados, y como en Zelda debes utilizar tus nuevas armas desbloqueadas en la mazmorra para poder acabar con ellos. A destacar el jefe final, que aunque no es excesivamente diícil da una pelea bastante interesante.

La ambientación y la estética están muy conseguidos también. Se trata de un mundo post-apocalíptico donde han engañado a Guerra (uno de los Cuatro Jinetes del Apocalipsis) para hacerle creer que el Juicio Final ha llegado. Tras la invasión de la Tierra por parte de demonios y ángeles, Guerra lucha por limpiar su nombre y demostrar que este simulacro de Apocalipsis fue una emboscada. La estética es una mezcla entre magia demónica y ángeles con tecnoarmaduras muy bien conseguida.

La verdad es que el juego me ha gustado mucho, es muy entretenido y las constantes mejoras y desbloqueos evitan que se haga excesivamente repetitivo. Lo único malo, a veces las partes brawler se alargan demasiado.

Darksiders es un juego de accion, aventura, y por sobre todo un buen hack'n'slash, en donde encarnamos a Guerra (Uno de los cuatro jinetes del apocalipsis). Muy divertido, y recomendable, si tienes un mando es mejor usarlo que los controles de teclado y mouse.

24373060.review:
The start of this game is fairly slow, introducing you to combat and the world and therefore drags a bit as there's really not much you can do in terms of combat initially. You earn more weapons and techniques for them throughout the game and the battle system eventually becomes quite well fleshed out. While not on par with Bayonetta or the later DMC titles, it's still got enough to work with that it can be fun.
Once the game introduces you to the dungeons it becomes a lot more fun and interesting and the first two dungeons are great, rivalling some of Zelda's best with some good bosses to round off the experience. 
Unfortunately the game begins to fall flat at around the halfway point with the latter two dungeons being much less interesting and the bosses being a bit lame. There is no final dungeon and the final battle isn't very challenging or engaging at all. To top this off, there's a bit of padding before the final dungeon which is really just backtracking and busywork, not aided by the poor map system.
The story is there but it's not something I was really invested in. I don't really care much about the characters and there weren't any great moments.

Overall I'd say this game is probably worth a play if you're into Zelda and want something that's similar but changes the formula up a bit. While it does dip towards the end, I feel that the first two dungeons at least are worth playing the game for if you get it cheap.
