24297803.review:
Some people refer to Darksiders as "Zelda meets God of War." I don't think they mean it in a bad way at all because the game is far different enough from those two to make it's mark as a distinguished title.

The comparison to Zelda and God of War are in reference to the fact that this is an action-adventure game with combat similar to God of War and puzzles similar to Zelda. As I said earlier though, this game is different enough from those two that it makes for a fairly unique game experience. Few action games have the kind of puzzles present in this game and almost no puzzle based games feature the combat that Darksiders has. 

Even though it's different in it's own way than God of War, if you have played GoW you'll feel right at home with the controls and the combat. You have your basic attacks, magic, and a huge number of combos to pull off. Countering enemies is always satisfying and gives you a huge advantage in that moment. Bosses are also great with each providing a slightly different mechanic to use to defeat them.

One area where I feel the game could improve is the ratio of combat to puzzles. There were some puzzle sections that seemed to go on just a hair too long as I was itching to kill more stuff. Combat is so fun that you end up missing it when doing the puzzle sections (which are adequate, but not quite up there with Zelda). This slightly breaks up the flow of the game and as I said earlier some puzzle stages definitely overstay their welcome. It doesn't help that the puzzles are usually somewhat mediocre (move x to y, push button, etc.). They aren't bad, but it's not like the combat which in itself is pretty exceptional.

On a visual level this is a relatively old game but it still looks pretty good thanks to Todd McFarlane's excellent character designs. Character design is great and you truly get the sense of being in a fantasy/post-apocalyptic setting. Some visual effects are absent as this game was made awhile ago and unfortunately cut scenes are not in 1080p.

Puzzles and visuals aside this is one great game. It's fun and challenging without being frustrating and combat is a blast (when you're not solving puzzles). As far as achievements go there are a number of collectibles in the form of upgrades so they are worth collecting even if you need a guide. A forewarning about achievements in this game though: Some will NOT unlock when they should so keep your eye on the corner of your screen when you expect to get an achievement. I found I had to go back several times to pick up an achievement for beating a boss or collecting an item so make a LOT of saves if you can. This doesn't break the experience though and it only happened a few times so I would still give it a shot at getting 100% if you're up for that sort of thing. 

With great combat and a unique art style (even with dated graphics) Darksiders is a great experience. There really isn't too much else out there like it and it will keep you busy for awhile (15-20 hours).

8.5/10

24252747.review:
I heard a lot of terrible things about the PC ports of Darksiders. So when I saw them on sale, I was sceptical.
But, I decided to pick them up for a few dollars each, to see if it was worth it.
IT WAS.

Darksiders is basically God Of War meets Devil May Cry meets Legend Of Zelda Ocarina Of Time.
Set in a world where Hell and Hell are two dormant sides waiting to tear out each others throats above
the Kingdom Of Mankind, you play as War, a giant-sword-wielding, demon-obliterating badass.

Pros:
-Incredibly satisfying, good paced combat system that's easy to grasp but challenging to master.
-Looks pretty decent despite itss age.
-The whole game is set in this sort of sub-linear, sub-open world. If you're not directly in a dungeon, you're
free to wander as you please from space to space.
-Puzzles start off easy, and become interesting and challenging towards the end of the game.
-Genuinly decent storyline. Not amazing, but interesting enough.
-Great pacing. Just whenever the game begins to feel dull, a new mechanic is introduced, be it a grappling 
hook, explosives, riding on horseback, a new weapon, or so on. 

Cons:
-Supposedly has some issues running on some computers, not that I experienced them.
-Lacks graphical settings other than V-Sync and Resolution.
-Basically requires a controller to play. PC controls are blegh.
-A few small bugs in places.

Overall, I was pleasently surprised to find that Darksiders was an absolutely amazing game that I couldn't put down.
It played smoothly, it was fun, the pacing was great, and I loved every second of it. If you have any sort of enjoyment
in brawler style games, like you played God of War or Devil May Cry or anything like them, I definetely reccomend you
try out Darksiders.

24081457.review:
I got around to playing this game after grabbing it in the 2016 Summer Sale.  I gotta admit - for a game six years old, I was pleasantly surprised!  I watched a trailer and purchased the game assuming that I was going to get a mindless hack and slash experience.  I DID get that experience - and got so much more.

Darksiders is a great entertaining distraction with an interesting character and plot.  The game wonderfully integrates a great blend of genres - the hack and slash of Devil May Cry, the puzzles and exploration of Zelda, Progression of Metroidvania, and even some shooter elements.  As soon as I was tired of hacking things to bits in 50+ hit combos, I was rewarded with a couple hours of puzzle solving and dungeon exploration.  That back and forth continued throughout the game.

That said, the game is far from perfect.  The end game collect-a-thon grew very old very fast.  I can't help but think this was a dropped ball by Vigil Games narratively and gamplay-wise.  It felt as if they took the "easy way out."  Go collect these four hearts...and then collect the seven pieces of the sword...and then go fight the boss, which requires you to fight the four mini bosses before hand.  Darksiders is set in a cosmic world with compelling ingredients - interesting characters, unique plot, and a blend of mechanics that somehow falls short in the end.

I also went for 100% completion to get all the achievements, and the achievements were a drag to get.  I'm a completionist at heart and prefer gaming that way, but I felt like an idiot at the end killing spiders over and over again to farm money and experience for the sake of the achievement and not the sake of the game.  I felt even dumber riding the horse for 100 miles -- two hours of rotating the joystick while I watched TV.  

All in all, though, for $4 -- Darksiders does not disappoint.  A great distraction that holds up wonderfully, even six years later.  I'll pick up the second one eventually, but not for a while.  The 100% achievement collecting kinda burned me out.

24055744.review:
This game has its ups and downs. 

I really liked the story, the setting, the skills and the fighting/boss fights. Graphically this game is similar to the Prototype.

But what I really disliked was: 

Tons of different bugs. Many NPCs can just bug out and you will need to relaunch the game. The enemies sometimes get stuck into the walls. The game crashes a lot. Especially if you like to alt+tab from the game from time to time. 
It will be hard to get the achievements because they get bugged if you quit the game or get an occasional crash.

The puzzles will take the most of your playing time. There is a lot of backtracking too (I really dislike when you have to revisit the locations only because you get a new ability and you can go somewhere where before, you just couldn't).

Some people think that it's hard to play with keyboard and mouse, but I completed this game with this setup and I didn't have any trouble (maybe because I'm not a console guy).

I think the beginning of the game is a bit too slow paced, the middle game is very enjoyable and the late game is just full of long puzzles with little action.

23967168.review:
I have completed Darksiders three times now. It doesn't really amaze me as a game in any way. The graphics are cartoonish and just about worthy of the Xbox 360 (not a compliment), the gameplay is formulaic and platformy reminiscent of a PlayStation 2 game (that's sort of a compliment) and the story-line and script is about as impressive as Michael Bay at his best (not really a compliment either), although having said that its "twist" ending keeps things at least a little fresh.

Despite all this, to this day I find something in Darksiders simplicity that I like. Maybe it is simply the pleasure in experiencing the humble origins of its overly-ambitious sequel, perhaps it's the idiosyncratic lore-rich post-apocalyptic Earth, or maybe it's the storyline - the idea of ageless god-like creatures on a self-serving mission to resurrect the annihilated human race. 

There is nothing new or groundbreaking about Darksiders, and although it was one of THQ's larger releases it is not at all a game that was made to be a money spinner I don't think. Somebody loved Darksiders, and in 2016 I still do. The level design is varied in a predictable sort of way (forest level, desert level, city level, scary level), the bosses which you hunt are quite interesting but again nothing new (giant spider, giant bat) and a lot of the game's completion relies on that obsession with collectables and point gathering that 2006-2010 games are so infamous for. 

This game is totally charming. And it did give us the bug-riddled but excellent Darksiders II. If you are a fan of the latter or you think that the Playstation 2 was the best games console to grace God's green Earth, pick up this game.

Be prepared to do a lot of running back through levels you have already cleared to get to the next mission point. The only real challenge to the game is poor level layout.

In all, if you would like a GoW experience without the GoW... anything really, you are in for a treat.

23736000.review:
Man.. What do I say about Darksiders.. Well, it is by no means a bad game. The gameplay and combat are clean; the puzzles are intriguing enough; the voice acting is fairly well done (especially work done by Mark Hamill); and most enemy designs are intuitive and fun to fight. Speaking of enemies, instant killing enemies is such a joy!
 
However...

Darksiders is woefully uninspired. There is absolutely NOTHING original about this game. Everything about the combat, the puzzles, the level/game design, the level up schematic, and even the way you ride your horse (which you won't do very often) is borrowed from other game designs. If you have every played God of War and The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time you will quickly pick up on the tropes and cliches that this game uses. Also, the bosses are simple and gimmicky. Not to mention that the game is fairly easy, even on hard. Lastly, the lore is mildy interesting but the plot and story execution are weak and it just feels like set up for the sequel. 

Final Word: 
Don't take my criticism as me not liking the game. I did enjoy it but it is far from being a great game. If you like linear hack and slash action games like God of War and Devil May Cry then you will enjoy this game. However, if you are looking for something fresh, new, and innovative, then Darksiders simply won't fit the bill. 

P.S I recommend playing with a controller; better layout and feel. 

Happy Gaming!

23519628.review:
As many before it, it's a game about empowerment, growing stronger. You play as War, one of the Horsemen of the Apocalypse, who has been stripped of his powers, and are tasked with regaining War's former glory and proving his innocence to an atrocity he's being accused of. And boy is that former power being regained at a brisk pace, piece by piece. There's a constant stream of small pieces of increased abilities. There's always some trinket, power up, a new weapon or stat increase just behind the corner. It's like following a trail of treasure crumbs back home. The frequent small rewards provide a hook that makes it more difficult to put the game down. Just one more treasure, I found myself muttering.

The game progresses steadily and without too much effort from the player. The main obstacle between War and the treasures are enemies vanquishable by combat. The fights have just enough difficulty to keep the player engaged and unable to watch Netflix from another screen, but without much risk of stifling advancement and the player getting stuck in one spot for too long. Combat could be a tad more difficult to encourage utilizing the whole set of tools available to the player. As it is all fights resemble each other a lot, and straightforward button smashing is a bit more effective than I would like. Light puzzles sprinkled between and around combat encounters follow a similar pattern, where they activate a couple brain cells but shouldn't leave most people stumped for very long.

The main path is linear and straightforward, but small secrets hidden in the nooks and crannies keep anyone inclined to do so exploring a good while longer than would be necessary to progress the main quest. Oftentimes a strange contraption is encountered - a sure sign you can't quite go somewhere yet, but are meant to come back after acquiring some ability later on in the game. This kind of backtracking is frequent, but mostly optional. Only in the end is it necessary to visit most already previously seen areas in the game, but this is a quick excursion that highlights just how much more powerful War is at that point than he was before.

There's not much new and fresh here, but the familiar ingredients form an entertaining enough package. An adequate game to pass some time with and then put it down without having experienced grand revelations one way or the other.

23404913.review:
God of War with a Biblical backdrop; thats pretty much this game in nutshell. If you like the God of War series, this is right up your alley. 

The puzzles are great and inventive. You'll have to use some good problem solving skills at times to figure them out but they aren't overly taxing. The story itself is good, engaging, and enjoyable. The story comes in good amounts and at/and for the right amounts of time and place; you won't be overburdened with story when you wanna be killing things. 

The combat itself takes a little getting used to but isn't bad. I do feel the game suffers a little bit being being somewhat clunky and rigid when it comes to combat. You need to be aware of the other enemies and your environment around you when fighting because you won't always be able to target what you want, when you want, at the right time. 

You'll get other weapons besides the trademark sword but you won't ever see a need to use them. The weapon and item swap system in this game suffers from the same clunkiness and non-intuitiveness that the combat sometimes finds itself suffering from. 

Overall I would recommend this game to action, hack/slash fans out there. Its a worthy investment but know it has its flaws.

23247936.review:
MINIMALISTIC REVIEW:

[b]PROS:[/b]
[list]
    [*]The story basically taken from the Book of Revelations (from the Bible) with twists, which is awesome (APOCALYPSEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE-aahhhhhh).
    [*]Hyped gameplay.
    [*]UI is "apocalyptic" and pretty much describe War's personality.
    [*]HUD is simple and easy to memorize.
    [*]Enemies are amazing! Killing angels (pure and fallen) and demons and... ugh... [spoiler]spiders[/spoiler]. Oh yes, I gotta tell you: DEMONS DO LIKE REAL DEMONS.
    [*]Powers? Totally define a powerful doomsday horseman.
    [*]Puzzles are somehow easy. Just think, though and try to look around.
    [*]Finishers, finishers and more finishers!
    [*]The places given are amazing AF. It totally apocalyptic-looking.
    [*]Few weapons but they are enough, actually, and they are powerful.
    [*]Soundtrack is cool. Believe me.
[/list]

[b]CONS:[/b]
[list]
    [*]The controls are totally... hard to press when you are using PC and more comfortable when playing with a controller. Switching weapons and using powers while fighting is kinda hard when you play it for the first time but you'll do good later on.
    [*]SPOILERS > [spoiler]On the "prologue", I expected more people running, a lot of crashes on the building & roads and... you know, blood and gore but it lacks the apocalyptic feeling on that part. The rest are fine, though, so yeah...[/spoiler]
    [*]SFX is not appealing compared to the cutscene on the "prologue". Yeah, I know... it uses an old engine, but it's fine with me.
    [*]Game crashes sometimes. IDK if you do and will experience it or maybe it's just my laptop.
    [*]Some chests are hard to get and requires items that can be obtained when you play it long enough. Of course, after getting the items, "backtracking" towards the chests that you need to open is a pain in the butt (except if you use a guide).
    [*]I noticed that some of the enemies are kinda "copied", like the [spoiler]Hellguard angels and fallen angels[/spoilers]. It's annoying but I can live with it.
[/list]

OVERALL RATING: 8/10 would crash-party on the apocalyptic world again.

23242663.review: Es un gran juego, tiene una banda sonora espectacular, gráficamente no es malo, pero visualmente los escenarios son espectaculares, tiene una gran historia, la mayoría del juego son puzles pero así le dan emoción, simplemente te enganchas

23223711.review:
Se trata de un hack and slash a la antigua, estilo Devil May Cry; eso sí, con una historia que te tendrá enganchado y te forzará a continuar para conocer la verdad.

Aun así, como cualquier otro juego no se libra de tener sus inconvenientes, y algunos son bastante molestos, como el manejo parcialmente incómodo del shuriken cuando estás luchando y necesitas seleccionar varios objetivos antes de lanzarlo; objetivos que por supuesto no se van a quedar quietos esperando a que les ataques. Yo lo jugué en dificultad Normal, así que no sé cómo de fácil será la Fácil (valga la redundancia), pero al menos la Normal me ha parecido demasiado complicada por momentos, tanto por la cantidad y a veces potencia de algunos enemigos como la crisis que debe estar pasando Vulgrim para poner tan por las nubes los precios.

Pero al menos lo compensa como puede con la variedad de objetos, habilidades (las que te puedas permitir) y bastante variedad de desafíos, tales como explorar zonas, descubrir objetos ocultos, usar un objeto que te permite descubrir cosas que están ahí pero en otro plano, andar a caballo (cómo no xD) y, volviendo al principio, una historia llena de misterios que desvelar.

23122076.review:
Its a really good game, tho it is a little too simplistic.

The only "real" challenges come from the boss battles, and they feel more tedious than epic.....
I feel like this game would be better if it was scaled down a little. The areas you have to traverse are often very large and unpopulated, and the majority of the enemies are easily defeated by button mashing......

I like the looks, style and story a lot. The combat does get tedious, but it never really feels tedious, it just doesn't feel exciting. It's not bad, it is just unremarkable.

Darksiders 2 srtill feels overly large and empty, but the changes to the combat make the game a little more compelling........

If you like this genre pick this game up on sale, you may get bored before you finish it (like I did) but you'll get your 5 bucks worth ;)

23096763.review: Good hack and slash game, nice ghraphics decent story real fun for the money. Although something frustrating was there and that was those bugged achievements that didnt correspond your deeds... Altogether very decent game I'm buying the second game...

23092896.review: This was a fantastic hack and slash dungeon crawler that I enjoyed immensly. There are tons of secrets and upgrades to find with areas you have to revisit later on to get access to previously unreachable sections if you want to collect everything. The combat is brutal and bloody and the boss fights reminded me of Zelda games, challenging yet fair boss fights where you have to find each boss's weakness. Overall if you like action games I recommend picking this one up even at the full price. It does go on sale every couple of months if you are the patient type so your call!

23077904.review: I picked this game and Darksiders 2 during a sale bundle for both. The story, character design, combat and voice acting for this game are really top notch and getting deluxe editions of both games for less than $10 was a steal. However I encountered a bug after about 2 hours of gameplay (ignore the Steam tracker, it lies) that made the game unplayable since there was a puzzle that could not be finished without a sword that went poof. So while I reccomend you pick this game up do so only on sale and prepare to start all over again if your save encounters a game breaking bug. 7/10
